eng: "Which makes his good manners the more valuable. The older a person grows, Harriet, the more important it is that their manners should not be bad; the more glaring and disgusting any loudness, or coarseness, or awkwardness becomes. What is passable in youth is detestable in later age.
fr: M. Martin parait vulgaire, malgre sa jeunesse ; que sera-ce lorsqu'il aura atteint l'age de M. Weston ?

eng: Mr. Martin is now awkward and abrupt; what will he be at Mr. Weston's time of life?"
fr: -- Votre remarque est juste, dit Harriet d'un air grave.

eng: "There is no saying, indeed," replied Harriet rather solemnly. "But there may be pretty good guessing. He will be a completely gross, vulgar farmer, totally inattentive to appearances, and thinking of nothing but profit and loss."
fr: -- Il deviendra un gros fermier uniquement preoccupe de ses interets.

eng: "Will he, indeed? That will be very bad."
fr: -- Est-ce possible ? Ce serait epouvantable !

eng: "How much his business engrosses him already is very plain from the circumstance of his forgetting to inquire for the book you recommended. He was a great deal too full of the market to think of any thing else--which is just as it should be, for a thriving man. What has he to do with books? And I have no doubt that he _will_ thrive, and be a very rich man in time--and his being illiterate and coarse need not disturb _us_."
fr: -- Le fait d'avoir oublie de se procurer le livre que vous lui aviez recommande indique suffisamment combien ses devoirs professionnels l'absorbent deja ; il etait beaucoup trop occupe des fluctuations du marche pour penser a autre chose, ce qui est fort naturel chez un homme qui gagne sa vie.

eng: "I wonder he did not remember the book"--was all Harriet's answer, and spoken with a degree of grave displeasure which Emma thought might be safely left to itself.
fr: -- Je suis etonnee qu'il ait oublie le livre, dit Harriet d'un ton de regret.

eng: She, therefore, said no more for some time. Her next beginning was, "In one respect, perhaps, Mr. Elton's manners are superior to Mr. Knightley's or Mr. Weston's. They have more gentleness.
fr: Apres avoir laisse a Harriet le temps de mediter sur cette negligence, Emma reprit : << A un certain point de vue on peut dire que les manieres de M. Elton sont superieures a celles de M. Knightley et de M. Weston.

eng: They might be more safely held up as a pattern. There is an openness, a quickness, almost a bluntness in Mr. Weston, which every body likes in _him_, because there is so much good-humour with it--but that would not do to be copied. Neither would Mr. Knightley's downright, decided, commanding sort of manner, though it suits _him_ very well; his figure, and look, and situation in life seem to allow it; but if any young man were to set about copying him, he would not be sufferable.
fr: Il y a chez ce dernier une vivacite, une sorte de brusquerie qui s'adaptent a son temperament chez lui, mais il ne conviendrait pas de l'imiter ; de meme la maniere decidee, imperieuse de M. Knightley s'accorde parfaitement avec son esprit, sa taille et sa situation sociale ; pourtant si un jeune homme s'avisait de l'adopter, il ne serait pas supportable.'

eng: Did not I tell you what he said of you the other day?"
fr: 'Vous ai-je repete tous les compliments qu'il m'a faits de vous l'autre jour ?

eng: She then repeated some warm personal praise which she had drawn from Mr. Elton, and now did full justice to; and Harriet blushed and smiled, and said she had always thought Mr. Elton very agreeable.
fr: >> Emma en rapportant ces propos flatteurs omit de dire qu'elle les avait encourages. Harriet rougit de plaisir et protesta avoir toujours trouve M. Elton tres agreable ;

eng: Mr. Elton was the very person fixed on by Emma for driving the young farmer out of Harriet's head.
fr: ce dernier etait precisement la personne sur laquelle Emma avait jete son devolu pour faire oublier a Harriet son jeune fermier.

eng: She thought it would be an excellent match; and only too palpably desirable, natural, and probable, for her to have much merit in planning it.
fr: La position sociale de M. Elton lui paraissait particulierement adaptee a la situation ; il etait tres comme il faut, sans pourtant appartenir a une famille que la naissance irreguliere d'Harriet pourrait offusquer.

eng: She feared it was what every body else must think of and predict.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It was not likely, however, that any body should have equalled her in the date of the plan, as it had entered her brain during the very first evening of Harriet's coming to Hartfield.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The longer she considered it, the greater was her sense of its expediency.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Mr. Elton's situation was most suitable, quite the gentleman himself, and without low connexions; at the same time, not of any family that could fairly object to the doubtful birth of Harriet.
fr: Les revenus personnels du jeune vicaire devaient etre suffisants car la cure de Hartfield n'etait pas importante.

eng: He had a comfortable home for her, and Emma imagined a very sufficient income; for though the vicarage of Highbury was not large, he was known to have some independent property; and she thought very highly of him as a good-humoured, well-meaning, respectable young man, without any deficiency of useful understanding or knowledge of the world.
fr: Elle avait une tres bonne opinion de lui et le considerait comme un jeune homme d'avenir.

eng: She had already satisfied herself that he thought Harriet a beautiful girl, which she trusted, with such frequent meetings at Hartfield, was foundation enough on his side; and on Harriet's there could be little doubt that the idea of being preferred by him would have all the usual weight and efficacy.
fr: Elle ne doutait pas qu'il n'admirat beaucoup Harriet et elle comptait sur de frequentes rencontres a Hartfield pour developper ce sentiment ; quant a Harriet, il lui suffirait sans doute de s'apercevoir de la preference dont elle serait l'objet pour l'apprecier aussitot a sa juste valeur.

eng: And he was really a very pleasing young man, a young man whom any woman not fastidious might like.
fr: M. Elton, du reste, pouvait legitimement avoir la pretention de plaire a la plupart des femmes ; il passait pour un tres bel homme ;

eng: He was reckoned very handsome; his person much admired in general, though not by her, there being a want of elegance of feature which she could not dispense with:--but the girl who could be gratified by a Robert Martin's riding about the country to get walnuts for her might very well be conquered by Mr. Elton's admiration.
fr: Emma pour sa part ne partageait pas l'opinion generale, elle jugeait que le visage de M. Elton manquait d'une certaine noblesse qu'elle prisait par dessus tout ; mais il lui paraissait evident que la jeune fille qui avait pu etre flattee des attentions de Robert Martin serait vite conquise par les hommages de M. Elton.

eng: "I do not know what your opinion may be, Mrs. Weston," said Mr. Knightley, "of this great intimacy between Emma and Harriet Smith, but I think it a bad thing."
fr: V -- Je ne sais quelle est votre opinion, Mme Weston, dit M. Knightley, sur l'intimite qui est en train de s'etablir entre Emma et Henriette Smith. Quant a moi, je ne l'approuve pas.

eng: "A bad thing! Do you really think it a bad thing?--why so?"
fr: -- Vraiment ! Et pourquoi ?

eng: "I think they will neither of them do the other any good."
fr: -- Je crains qu'elles n'aient une facheuse influence l'une sur l'autre.

eng: "You surprize me! Emma must do Harriet good: and by supplying her with a new object of interest, Harriet may be said to do Emma good. I have been seeing their intimacy with the greatest pleasure.
fr: -- Vous m'etonnez, Harriet ne peut que gagner a ce contact et d'autre part, en devenant pour Emma un objet d'interet, elle rendra indirectement service a son amie.

eng: How very differently we feel!--Not think they will do each other any good! This will certainly be the beginning of one of our quarrels about Emma, Mr. Knightley."
fr: Je prevois que cette divergence d'opinions va servir de preface a une de nos querelles a propos d'Emma.

eng: "Perhaps you think I am come on purpose to quarrel with you, knowing Weston to be out, and that you must still fight your own battle."
fr: -- Vous l'avez devine sans doute : je profite de l'absence de M. Weston pour livrer bataille. Il faut que vous vous defendiez toute seule comme autrefois.

eng: "Mr. Weston would undoubtedly support me, if he were here, for he thinks exactly as I do on the subject. We were speaking of it only yesterday, and agreeing how fortunate it was for Emma, that there should be such a girl in Highbury for her to associate with.
fr: -- M. Weston, s'il etait la, serait assurement de mon cote, car il partage entierement ma maniere de voir : nous parlions precisement d'Emma, hier soir, et nous etions d'accord pour considerer comme une bonne fortune qu'il se soit trouve, a Hartfield, une jeune fille en situation de lui tenir compagnie.'

eng: If he means any thing, it must be to please you.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Mr. Knightley, I shall not allow you to be a fair judge in this case.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I can imagine your objection to Harriet Smith.
fr: Je vois venir votre objection relativement a Harriet Smith :

eng: She is not the superior young woman which Emma's friend ought to be.
fr: ce n'est pas la jeune fille superieure que devrait etre l'amie d'Emma...

eng: But on the other hand, as Emma wants to see her better informed, it will be an inducement to her to read more herself. They will read together.
fr: mais d'autre part, je sais qu'Emma se propose de lire avec Harriet, ce sera pour elle une occasion de s'occuper serieusement.

eng: She means it, I know.
fr: -- Depuis qu'elle a douze ans, Emma a l'intention de s'adonner a la lecture.

eng: Emma has been meaning to read more ever since she was twelve years old.
fr: Elle a dresse a differentes epoques la liste des ouvrages qu'elle voulait lire.

eng: I have seen a great many lists of her drawing-up at various times of books that she meant to read regularly through--and very good lists they were--very well chosen, and very neatly arranged--sometimes alphabetically, and sometimes by some other rule.
fr: Je me rappelle avoir conserve un plan d'etudes compose a quatorze ans et qui faisait honneur a son jugement.

eng: The list she drew up when only fourteen--I remember thinking it did her judgment so much credit, that I preserved it some time; and I dare say she may have made out a very good list now.
fr: Mais j'ai renonce a attendre d'Emma un effort serieux dans ce sens ;

eng: But I have done with expecting any course of steady reading from Emma.
fr: jamais elle ne se soumettra a un travail qui exige de la patience et de la suite.

eng: She will never submit to any thing requiring industry and patience, and a subjection of the fancy to the understanding.
fr: A coup sur la ou Mlle Taylor a echoue, Harriet Smith ne reussira pas !

eng: Where Miss Taylor failed to stimulate, I may safely affirm that Harriet Smith will do nothing.
fr: Vous savez bien que vous n'avez jamais pu obtenir qu'elle consacrat a la lecture le temps necessaire.

eng: You never could persuade her to read half so much as you wished.
fr: -- Il est possible, repondit Mme Weston en souriant, que tel ait ete mon avis a cette epoque, mais depuis notre separation j'ai perdu tout souvenir qu'Emma ait jamais refuse de complaire a mes desirs.

eng: You know you could not.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I dare say," replied Mrs. Weston, smiling, "that I thought so _then_;--but since we have parted, I can never remember Emma's omitting to do any thing I wished.
fr: -- Il serait cruel de chercher a guerir ce genre d'amnesie, repondit M. Knightley affectueusement, mais moi dont aucun charme n'a emousse les sens, je vois, j'entends et je me rappelle.

eng: There is hardly any desiring to refresh such a memory as _that_,"--said Mr. Knightley, feelingly; and for a moment or two he had done.
fr: Ce qui a gate Emma c'est d'etre la plus intelligente de sa famille ;

eng: But I," he soon added, "who have had no such charm thrown over my senses, must still see, hear, and remember.
fr: elle a toujours fait preuve de vivacite d'esprit et d'assurance : Isabelle, au contraire, etait timide et d'intelligence moyenne.

eng: Emma is spoiled by being the cleverest of her family.
fr: Depuis l'age de douze ans, c'est la volonte d'Emma qui a prevalu a Hartfield.

eng: At ten years old, she had the misfortune of being able to answer questions which puzzled her sister at seventeen.
fr: En perdant sa mere, elle a perdu la seule personne qui aurait pu lui tenir tete.

eng: She was always quick and assured: Isabella slow and diffident.
fr: Elle a herite de l'intelligence de Mme Woodhouse, mais le joug maternel lui a manque.

eng: And ever since she was twelve, Emma has been mistress of the house and of you all.
fr: Si j'avais quitte la famille de M. Woodhouse pour chercher une autre situation, je n'aurais pas voulu dependre d'une recommandation de votre part ;

eng: In her mother she lost the only person able to cope with her.
fr: vous n'auriez fait mes eloges a personne et je me rends compte que vous m'avez toujours jugee inferieure a la charge que j'avais assumee.

eng: She inherits her mother's talents, and must have been under subjection to her.
fr: Oui, dit-il en souriant, vous etes plus a votre place ici.

eng: I should have been sorry, Mr. Knightley, to be dependent on _your_ recommendation, had I quitted Mr. Woodhouse's family and wanted another situation; I do not think you would have spoken a good word for me to any body.
fr: Vous vous prepariez, pendant votre sejour a Hartfield, a devenir une epouse modele.

eng: I am sure you always thought me unfit for the office I held.
fr: Sans doute, vous n'avez peut-etre pas donne a Emma une education aussi complete qu'auraient pu le faire supposer vos capacites ;

eng: Yes," said he, smiling.
fr: mais, en revanche, vous appreniez d'elle a plier votre volonte pour la soumission conjugale ;

eng: You are better placed _here_; very fit for a wife, but not at all for a governess.
fr: si M. Weston m'avait consulte a la veille de prendre femme, je n'aurais pas manque de lui indiquer Mlle Taylor.

eng: But you were preparing yourself to be an excellent wife all the time you were at Hartfield.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: You might not give Emma such a complete education as your powers would seem to promise; but you were receiving a very good education from _her_, on the very material matrimonial point of submitting your own will, and doing as you were bid; and if Weston had asked me to recommend him a wife, I should certainly have named Miss Taylor.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "There will be very little merit in making a good wife to such a man as Mr. Weston."
fr: 'Il y aura, du reste, peu de merite a etre une femme devouee avec un mari comme M. Weston.'

eng: "Why, to own the truth, I am afraid you are rather thrown away, and that with every disposition to bear, there will be nothing to be borne."
fr: 'A dire vrai, je crains, en effet, que vous ne soyez pas appelee a donner la mesure de votre abnegation.'

eng: "We will not despair, however. Weston may grow cross from the wantonness of comfort, or his son may plague him."
fr: 'Ne desesperons pas pourtant : Weston peut devenir grognon a force de bien-etre ; son fils peut lui causer des ennuis.'

eng: "Not I, indeed."
fr: "-- Mes suppositions sont toutes gratuites."

eng: "I only name possibilities."
fr: "Je ne pretends pas aucunement avoir la clairvoyance d'Emma, ni son genie de prophetie."

eng: "I do not pretend to Emma's genius for foretelling and guessing."
fr: "Je ne pretends pas aucunement avoir la clairvoyance d'Emma, ni son genie de prophetie."

eng: "I hope, with all my heart, the young man may be a Weston in merit, and a Churchill in fortune."
fr: "J'espere de tout mon coeur que le jeune homme tiendra des Weston pour le merite et des Churchill pour la fortune !"

eng: "--But Harriet Smith--I have not half done about Harriet Smith."
fr: "Mais quant a Harriet Smith - je reviens a mes moutons !"

eng: "I think her the very worst sort of companion that Emma could possibly have."
fr: "je persiste a la considerer comme tout a fait impropre a tenir aupres d'Emma le role d'amie"

eng: "She knows nothing herself, and looks upon Emma as knowing every thing."
fr: "elle ne sait rien et considere Emma comme omnisciente !"

eng: I am much mistaken if Emma's doctrines give any strength of mind, or tend at all to make a girl adapt herself rationally to the varieties of her situation in life.--They only give a little polish.
fr: Je serais bien etonne si les doctrines d'Emma avaient pour resultat de former le caractere tout au plus peuvent-elles donner un leger vernis.

eng: "I either depend more upon Emma's good sense than you do, or am more anxious for her present comfort; for I cannot lament the acquaintance.
fr: -- Est-ce parce que je me fie au bon sens d'Emma, ou bien suis-je avant tout preoccupee de son bien-etre actuel, toujours est-il que je ne puis partager vos craintes.

eng: How well she looked last night!"
fr: Combien elle etait a son avantage, hier soir !

eng: "Oh!'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Pretty! say beautiful rather. Can you imagine any thing nearer perfect beauty than Emma altogether--face and figure?"
fr: '-- Jolie ! dites plutot parfaitement belle. -- En tout cas je ne connais pas de visage qui me plaise plus, mais je suis un si vieil ami que mon jugement reste entache de partialite.

eng: "I do not know what I could imagine, but I confess that I have seldom seen a face or figure more pleasing to me than hers. But I am a partial old friend."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Such an eye!--the true hazle eye--and so brilliant! regular features, open countenance, with a complexion! ~~~ oh! what a bloom of full health, and such a pretty height and size; such a firm and upright figure! ~~~ There is health, not merely in her bloom, but in her air, her head, her glance. One hears sometimes of a child being 'the picture of health;' now, Emma always gives me the idea of being the complete picture of grown-up health. She is loveliness itself. ~~~ Mr. Knightley, is not she?"
fr: -- Quelle vivacite dans le regard ! Des traits reguliers, un teint eblouissant, une taille parfaite ! On dit parfois qu'un enfant respire la sante : cette expression, il me semble, s'applique dans toute sa plenitude a Emma.

eng: "I have not a fault to find with her person," he replied. "I think her all you describe. I love to look at her; and I will add this praise, that I do not think her personally vain. Considering how very handsome she is, she appears to be little occupied with it; her vanity lies another way. Mrs. Weston, I am not to be talked out of my dislike of Harriet Smith, or my dread of its doing them both harm."
fr: -- Je n'ai rien a redire a sa personne et votre description est exacte ; j'aime a la regarder et j'ajouterai un compliment : je ne la crois pas vaniteuse. Quoiqu'il en soit, Madame Weston, vous n'arriverez pas a me persuader que cette amitie avec Harriet Smith ne soit pas nuisible pour toutes deux.

eng: "And I, Mr. Knightley, am equally stout in my confidence of its not doing them any harm. With all dear Emma's little faults, she is an excellent creature. Where shall we see a better daughter, or a kinder sister, or a truer friend? No, no; she has qualities which may be trusted; she will never lead any one really wrong; she will make no lasting blunder; where Emma errs once, she is in the right a hundred times."
fr: -- Et moi, monsieur Knightley, je reste convaincu qu'il n'en sortira aucun dommage. Malgre ses petits defauts, Emma est excellente. Ou trouverez-vous une fille plus devouee, une soeur plus affectueuse, une amie plus sure ? Quand elle se trompe, elle reconnait vite son erreur.

eng: "Very well; I will not plague you any more. Emma shall be an angel, and I will keep my spleen to myself till Christmas brings John and Isabella. John loves Emma with a reasonable and therefore not a blind affection, and Isabella always thinks as he does; except when he is not quite frightened enough about the children. I am sure of having their opinions with me."
fr: -- Je ne vous tourmenterai pas plus longtemps. Admettons qu'Emma soit un ange. Je garderai ma mauvaise humeur pour moi jusqu'a ce que Noel amene Jean et Isabelle. Jean aime Emma d'une affection raisonnable qui par consequent n'est pas aveugle, et Isabelle adopte toujours l'avis de son mari, excepte en ce qui concerne la sante et les soins de ses enfants. Je connais d'avance leur opinion.

eng: "I know that you all love her really too well to be unjust or unkind; but excuse me, Mr. Knightley, if I take the liberty (I consider myself, you know, as having somewhat of the privilege of speech that Emma's mother might have had) the liberty of hinting that I do not think any possible good can arise from Harriet Smith's intimacy being made a matter of much discussion among you."
fr: -- Je suis convaincue que vous l'aimez tous trop sincerement pour etre injustes ou severes ; mais permettez-moi, Monsieur Knightley, -- je me considere, vous le savez, comme ayant un peu le privilege de parler au nom de la mere d'Emma, - de vous suggerer les inconvenients qui pourraient surgir de la mise en discussion parmi vous de l'amitie d'Emma pour Harriet.

eng: "Be satisfied," said he, "I will not raise any outcry.
fr: '-- Soyez satisfaite : je ne jetterai pas le cri d'alarme.

eng: I will keep my ill-humour to myself. I have a very sincere interest in Emma.
fr: J'eprouve pour Emma un sentiment de sincere interet auquel se mele un peu d'inquietude.

eng: There is an anxiety, a curiosity in what one feels for Emma. I wonder what will become of her!"
fr: Je me demande quelle sera sa destinee !

eng: "So do I," said Mrs. Weston gently, "very much."
fr: -- Cette question me preoccupe beaucoup aussi.

eng: "She always declares she will never marry, which, of course, means just nothing at all.
fr: -- Elle declare toujours qu'elle ne se mariera jamais, ce qui, naturellement, ne signifie rien ;

eng: But I have no idea that she has yet ever seen a man she cared for.
fr: mais elle n'a pas, je crois, rencontre encore un homme qui lui plaise.'

eng: Isabella does not seem more my sister; has never excited a greater interest; perhaps hardly so great. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It would not be a bad thing for her to be very much in love with a proper object. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I should like to see Emma in love, and in some doubt of a return; it would do her good. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: There were wishes at Randalls respecting Emma's destiny, but it was not desirable to have them suspected;
fr: 'Mme Weston avait une arriere-pensee qu'elle s'efforcait de ne pas laisser paraitre : elle et son mari nourrissaient un projet concernant l'avenir d'Emma, mais ils jugeaient desirable de le tenir secret.

eng: and the quiet transition which Mr. Knightley soon afterwards made to "What does Weston think of the weather; shall we have rain?" convinced her that he had nothing more to say or surmise about Hartfield.
fr: Peu apres, M. Knightley reprit : -- Qu'est-ce que Weston pense du temps ; croit-il qu'il va pleuvoir ? et il se leva pour prendre conge.

eng: Emma could not feel a doubt of having given Harriet's fancy a proper direction and raised the gratitude of her young vanity to a very good purpose,
fr: VI Emma s'apercut bientot du succes de ses efforts pour donner a l'imagination d'Harriet un nouvel aliment : celle-ci ne tarda pas a apprecier comme il convenait les avantages physiques de M. Elton et l'agrement de ses manieres.

eng: for she found her decidedly more sensible than before of Mr. Elton's being a remarkably handsome man, with most agreeable manners;
fr: D'autre part, elle etait convaincue que ce dernier etait bien pres d'etre amoureux, s'il ne l'etait pas deja.

eng: and as she had no hesitation in following up the assurance of his admiration by agreeable hints, she was soon pretty confident of creating as much liking on Harriet's side, as there could be any occasion for.
fr: Il exprimait son appreciation des progres realises par Harriet depuis sa venue a Hartfield dans des termes qui paraissaient concluants : -- Vous avez donne a Mlle Smith ce qui lui manquait : l'aisance et le gout.

eng: She was quite convinced of Mr. Elton's being in the fairest way of falling in love, if not in love already.
fr: C'etait une ravissante creature lorsque vous l'avez connue, mais a mon avis les attraits dont vous l'avez ornee surpassent de beaucoup ceux qu'elle devait a la nature.

eng: She had no scruple with regard to him.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He talked of Harriet, and praised her so warmly, that she could not suppose any thing wanting which a little time would not add.
fr: -- Je suis heureuse de penser que mes conseils lui ont ete utiles ; mais a dire vrai Harriet possedait toutes les aptitudes. Mon oeuvre se reduit a peu de chose.

eng: His perception of the striking improvement of Harriet's manner, since her introduction at Hartfield, was not one of the least agreeable proofs of his growing attachment.
fr: -- S'il etait permis de contredire une femme... dit galamment M. Elton.

eng: "You have given Miss Smith all that she required," said he; "you have made her graceful and easy.
fr: -- Peut-etre son caractere a-t-il acquis un peu plus de decision : je lui ai suggere quelques points sur lesquels sa pensee n'avait pas l'habitude de s'arreter.

eng: She was a beautiful creature when she came to you, but, in my opinion, the attractions you have added are infinitely superior to what she received from nature."
fr: -- Precisement. Et ce resultat a ete obtenu en si peu de temps. Quelle legerete de touche !

eng: "I am glad you think I have been useful to her; but Harriet only wanted drawing out, and receiving a few, very few hints.
fr: -- Dites plutot : quelle culture facile ! Je n'ai jamais rencontre un esprit plus souple.

eng: She had all the natural grace of sweetness of temper and artlessness in herself.
fr: -- Je n'en doute pas.

eng: I have done very little."
fr: Quelques jours apres, au cours d'une conversation, elle demanda a Harriet en presence de M. Elton.

eng: "If it were admissible to contradict a lady," said the gallant Mr. Elton--
fr: -- A-t-on jamais fait votre portrait Harriet ?

eng: "I have perhaps given her a little more decision of character, have taught her to think on points which had not fallen in her way before."
fr: A ce moment, on vint appeler Harriet de la part de Mme Goddard.

eng: "Exactly so; that is what principally strikes me. So much superadded decision of character! Skilful has been the hand!"
fr: Avant de quitter le salon elle s'arreta une minute pour repondre avec une naivete charmante : -- Mais non, jamais.

eng: "Great has been the pleasure, I am sure. I never met with a disposition more truly amiable."
fr: Des qu'elle fut sortie Emma dit : -- Comme il serait agreable d'avoir un bon portrait d'elle ; j'ai presqu'envie de m'y essayer moi-meme.

eng: "I have no doubt of it."
fr: Vous ne le savez pas sans doute, mais il y a deux ou trois ans, je me suis adonnee avec passion a peindre des portraits ; puis le gout m'en est passe.

eng: And it was spoken with a sort of sighing animation, which had a vast deal of the lover.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She was not less pleased another day with the manner in which he seconded a sudden wish of hers, to have Harriet's picture.
fr: Nonobstant si Harriet voulait poser pour moi, je me risquerais encore une fois.

eng: "Did you ever have your likeness taken, Harriet?" said she: "did you ever sit for your picture?"
fr: -- Laissez-moi vous prier, mademoiselle Woodhouse, s'ecria M. Elton, d'exercer votre charmant talent en faveur de votre amie.

eng: Harriet was on the point of leaving the room, and only stopt to say, with a very interesting naivete, "Oh! dear, no, never."
fr: Je connais vos oeuvres. Comment pouvez-vous supposer le contraire ? Ce salon n'est-il pas tapisse de fleurs et de paysages dus a votre pinceau ?

eng: No sooner was she out of sight, than Emma exclaimed, "What an exquisite possession a good picture of her would be! I would give any money for it.
fr: ~~~ D'autre part ; j'ai pu examiner chez Mme Weston quelques delicieux specimens de vos dessins.

eng: I almost long to attempt her likeness myself.
fr: << Oui, excellent jeune homme, pensa Emma, mais ceci n'a rien a voir avec le don de la ressemblance ! Vous n'y entendez rien ! Ne simulez pas l'admiration pour ma peinture ; gardez la plutot pour Harriet ! >>

eng: You do not know it I dare say, but two or three years ago I had a great passion for taking likenesses, and attempted several of my friends, and was thought to have a tolerable eye in general.
fr: Puis elle reprit : -- Eh bien ! Monsieur Elton, puisque vous m'encouragez si aimablement, je crois que je vais essayer mes forces ; les traits d'Harriet sont si fins qu'il sera difficile d'en rendre toute la delicatesse ; cependant il y a dans la forme de l'oeil et dans le contour de la bouche quelque chose de si caracteristique que la ressemblance ne doit pas etre impossible a saisir.

eng: But from one cause or another, I gave it up in disgust.
fr: -- Vous dites bien : la forme de l'oeil et de la bouche !

eng: But really, I could almost venture, if Harriet would sit to me. It would be such a delight to have her picture!"
fr: ~~~ Vous reussirez certainement. Ce sera une oeuvre exquise !

eng: "Let me entreat you," cried Mr. Elton; "it would indeed be a delight! Let me entreat you, Miss Woodhouse, to exercise so charming a talent in favour of your friend.
fr: -- Mais je crains bien, Monsieur Elton, qu'Harriet ne se prete pas de bonne grace a ce desir : elle attache si peu d'importance a sa beaute.

eng: I know what your drawings are. How could you suppose me ignorant? Is not this room rich in specimens of your landscapes and flowers; and has not Mrs. Weston some inimitable figure-pieces in her drawing-room, at Randalls?"
fr: N'avez-vous pas observe avec quel detachement elle a repondu a ma question ? C'etait dire : << A quel propos aurait-on fait mon portrait ?'

eng: Yes, good man!--thought Emma--but what has all that to do with taking likenesses? You know nothing of drawing. Don't pretend to be in raptures about mine. Keep your raptures for Harriet's face.
"Well, if you give me such kind encouragement, Mr. Elton, I believe I shall try what I can do.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Harriet's features are very delicate, which makes a likeness difficult; and yet there is a peculiarity in the shape of the eye and the lines about the mouth which one ought to catch."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Exactly so--The shape of the eye and the lines about the mouth--I have not a doubt of your success. Pray, pray attempt it. As you will do it, it will indeed, to use your own words, be an exquisite possession."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "But I am afraid, Mr. Elton, Harriet will not like to sit. She thinks so little of her own beauty.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Did not you observe her manner of answering me? How completely it meant, 'why should my picture be drawn?'"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Harriet was soon back again, and the proposal almost immediately made; and she had no scruples which could stand many minutes against the earnest pressing of both the others.
fr: Harriet revint au bout de quelques instants : elle ne se fit pas prier longtemps et apres avoir faiblement proteste acquiesca a la proposition de son amie.

eng: Emma wished to go to work directly, and therefore produced the portfolio containing her various attempts at portraits, for not one of them had ever been finished, that they might decide together on the best size for Harriet.
fr: Emma voulut se mettre au travail sans retard et en consequence alla chercher un portefeuille contenant diverses ebauches. Aucun des portraits entrepris n'avait ete termine. Ils chercherent ensemble le procede qui conviendrait le mieux.

eng: Her many beginnings were displayed.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Miniatures, half-lengths, whole-lengths, pencil, crayon, and water-colours had been all tried in turn.
fr: Emma avait essaye de tout : miniature, pastel, crayon, aquarelle.

eng: She had always wanted to do every thing, and had made more progress both in drawing and music than many might have done with so little labour as she would ever submit to.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She played and sang;--and drew in almost every style; but steadiness had always been wanting; and in nothing had she approached the degree of excellence which she would have been glad to command, and ought not to have failed of.
fr: Mais la perseverance lui faisait defaut et, malgre ses dons naturels, elle ne reussissait pas a atteindre de degre de perfection qu'elle ambitionnait.

eng: They were both in ecstasies.
fr: Ils etaient tous deux en extase.

eng: A likeness pleases every body; and Miss Woodhouse's performances must be capital.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "No great variety of faces for you," said Emma.
fr: Il n'y a pas grande variete, dit Emma.

eng: "I had only my own family to study from.
fr: Je n'avais que les membres de ma famille comme modeles :

eng: There is my father--another of my father--but the idea of sitting for his picture made him so nervous, that I could only take him by stealth; neither of them very like therefore.
fr: voici mon pere, le voici encore une fois, mais cela le rendait si nerveux de poser que j'en etais reduite a dessiner a son insu ; en consequence, la ressemblance est mediocre...

eng: Mrs. Weston again, and again, and again, you see. Dear Mrs. Weston! always my kindest friend on every occasion. She would sit whenever I asked her.
fr: Voici Mme Weston sous toutes ses faces !

eng: There is my sister; and really quite her own little elegant figure!--and the face not unlike.
fr: Voici ma soeur : c'est bien sa silhouette elegante et son aimable figure ; j'aurais, je crois, bien reussi ce portrait, mais Isabelle etait tellement preoccupee de me voir commencer celui de ses quatre enfants qu'elle ne tenait pas en place...

eng: I should have made a good likeness of her, if she would have sat longer, but she was in such a hurry to have me draw her four children that she would not be quiet.

Then, here come all my attempts at three of those four children;--there they are, Henry and John and Bella, from one end of the sheet to the other, and any one of them might do for any one of the rest.
fr: Enfin voici les croquis des trois aines : Henry, Jean et Bella ; chacun de ces dessins pourrait, du reste, s'appliquer aussi bien a l'un qu'a l'autre ;

eng: She was so eager to have them drawn that I could not refuse; but there is no making children of three or four years old stand still you know; nor can it be very easy to take any likeness of them, beyond the air and complexion, unless they are coarser featured than any of mama's children ever were.
fr: comme vous pouvez l'imaginer, il n'y a pas moyen de faire tenir tranquilles des enfants de trois et quatre ans ; de plus tous ces petits visages se ressemblent...

eng: Here is my sketch of the fourth, who was a baby. I took him as he was sleeping on the sofa, and it is as strong a likeness of his cockade as you would wish to see. He had nestled down his head most conveniently. That's very like. I am rather proud of little George. The corner of the sofa is very good.
fr: Voila le quatrieme qui n'etait encore qu'un bebe ; je l'ai dessine pendant qu'il dormait sur le sofa : c'est l'exacte ressemblance de son petit bonnet, car il avait pris soin de dissimuler sa figure pour ma plus grande commodite. Je suis assez fiere de ce portrait du petit Georges !...

eng: Then here is my last,"--unclosing a pretty sketch of a gentleman in small size, whole-length--"my last and my best--my brother, Mr. John Knightley.--This did not want much of being finished, when I put it away in a pet, and vowed I would never take another likeness.
fr: Voici mon dernier ouvrage ; mon beau-frere, M. Jean Knightley, avait consenti a poser ; apres m'etre donne beaucoup de peine, j'etais assez satisfaite du resultat ; tandis que je me preparais a placer les dernieres retouches, Isabelle s'approcha pour donner son avis :

eng: I could not help being provoked; for after all my pains, and when I had really made a very good likeness of it--(Mrs. Weston and I were quite agreed in thinking it _very_ like)--only too handsome--too flattering--but that was a fault on the right side"--after all this, came poor dear Isabella's cold approbation of--"Yes, it was a little like--but to be sure it did not do him justice.
fr: << Je vois bien une petite ressemblance, mais je suis forcee de constater que M. Jean Knightley est beaucoup mieux en realite. >> C'est tout ce qu'elle trouva a dire. J'en eprouvai un veritable depit d'autant plus que le modele etait indiscutablement flatte.

eng: We had had a great deal of trouble in persuading him to sit at all. It was made a great favour of; and altogether it was more than I could bear; and so I never would finish it, to have it apologised over as an unfavourable likeness, to every morning visitor in Brunswick Square;--and, as I said, I did then forswear ever drawing any body again.
fr: Je m'etais bien promis de ne plus m'exposer a des deboires de ce genre ; neanmoins je suis disposee, en l'honneur d'Harriet, a manquer a mon voeu, puisqu'il n'y a pas, dans le cas present, d'amour-propre conjugal en jeu...

eng: But for Harriet's sake, or rather for my own, and as there are no husbands and wives in the case _at_ _present_, I will break my resolution now."
fr: pour le moment du moins !

eng: Mr. Elton seemed very properly struck and delighted by the idea, and was repeating, "No husbands and wives in the case at present indeed, as you observe. Exactly so. ~~~ No husbands and wives," with so interesting a consciousness, that Emma began to consider whether she had not better leave them together at once. But as she wanted to be drawing, the declaration must wait a little longer.
fr: Apres quelques hesitations, Emma se decida pour un portrait en pied, a l'aquarelle. La seance commenca.

eng: She had soon fixed on the size and sort of portrait. It was to be a whole-length in water-colours, like Mr. John Knightley's, and was destined, if she could please herself, to hold a very honourable station over the mantelpiece.
fr: Harriet rougissante et souriante sous l'oeil attentif de l'artiste, reunissait toutes les graces de la jeunesse.

eng: The sitting began; and Harriet, smiling and blushing, and afraid of not keeping her attitude and countenance, presented a very sweet mixture of youthful expression to the steady eyes of the artist. But there was no doing any thing, with Mr. Elton fidgeting behind her and watching every touch.
fr: Mais Emma sentait qu'elle ne pourrait rien faire tant que M. Elton se tiendrait a ses cotes, observant chaque coup de crayon.

eng: She gave him credit for stationing himself where he might gaze and gaze again without offence; but was really obliged to put an end to it, and request him to place himself elsewhere.
fr: Tout d'abord elle ne dit rien pour lui laisser toute latitude de contempler le modele ; au bout de quelques minutes elle fut obligee de mettre un terme a cette agitation et de le prier de s'eloigner.

eng: It then occurred to her to employ him in reading. "If he would be so good as to read to them, it would be a kindness indeed! It would amuse away the difficulties of her part, and lessen the irksomeness of Miss Smith's."
fr: Il lui vint ensuite a l'idee de l'occuper a lire. -- Si vous vouliez etre assez aimable pour nous lire a haute voix, je travaillerais plus librement et le temps paraitrait moins long a Mlle Smith.

eng: Mr. Elton was only too happy. Harriet listened, and Emma drew in peace.
fr: L'interpelle se declara trop heureux de se rendre utile. Harriet ecoutait et Emma dessinait en paix.

eng: She must allow him to be still frequently coming to look; any thing less would certainly have been too little in a lover; and he was ready at the smallest intermission of the pencil, to jump up and see the progress, and be charmed.--There was no being displeased with such an encourager, for his admiration made him discern a likeness almost before it was possible.
fr: Elle dut pourtant autoriser M. Elton a venir de temps en temps jeter un coup d'oeil et celui-ci s'extasiait a chaque progres ; c'etait un critique encourageant qui distinguait la ressemblance avant meme que les elements constitutifs en fussent assembles !

eng: She could not respect his eye, but his love and his complaisance were unexceptionable.
fr: Si Emma tenait en petite estime la competence artistique de M. Elton, elle ne pouvait que se rejouir de son aveuglement d'amoureux.

eng: The sitting was altogether very satisfactory; she was quite enough pleased with the first day's sketch to wish to go on. There was no want of likeness, she had been fortunate in the attitude, and as she meant to throw in a little improvement to the figure, to give a little more height, and considerably more elegance, she had great confidence of its being in every way a pretty drawing at last, and of its filling its destined place with credit to them both--a standing memorial of the beauty of one, the skill of the other, and the friendship of both; with as many other agreeable associations as Mr. Elton's very promising attachment was likely to add.
fr: La seance fut satisfaisante a tous les points de vue : Emma etait assez contente de cette premiere esquisse pour desirer continuer ; il y avait deja un air de ressemblance, l'attitude etait gracieuse et les details heureusement choisis ; elle esperait que ce portrait leur ferait honneur a toutes deux ; il perpetuerait le souvenir de la beaute de l'une, du talent de l'autre et de leur commune amitie ; elle escomptait aussi les associations d'idees accessoires que l'attachement naissant de M. Elton ne manquerait pas d'y ajouter.

eng: 'Every body who saw it was pleased, but Mr. Elton was in continual raptures, and defended it through every criticism.'
fr: 'Quant a M. Elton, son admiration n'avait pas de bornes et il n'admettait aucune critique.'

eng: '"Miss Woodhouse has given her friend the only beauty she wanted,"--observed Mrs. Weston to him--not in the least suspecting that she was addressing a lover.--'
fr: '<< Mlle Woodhouse a dote son amie de la seule beaute qui lui manque >>, dit Mme Weston en s'adressant a M. Elton.'

eng: '"The expression of the eye is most correct, but Miss Smith has not those eyebrows and eyelashes. It is the fault of her face that she has them not." '
fr: '<< L'expression de l'oeil est parfaite, mais Mlle Smith n'a pas des sourcils et des cils pareils ; c'est l'unique defaut de son visage.'

eng: '"Do you think so?"'
fr: '-- Vous trouvez ?'

eng: "I cannot agree with you. It appears to me a most perfect resemblance in every feature. I never saw such a likeness in my life. We must allow for the effect of shade, you know."
fr: 'Je ne puis etre de votre avis ; la ressemblance me parait parfaite dans tous ses details. Il faut calculer l'effet de l'ombre.'

eng: "You have made her too tall, Emma," said Mr. Knightley.
fr: '-- Vous l'avez faite trop grande, Emma, fit observer M. Knightley.'

eng: Emma knew that she had, but would not own it; and Mr. Elton warmly added, "Oh no! certainly not too tall; not in the least too tall. Consider, she is sitting down--which naturally presents a different--which in short gives exactly the idea--and the proportions must be preserved, you know. Proportions, fore-shortening.--Oh no! it gives one exactly the idea of such a height as Miss Smith's. Exactly so indeed!"
fr: 'Emma s'en etait rendu compte, mais elle ne voulait pas en convenir, et M. Elton ajouta avec chaleur : -- Bien entendu, la position assise modifie les proportions, mais ce raccourci me suggere exactement l'idee de la taille de Mlle Smith.'

eng: "It is very pretty," said Mr. Woodhouse.
fr: '-- C'est extremement joli dit M. Woodhouse,'

eng: "So prettily done! Just as your drawings always are, my dear. I do not know any body who draws so well as you do. The only thing I do not thoroughly like is, that she seems to be sitting out of doors, with only a little shawl over her shoulders--and it makes one think she must catch cold."
fr: 'et si bien dessine et peint ! Comme tout ce que vous faites, ma chere. Il n'y a qu'une chose a laquelle je trouverais a redire : Mlle Smith parait etre assise dehors et elle n'a qu'un petit chale sur les epaules !'

eng: "But, my dear papa, it is supposed to be summer; a warm day in summer. Look at the tree."
fr: '-- Mais mon cher papa, nous sommes supposes etre dans la belle saison, le decor evoque une chaude journee d'ete. Voyez les feuilles de cet arbre !'

eng: "But it is never safe to sit out of doors, my dear."
fr: '-- Mais ma chere, il n'est jamais prudent de s'asseoir dehors.'

eng: "You, sir, may say any thing," cried Mr. Elton, "but I must confess that I regard it as a most happy thought, the placing of Miss Smith out of doors; and the tree is touched with such inimitable spirit! Any other situation would have been much less in character. The naivete of Miss Smith's manners--and altogether--Oh, it is most admirable! I cannot keep my eyes from it. I never saw such a likeness."
fr: 'Je m'incline devant votre avis, Monsieur, dit M. Elton, mais il me semble, je dois l'avouer, que c'est une tres heureuse idee d'avoir place Mlle Smith en plein air ; aucun autre cadre ne se fut harmonise aussi parfaitement avec la grace et le naturel du modele. Je ne puis voir de defaut a ce portrait ni en detacher mon regard.'

eng: The next thing wanted was to get the picture framed; and here were a few difficulties.
fr: 'Il fallut ensuite songer a faire encadrer l'aquarelle et a ce propos quelques difficultes se presenterent ;'

eng: It must be done directly; it must be done in London; the order must go through the hands of some intelligent person whose taste could be depended on; and Isabella, the usual doer of all commissions, must not be applied to, because it was December, and Mr. Woodhouse could not bear the idea of her stirring out of her house in the fogs of December.
fr: 'Emma desirait que le cadre fut commande... sans retard... a Londres... par l'intermediaire d'une personne intelligente et d'un gout sur ; on ne pouvait songer a avoir recours a Isabelle, car M. Woodhouse n'aurait pu supporter l'idee que sa fille fut obligee de sortir par les brouillards de decembre.'

eng: But no sooner was the distress known to Mr. Elton, than it was removed. His gallantry was always on the alert.
fr: 'Des que M. Elton eut ete mis au courant de la perplexite ou se trouvaient ses amis, il proposa une solution :'

eng: "Might he be trusted with the commission, what infinite pleasure should he have in executing it! he could ride to London at any time. It was impossible to say how much he should be gratified by being employed on such an errand."
fr: 'le jugerait-on digne de faire la commission ? Il aurait un plaisir infini a l'executer. Il lui serait facile de se rendre a Londres a cheval et on ne pouvait savoir a quel point il se sentirait flatte d'une pareille mission.'

eng: "He was too good!--she could not endure the thought!--she would not give him such a troublesome office for the world,"--brought on the desired repetition of entreaties and assurances,--and a very few minutes settled the business.
fr: 'Apres avoir remercie et declare qu'elle ne voudrait a aucun prix lui causer un tel derangement, Emma finit par ceder et accepta le concours de M. Elton ; il fut convenu que ce dernier porterait l'aquarelle a Londres, choisirait le cadre et donnerait les instructions necessaires.'

eng: '"What a precious deposit!" said he with a tender sigh, as he received it.
fr: '-- Quel precieux depot, dit-il avec un soupir, quand il le recut.

eng: "This man is almost too gallant to be in love," thought Emma.
fr: << Je m'explique mal l'empressement galant dont il fait preuve a mon egard, etant donne les circonstances, pensa Emma,

eng: "I should say so, but that I suppose there may be a hundred different ways of being in love.
fr: mais il y a sans doute un grand nombre de manieres d'etre amoureux.

eng: He is an excellent young man, and will suit Harriet exactly; it will be an 'Exactly so,' as he says himself; but he does sigh and languish, and study for compliments rather more than I could endure as a principal.
fr: C'est un excellent jeune homme qui conviendra parfaitement a Harriet ; je trouve seulement qu'il abuse des soupirs et des compliments : pour un personnage de second plan ma part de louanges est excessive.

eng: I come in for a pretty good share as a second. But it is his gratitude on Harriet's account."
fr: Sans doute, il agit ainsi par reconnaissance. >>

eng: CHAPTER VII
fr: VII

eng: The very day of Mr. Elton's going to London produced a fresh occasion for Emma's services towards her friend.
fr: Le jour meme du voyage de M. Elton a Londres un evenement se produisit qui fut l'occasion pour Emma de juger de son influence sur Harriet.

eng: Harriet had been at Hartfield, as usual, soon after breakfast; and, after a time, had gone home to return again to dinner: she returned, and sooner than had been talked of, and with an agitated, hurried look, announcing something extraordinary to have happened which she was longing to tell.
fr: Celle-ci etait venue faire une visite a Hartfield apres dejeuner comme d'habitude ; elle etait ensuite rentree chez elle et devait revenir pour diner ; elle arriva avant l'heure convenue ; son air nerveux et agite indiquait clairement qu'il s'etait passe quelque chose d'extraordinaire dont elle brulait de faire part a son amie.

eng: Half a minute brought it all out.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Who could have thought it?
fr: 'Qui aurait pu imaginer une chose pareille ?

eng: She was so surprized she did not know what to do.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Yes, quite a proposal of marriage; and a very good letter, at least she thought so.
fr: 'La lettre est bien tournee, du moins je le crois ;

eng: And he wrote as if he really loved her very much--but she did not know--and so, she was come as fast as she could to ask Miss Woodhouse what she should do.--"
fr: 'j'ai l'impression qu'il m'aime beaucoup et je suis tres embarrassee pour repondre ; je me suis hatee de venir vous trouver pour demander avis et conseil.

eng: Emma was half-ashamed of her friend for seeming so pleased and so doubtful.
fr: 'Emma se sentit honteuse en voyant son amie manifester une satisfaction si evidente.

eng: "Upon my word," she cried, "the young man is determined not to lose any thing for want of asking.
fr: '-- Sur ma parole, dit-elle, ce jeune homme est decide a ne pas laisser echapper l'occasion de se marier avantageusement.

eng: He will connect himself well if he can."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Will you read the letter?" cried Harriet.
fr: '-- Voulez-vous lire la lettre ?

eng: "Pray do. I'd rather you would."
fr: reprit Harriet.

eng: Emma was not sorry to be pressed.
fr: Emma ne se fit pas prier.

eng: She read, and was surprized.
fr: Elle lut et demeura etonnee :

eng: The style of the letter was much above her expectation.
fr: non seulement il n'y avait pas de fautes de grammaire, mais la lettre etait digne d'un homme d'education ;

eng: There were not merely no grammatical errors, but as a composition it would not have disgraced a gentleman;
fr: le ton tout en restant simple etait sincere et convaincant et tous les sentiments exprimes faisaient honneur a celui qui l'avait redigee ;

eng: the language, though plain, was strong and unaffected, and the sentiments it conveyed very much to the credit of the writer.
fr: Harriet observait attentivement son amie et dit enfin :

eng: It was short, but expressed good sense, warm attachment, liberality, propriety, even delicacy of feeling.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She paused over it, while Harriet stood anxiously watching for her opinion, with a "Well, well," and was at last forced to add, "Is it a good letter? or is it too short?"
fr: '-- Eh bien, la lettre vous parait-elle bien ?

eng: "Yes, indeed, a very good letter," replied Emma rather slowly--"so good a letter, Harriet, that every thing considered, I think one of his sisters must have helped him.
fr: '-- C'est, ma foi, une lettre fort bien tournee reprit Emma, et je suis portee a croire que ses soeurs ont du y collaborer.

eng: I can hardly imagine the young man whom I saw talking with you the other day could express himself so well, if left quite to his own powers, and yet it is not the style of a woman; no, certainly, it is too strong and concise; not diffuse enough for a woman.
fr: J'imagine difficilement que le jeune homme que j'ai vu causer avec vous l'autre jour puisse, livre a ses propres moyens, s'exprimer avec tant d'elegance. Pourtant ce n'est pas le style d'une femme : c'est trop concis et vigoureux.

eng: No doubt he is a sensible man, and I suppose may have a natural talent for--thinks strongly and clearly--and when he takes a pen in hand, his thoughts naturally find proper words.
fr: Evidemment ce jeune homme a du bon sens ; il pense clairement et quand il prend la plume il trouve les mots appropries.

eng: It is so with some men.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Yes, I understand the sort of mind. Vigorous, decided, with sentiments to a certain point, not coarse.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: A better written letter, Harriet (returning it,) than I had expected."
fr: Elle ajouta, en rendant la lettre : -- Vraiment cette lettre surpasse de beaucoup mon attente.

eng: "Well," said the still waiting Harriet;--"well--and--and what shall I do?"
fr: '-- Eh bien ? Eh bien ? Que dois-je faire ?

eng: "What shall you do! In what respect? Do you mean with regard to this letter?"
fr: '-- A quel point de vue ? Voulez-vous dire relativement a cette lettre ?

eng: "Yes."
fr: '-- Oui.

eng: "But what are you in doubt of? You must answer it of course--and speedily."
fr: '-- Mais il faut y repondre, bien entendu, sans delai.

eng: "Yes. But what shall I say?
fr: '-- Que dois-je dire ?

eng: Dear Miss Woodhouse, do advise me."
fr: 'Chere Mlle Woodhouse donnez-moi votre avis.

eng: "Oh no, no! the letter had much better be all your own. You will express yourself very properly, I am sure.
fr: '-- Non, Harriet, ecrivez votre reponse en toute liberte ;

eng: There is no danger of your not being intelligible, which is the first thing.
fr: l'essentiel est de vous faire clairement comprendre : il ne faut pas d'equivoque, pas de doute, pas de sursis ;

eng: Your meaning must be unequivocal; no doubts or demurs: and such expressions of gratitude and concern for the pain you are inflicting as propriety requires, will present themselves unbidden to _your_ mind, I am persuaded.
fr: quant aux expressions de reconnaissance et de regret pour le desappointement que vous causez elles vous viendront tout naturellement sous la plume.

eng: You need not be prompted to write with the appearance of sorrow for his disappointment."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "You think I ought to refuse him then," said Harriet, looking down.
fr: '-- Alors... vous trouvez que je dois refuser, dit Harriet en baissant les yeux.

eng: "Ought to refuse him! My dear Harriet, what do you mean? Are you in any doubt as to that?
fr: '-- Si vous devez refuser ! Ma chere Harriet, que voulez-vous dire ? Il y a un malentendu entre nous, puisque vous avez un doute sur le sens meme de votre reponse ;

eng: I thought--but I beg your pardon, perhaps I have been under a mistake.
fr: je croyais, moi, que vous me consultiez simplement sur la forme et je vous demande pardon de m'etre avancee de la sorte.

eng: I certainly have been misunderstanding you, if you feel in doubt as to the _purport_ of your answer.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I had imagined you were consulting me only as to the wording of it."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Harriet was silent.
fr: Harriet demeura silencieuse et Emma reprit avec une certaine reserve.

eng: With a little reserve of manner, Emma continued: "You mean to return a favourable answer, I collect."
fr: '-- D'apres ce que je comprends, vous comptez donner une reponse favorable.

eng: "No, I do not; that is, I do not mean--What shall I do? What would you advise me to do?
fr: '-- Non, je n'ai pas cette intention... Que dois-je faire ? Je vous, en prie, mademoiselle Woodhouse, conseillez-moi.

eng: Pray, dear Miss Woodhouse, tell me what I ought to do."
fr: '-- Il ne m'appartient pas de vous donner un conseil, Harriet. Vous ne devez consulter que vous-meme.

eng: "I shall not give you any advice, Harriet. I will have nothing to do with it. This is a point which you must settle with your feelings."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I had no notion that he liked me so very much," said Harriet, contemplating the letter.
fr: 'Je n'avais pas idee qu'il m'aimat autant, dit Harriet en contemplant la lettre.'

eng: It is not a state to be safely entered into with doubtful feelings, with half a heart.
fr: On ne peut entrer dans l'etat de mariage avec des sentiments douteux.

eng: I thought it my duty as a friend, and older than yourself, to say thus much to you.
fr: J'estime qu'il est de mon devoir, comme votre amie et comme votre ainee, de vous donner cet avertissement, mais ne croyez pas que je veuille vous influencer.

eng: But do not imagine that I want to influence you.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Oh! no, I am sure you are a great deal too kind to--but if you would just advise me what I had best do--
fr: -- Certainement non ; mais si vous vouliez etre assez bonne pour me donner votre avis...

eng: No, no, I do not mean that--As you say, one's mind ought to be quite made up--One should not be hesitating--It is a very serious thing.
fr: Non, ce n'est pas ce que je veux dire ; vous avez raison, il faut savoir se decider soi-meme ; c'est une question trop grave.

eng: It will be safer to say 'No,' perhaps.
fr: Il serait peut-etre plus sage de dire << non >>.

eng: Do you think I had better say 'No?'
fr: Ne le croyez-vous pas ?

eng: "Not for the world," said Emma, smiling graciously, "would I advise you either way.
fr: -- Pour rien au monde, dit Emma en souriant, je ne voudrais vous conseiller dans un sens ni dans un autre :

eng: You must be the best judge of your own happiness.
fr: vous seule etes juge des conditions de votre bonheur.

eng: If you prefer Mr. Martin to every other person; if you think him the most agreeable man you have ever been in company with, why should you hesitate?
fr: Si vous jugez M. Martin l'homme le plus agreable que vous ayez rencontre, pourquoi hesiteriez-vous ?

eng: You blush, Harriet.
fr: Vous rougissez, Harriet !

eng: Does any body else occur to you at this moment under such a definition?
fr: Est-ce qu'il vous semble qu'une autre personne reponde a cette definition ?

eng: Harriet, Harriet, do not deceive yourself; do not be run away with by gratitude and compassion.
fr: Harriet, ne vous trompez pas vous-meme, ne vous laissez pas entrainer par la reconnaissance.

eng: At this moment whom are you thinking of?
fr: A qui pensez-vous en ce moment ?

eng: The symptoms were favourable.
fr: Les symptomes etaient favorables :

eng: Instead of answering, Harriet turned away confused, and stood thoughtfully by the fire; and though the letter was still in her hand, it was now mechanically twisted about without regard.
fr: au lieu de repondre Harriet se detourna pour cacher sa confusion ; elle se tenait devant la cheminee, tout en maniant machinalement la lettre qu'elle avait a la main.

eng: If she can hesitate as to 'Yes,' she ought to say 'No' directly.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: While you were at all in suspense I kept my feelings to myself, but now that you are so completely decided I have no hesitation in approving.
fr: Tant que vous etiez en suspens, j'ai garde mon opinion pour moi, mais maintenant que vous etes decidee, je m'empresse de vous approuver.

eng: Dear Harriet, I give myself joy of this.
fr: Ma chere Harriet, vous me causez une vraie joie.

eng: It would have grieved me to lose your acquaintance, which must have been the consequence of your marrying Mr. Martin.
fr: Une des consequences de votre mariage avec M. Martin eut ete de vous separer de moi.

eng: While you were in the smallest degree wavering, I said nothing about it, because I would not influence; but it would have been the loss of a friend to me.
fr: Je n'ai pas voulu vous le dire auparavant pour ne pas vous influencer ; je n'aurais pas pu rester en relations avec Mme Robert Martin d'Abbey Mill.

eng: I could not have visited Mrs. Robert Martin, of Abbey-Mill Farm.
fr: Je n'aurais pas pu rester en relations avec Mme Robert Martin d'Abbey Mill.

eng: Now I am secure of you for ever."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Harriet had not surmised her own danger, but the idea of it struck her forcibly.
fr: Harriet n'avait pas envisage cette eventualite ; elle s'ecria : -- C'est evident !

eng: "You could not have visited me!" she cried, looking aghast.
fr: elle s'ecria : -- C'est evident !

eng: "No, to be sure you could not; but I never thought of that before.
fr: Je n'y avais jamais, reflechi.

eng: That would have been too dreadful!--What an escape!--
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Dear Miss Woodhouse, I would not give up the pleasure and honour of being intimate with you for any thing in the world.
fr: Chere Mlle Woodhouse, pour aucune consideration, je ne renoncerai au plaisir et a l'honneur de votre intimite.

eng: "Indeed, Harriet, it would have been a severe pang to lose you; but it must have been.
fr: -- A coup sur, Harriet, j'aurais eu un veritable chagrin de vous perdre, mais c'etait inevitable.

eng: You would have thrown yourself out of all good society.
fr: Vous vous seriez exclue de la bonne societe et j'aurais ete forcee de vous abandonner.

eng: I must have given you up.
fr: j'aurais ete forcee de vous abandonner.

eng: "Dear me!--How should I ever have borne it!
fr: -- Mon Dieu ! Comment aurais-je pu supporter cette separation !

eng: "Dear affectionate creature!--_You_ banished to Abbey-Mill Farm!--_You_ confined to the society of the illiterate and vulgar all your life! I wonder how the young man could have the assurance to ask it. He must have a pretty good opinion of himself."
fr: '-- Chere affectueuse creature ! ~~~ Je ne puis vous imaginer exilee a Abbey Mill, reduite a la societe de personnes vulgaires pour le reste de votre vie ! Je suis surprise que ce jeune homme se soit cru autorise a vous demander en mariage. Il doit avoir une bonne opinion de lui-meme.'

eng: "I do not think he is conceited either, in general," said Harriet, her conscience opposing such censure; "at least, he is very good natured, and I shall always feel much obliged to him, and have a great regard for--but that is quite a different thing from--and you know, though he may like me, it does not follow that I should--and certainly I must confess that since my visiting here I have seen people--and if one comes to compare them, person and manners, there is no comparison at all, _one_ is so very handsome and agreeable. However, I do really think Mr. Martin a very amiable young man, and have a great opinion of him; and his being so much attached to me--and his writing such a letter--but as to leaving you, it is what I would not do upon any consideration."
fr: 'Je ne le crois pourtant pas vaniteux, repondit Harriet dont la conscience se revoltait devant un pareil parti pris. ~~~ Il a un excellent naturel et je lui serai toujours reconnaissante. Evidemment de ce qu'il m'aime il ne s'ensuit pas que je doive partager ses sentiments. Je puis l'avouer : j'ai rencontre a Hartfield des personnes avec lesquelles indiscutablement il ne supporte pas la comparaison. Je conserverai neanmoins une tres bonne opinion de M. Martin et le souvenir de son affection ; mais quant a vous quitter, c'est a quoi je ne me resoudrai jamais...'

eng: "Thank you, thank you, my own sweet little friend. ~~~ We will not be parted. A woman is not to marry a man merely because she is asked, or because he is attached to her, and can write a tolerable letter."
fr: '-- Merci, ma chere petite amie, nous ne nous separerons pas. Une femme ne doit pas epouser un homme pour la seule raison qu'il est amoureux d'elle et capable d'ecrire une lettre convenable !'

eng: "Oh no;--and it is but a short letter too."
fr: '-- Oh ! non... et du reste sa lettre est bien courte !'

eng: "Emma felt the bad taste of her friend, but let it pass with a "very true; and it would be a small consolation to her, for the clownish manner which might be offending her every hour of the day, to know that her husband could write a good letter."
fr: 'Emma sentit le manque de gout de son amie, mais elle se garda bien de le relever et repondit : -- Certainement ; du reste, ses capacites epistolaires eussent ete une bien maigre compensation a l'insuffisance de son education et de ses manieres dont vous auriez eu a souffrir journellement.'

eng: "Oh! ~~~ yes, very. Nobody cares for a letter; the thing is, to be always happy with pleasant companions. ~~~ I am quite determined to refuse him. But how shall I do? ~~~ What shall I say?"
fr: '-- Une lettre, ce n'est rien, reprit Harriet ; l'important est d'etre heureuse et de passer sa vie avec des amis agreables ; je suis bien decidee a le refuser ; mais comment vais-je m'y prendre ? Que dois-je dire ?'

eng: "Emma assured her there would be no difficulty in the answer, and advised its being written directly, which was agreed to, in the hope of her assistance; and though Emma continued to protest against any assistance being wanted, it was in fact given in the formation of every sentence."
fr: 'Emma lui assura que la reponse ne presentait aucune difficulte, et lui conseilla de s'y mettre immediatement. Harriet acquiesca dans l'espoir d'etre aidee. Tout en protestant de son absolu desinteressement, Emma intervint dans la redaction de chaque phrase.'

eng: "The looking over his letter again, in replying to it, had such a softening tendency, that it was particularly necessary to brace her up with a few decisive expressions; and she was so very much concerned at the idea of making him unhappy, and thought so much of what his mother and sisters would think and say, and was so anxious that they should not fancy her ungrateful, that Emma believed if the young man had come in her way at that moment, he would have been accepted after all."
fr: 'A mesure qu'elle relisait la lettre pour y repondre, Harriet se laissait attendrir et avait grand besoin d'etre encouragee ; elle se montra si preoccupee a l'idee de rendre M. Martin malheureux, si affectee du contre-coup qui allait atteindre la mere et les soeurs, elle manifesta tant d'apprehension a l'idee de paraitre ingrate qu'Emma se rendit compte que si le jeune homme avait pu plaider lui-meme sa cause, il aurait sans doute ete agree.'

eng: "This letter, however, was written, and sealed, and sent. ~~~ The business was finished, and Harriet safe."
fr: 'Cependant, la lettre fut ecrite, cachetee et envoyee : Harriet etait sauvee !'

eng: "She was rather low all the evening, but Emma could allow for her amiable regrets, and sometimes relieved them by speaking of her own affection, sometimes by bringing forward the idea of Mr. Elton."
fr: 'Emma ne s'etonna pas que son amie fut un peu deprimee pendant la soiree et s'efforca de la distraire tantot en lui parlant de sa propre affection, tantot en evoquant l'idee de M. Elton.'

eng: "I think Mrs. Goddard would be very much surprized if she knew what had happened."
fr: 'Mme Goddard serait bien surprise si elle apprenait ce qui est arrive ;'

eng: "I am sure Miss Nash would--for Miss Nash thinks her own sister very well married, and it is only a linen-draper."
fr: 'je suis sure que Mlle Nash ne s'expliquerait pas mon refus : elle qui considere que sa soeur a fait un excellent mariage en epousant un marchand de drap.'

eng: "One should be sorry to see greater pride or refinement in the teacher of a school, Harriet."
fr: 'Il serait facheux, Harriet, qu'une maitresse d'ecole nourrisse des ambitions exagerees.'

eng: "I dare say Miss Nash would envy you such an opportunity as this of being married."
fr: 'Mlle Nash, sans aucun doute, considererait cette conquete comme tres flatteuse.'

eng: "Even this conquest would appear valuable in her eyes."
fr: 'Elle ne saurait imaginer rien de mieux pour vous.'

eng: "As to any thing superior for you, I suppose she is quite in the dark."
fr: 'Les attentions d'une certaine personne ne doivent pas encore avoir transpire a Highbury et nous sommes, je pense, les seules a soupconner la verite.'

eng: "The attentions of a certain person can hardly be among the tittle-tattle of Highbury yet."
fr: 'Les attentions d'une certaine personne ne doivent pas encore avoir transpire a Highbury et nous sommes, je pense, les seules a soupconner la verite.'

eng: "Hitherto I fancy you and I are the only people to whom his looks and manners have explained themselves."
fr: 'Les attentions d'une certaine personne ne doivent pas encore avoir transpire a Highbury et nous sommes, je pense, les seules a soupconner la verite.'

eng: "Harriet blushed and smiled, and said something about wondering that people should like her so much."
fr: 'Harriet sourit et rougit ; elle manifesta son etonnement de l'affection qu'elle semblait inspirer.'

eng: "The idea of Mr. Elton was certainly cheering; but still, after a time, she was tender-hearted again towards the rejected Mr. Martin."
fr: 'Apres quelque temps, toutefois, elle sentit sa compassion pour M. Martin se reveiller.'

eng: ""Now he has got my letter," said she softly. "I wonder what they are all doing--whether his sisters know--if he is unhappy, they will be unhappy too. I hope he will not mind it so very much.""
fr: 'Maintenant il a recu ma lettre... ses soeurs doivent etre au courant : s'il est malheureux, elles seront malheureuses aussi. J'espere qu'il ne sera pas trop decu.'

eng: ""Let us think of those among our absent friends who are more cheerfully employed," cried Emma."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "At this moment, perhaps, Mr. Elton is shewing your picture to his mother and sisters, telling how much more beautiful is the original, and after being asked for it five or six times, allowing them to hear your name, your own dear name."
fr: 'Et moi, reprit Emma, j'imagine qu'en ce moment M. Elton est occupe a montrer votre portrait a sa mere et a ses soeurs ; il proteste que l'original est beaucoup plus charmant encore, et cedant a leurs instances il leur confie votre nom.'

eng: "My picture!--But he has left my picture in Bond-street."
fr: 'Mon portrait ! ~~~ Mais il l'a laisse dans Bond Street.'

eng: "Has he so!--Then I know nothing of Mr. Elton."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "No, my dear little modest Harriet, depend upon it the picture will not be in Bond-street till just before he mounts his horse to-morrow."
fr: 'Vous croyez ? Non, ma petite Harriet, quoiqu'il en coute a votre modestie, apprenez que votre portrait ne sera sans doute depose chez l'encadreur de Bond Street que demain au moment du depart.'

eng: "It is his companion all this evening, his solace, his delight."
fr: 'Ce soir, il tiendra compagnie a M. Elton, qui choisira ce pretexte pour mettre sa famille au courant de ses projets, pour vous presenter a elle, pour vous faire connaitre les principaux attraits de votre personne.'

eng: "It opens his designs to his family, it introduces you among them, it diffuses through the party those pleasantest feelings of our nature, eager curiosity and warm prepossession."
fr: 'Quelle curiosite sa confidence a du susciter ! J'entends d'ici les interrogations et les cris de surprise !'

eng: "How cheerful, how animated, how suspicious, how busy their imaginations all are!"
fr: 'Quelle curiosite sa confidence a du susciter ! J'entends d'ici les interrogations et les cris de surprise !'

eng: "Harriet smiled again, and her smiles grew stronger."
fr: 'Cette gracieuse evocation amena sur les levres d'Harriet un sourire plus assure.'

eng: "Harriet slept at Hartfield that night."
fr: 'VIII Harriet coucha ce soir-la a Hartfield ;'

eng: "For some weeks past she had been spending more than half her time there, and gradually getting to have a bed-room appropriated to herself; and Emma judged it best in every respect, safest and kindest, to keep her with them as much as possible just at present."
fr: 'depuis quelques semaines elle y passait plus de la moitie de son temps et insensiblement une chambre lui avait ete reservee ; Emma jugeait qu'il valait mieux, a tous les points de vue, garder son amie aupres d'elle le plus possible pendant cette periode de crise.'

eng: While she was gone, Mr. Knightley called, and sat some time with Mr. Woodhouse and Emma,
fr: Peu d'instants apres le depart d'Harriet, M. Knightley fut introduit : les salutations terminees,

eng: till Mr. Woodhouse, who had previously made up his mind to walk out, was persuaded by his daughter not to defer it,
fr: Emma encouragea son pere, qui etait precisement sur le point de sortir, a mettre son projet a execution ;

eng: and was induced by the entreaties of both, though against the scruples of his own civility, to leave Mr. Knightley for that purpose.
fr: M. Knightley joignit ses instances a celles d'Emma et malgre ses scrupules de politesse M. Woodhouse finit par ceder.

eng: Mr. Knightley, who had nothing of ceremony about him, was offering by his short, decided answers, an amusing contrast to the protracted apologies and civil hesitations of the other.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Well, I believe, if you will excuse me, Mr. Knightley, if you will not consider me as doing a very rude thing, I shall take Emma's advice and go out for a quarter of an hour.
fr: -- Eh bien ! dit-il, si vous voulez bien, Monsieur Knightley, excuser mon impolitesse, je crois que je vais suivre l'avis d'Emma et sortir pendant un quart d'heure.

eng: As the sun is out, I believe I had better take my three turns while I can.
fr: Sans doute il est preferable que je profite des heures de soleil pour aller faire un tour.

eng: I treat you without ceremony, Mr. Knightley."
fr: Je vous traite sans ceremonie.

eng: "And therefore I think I will beg your excuse and take my three turns--my winter walk."
fr: "Dans ces conditions je prendrai la liberte d'aller faire ma promenade quotidienne."

eng: "You cannot do better, sir."
fr: "Rien de plus opportun, Monsieur."

eng: "I would ask for the pleasure of your company, Mr. Knightley, but I am a very slow walker, and my pace would be tedious to you; and, besides, you have another long walk before you, to Donwell Abbey."
fr: "Je vous demanderais bien de me faire le plaisir de m'accompagner, Monsieur Knightley, mais je marche si lentement que ce serait un ennui pour vous ; du reste vous avez encore une longue route a faire pour rentrer a Donwell Abbey."

eng: "Come," said he, "you are anxious for a compliment, so I will tell you that you have improved her. You have cured her of her school-girl's giggle; she really does you credit."
fr: '-- Allons, je vois que vous attendez un compliment ; je vous dirai donc que vous l'avez amelioree ; ce n'est plus l'ecoliere qu'elle etait ; elle vous fait honneur.'

eng: "Thank you. I should be mortified indeed if I did not believe I had been of some use; but it is not every body who will bestow praise where they may. ~~~ _You_ do not often overpower me with it."
fr: '-- Je vous remercie. Je serais humiliee, en effet, si je ne croyais pas lui avoir ete de quelque utilite ; et je vous suis d'autant plus obligee de votre observation que vous n'etes pas d'habitude prodigue de louanges.'

eng: "You are expecting her again, you say, this morning?"
fr: '-- Ne m'avez-vous pas dit que vous l'attendiez ce matin ?'

eng: "Almost every moment. ~~~ She has been gone longer already than she intended."
fr: '-- D'un moment a l'autre ; je suis meme etonnee qu'elle ne soit pas ici.'

eng: "Something has happened to delay her; some visitors perhaps."
fr: '-- Peut-etre a-t-elle ete retenue par quelque visite ?'

eng: "Highbury gossips!--Tiresome wretches!"
fr: '-- De peu d'interet, en tout cas !'

eng: "Harriet may not consider every body tiresome that you would."
fr: '-- Qui sait si Harriet partage sur ce point votre maniere de voir !'

eng: Emma knew this was too true for contradiction, and therefore said nothing.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He presently added, with a smile, "I do not pretend to fix on times or places, but I must tell you that I have good reason to believe your little friend will soon hear of something to her advantage."
fr: 'Puis il ajouta en souriant : -- Je ne pretends pas etre sur de l'heure et du jour, mais je puis vous dire que votre jeune amie apprendra bientot une nouvelle tout a son avantage.'

eng: '"I am glad you think so; and the good hands, I hope, may not be wanting."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I have reason to think," he replied, "that Harriet Smith will soon have an offer of marriage, and from a most unexceptionable quarter:--Robert Martin is the man.
fr: '-- J'ai des raisons de croire, reprit-il, qu'Harriet Smith recevra bientot une demande en mariage -- de premier ordre. Il s'agit de Robert Martin.

eng: Her visit to Abbey-Mill, this summer, seems to have done his business.
fr: La visite qu'elle a faite cet ete a Abbey Mill parait avoir porte ses fruits :

eng: He is desperately in love and means to marry her."
fr: il est extremement amoureux d'elle et est decide a l'epouser.

eng: "He is very obliging," said Emma; "but is he sure that Harriet means to marry him?"
fr: -- C'est bien aimable de sa part, repondit Emma ; mais a-t-il la certitude de trouver chez l'interessee une ardeur egale ?

eng: "Well, well, means to make her an offer then. Will that do?
fr: Bien ! ~~~ Bien ! J'emploierai des termes plus protocolaires : il se propose de demander la main d'Harriet.

eng: He came to the Abbey two evenings ago, on purpose to consult me about it.
fr: Il est venu avant hier a l'Abbaye pour me consulter a ce sujet.

eng: He knows I have a thorough regard for him and all his family, and, I believe, considers me as one of his best friends.
fr: Il sait que j'ai pour lui et pour sa famille une grande estime et il me considere comme un de ses meilleurs amis ;

eng: He came to ask me whether I thought it would be imprudent in him to settle so early; whether I thought her too young: in short, whether I approved his choice altogether;
fr: il venait me demander si je ne trouvais pas que ce fut imprudent de sa part de se marier, si la jeune fille ne me paraissait pas trop jeune ; en un mot, si j'approuvais son choix.
