eng: "And the distinction is not quite so much against the candour and common sense of the world as appears at first; for a very narrow income has a tendency to contract the mind, and sour the temper."
fr: "Cette distinction n'est pas aussi injuste qu'elle parait au premier abord, car un revenu mesquin contribue a retrecir l'intelligence et a aigrir le caractere."

eng: "Those who can barely live, and who live perforce in a very small, and generally very inferior, society, may well be illiberal and cross."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "This does not apply, however, to Miss Bates; she is only too good natured and too silly to suit me; but, in general, she is very much to the taste of every body, though single and though poor."
fr: "Ce que je dis ne s'applique pas neanmoins a Mlle Bates, trop banale et trop sotte pour me plaire, mais dont le coeur est excellent :"

eng: "Poverty certainly has not contracted her mind: I really believe, if she had only a shilling in the world, she would be very likely to give away sixpence of it; and nobody is afraid of her: that is a great charm."
fr: "je crois vraiment que si elle ne possedait qu'un shilling elle en distribuerait la moitie.'"

eng: ""Dear me!""
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Woman's usual occupations of hand and mind will be as open to me then as they are now; or with no important variation.
fr: Les occupations de la femme, manuelles et intellectuelles, ne me feront pas plus defaut qu'aujourd'hui.

eng: If I draw less, I shall read more; if I give up music, I shall take to carpet-work.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: And as for objects of interest, objects for the affections, which is in truth the great point of inferiority, the want of which is really the great evil to be avoided in _not_ marrying, I shall be very well off, with all the children of a sister I love so much, to care about.
fr: Quant a des objets d'interet pour mon affection, je n'en manquerai pas ; je pourrai me consacrer aux enfants d'une soeur que je cheris.

eng: There will be enough of them, in all probability, to supply every sort of sensation that declining life can need.
fr: Il y en aura tres probablement un assez grand nombre pour me fournir toutes les especes de sensations dont se nourrit la vie a son declin ;

eng: There will be enough for every hope and every fear; and though my attachment to none can equal that of a parent, it suits my ideas of comfort better than what is warmer and blinder.
fr: ils me donneront matiere d'esperer et de craindre. Sans doute, je ne ressentirai pour aucun d'eux la tendresse qui est l'apanage des parents, mais mon humeur s'accommodera volontiers d'un sentiment plus calme et moins aveugle que l'amour maternel.

eng: My nephews and nieces!--I shall often have a niece with me.
fr: Souvent une de mes nieces me tiendra compagnie !

eng: "Do you know Miss Bates's niece? ~~~ That is, I know you must have seen her a hundred times--but are you acquainted?"
fr: -- Connaissez-vous la niece de Mlle Bates ou pour mieux dire etes-vous en relation avec elle ?

eng: "Oh! yes; we are always forced to be acquainted whenever she comes to Highbury.
fr: -- Oh ! oui, nous sommes obliges de la voir toutes les fois qu'elle vient a Hartfield.

eng: By the bye, _that_ is almost enough to put one out of conceit with a niece.
fr: Je veux croire que l'exemple de Mlle Bates me preservera d'une admiration exageree pour mes nieces.

eng: ~~~ Heaven forbid! at least, that I should ever bore people half so much about all the Knightleys together, as she does about Jane Fairfax.
fr: Puisse le ciel m'eviter au moins d'ennuyer les gens au sujet de tous les Knightley reunis seulement la moitie autant que le fait Mlle Bates, a propos de Jeanne Fairfax ;

eng: ~~~ One is sick of the very name of Jane Fairfax.
fr: le son seul de ce nom est devenu pour moi une fatigue.

eng: She understood their ways, could allow for their ignorance and their temptations, had no romantic expectations of extraordinary virtue from those for whom education had done so little;
fr: Elle comprenait leur maniere d'etre, excusait leur ignorance, compatissait a leurs tentations et ne s'attendait pas a trouver chez eux des vertus extraordinaires.

eng: entered into their troubles with ready sympathy, and always gave her assistance with as much intelligence as good-will.
fr: Elle prenait part a leur chagrin et leur venait toujours en aide avec intelligence et bonne volonte.

eng: In the present instance, it was sickness and poverty together which she came to visit; and after remaining there as long as she could give comfort or advice, she quitted the cottage with such an impression of the scene as made her say to Harriet, as they walked away, "These are the sights, Harriet, to do one good. How trifling they make every thing else appear!--I feel now as if I could think of nothing but these poor creatures all the rest of the day; and yet, who can say how soon it may all vanish from my mind?"
fr: Dans ce cas particulier, sa visite avait pour but non seulement de distribuer des secours a des indigents, mais encore de porter remede aux souffrances d'un malade. Elle quitta la maison, impressionnee a la vue de tant de misere. Une fois dehors, elle dit : -- Voila des spectacles, Harriet, qui vous font du bien. Comme tout parait insignifiant a cote ! Il me semble que je ne pourrai plus detacher mon esprit de ces pauvres creatures tout le reste de la journee.

eng: "Very true," said Harriet.
fr: -- Vous dites vrai, repondit Harriet,

eng: "Poor creatures! one can think of nothing else."
fr: pauvres creatures !

eng: "And really, I do not think the impression will soon be over," said Emma, as she crossed the low hedge, and tottering footstep which ended the narrow, slippery path through the cottage garden, and brought them into the lane again.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I do not think it will," stopping to look once more at all the outward wretchedness of the place, and recall the still greater within.
fr: Emma referma la barriere placee a l'extremite du sentier qui traversait le petit jardin. Emma jeta un dernier coup d'oeil sur l'aspect minable du lieu et evoqua la misere qu'il recelait.

eng: "Oh! ~~~ dear, no," said her companion.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They walked on. The lane made a slight bend; and when that bend was passed, Mr. Elton was immediately in sight; and so near as to give Emma time only to say farther, "Ah! Harriet, here comes a very sudden trial of our stability in good thoughts.
fr: Elles se retrouverent sur la route qui, a cet endroit tournait brusquement et une fois la courbe franchie les deux jeunes filles apercurent soudain M. Elton qui venait vers elles : il etait si pres qu'Emma eut a peine le temps de dire : -- Ah ! Harriet, voici qui va mettre a l'epreuve notre fidelite aux bonnes pensees.

eng: Well, (smiling,) I hope it may be allowed that if compassion has produced exertion and relief to the sufferers, it has done all that is truly important.
fr: Quoi qu'il en soit, l'essentiel c'est que notre compassion ait procure un peu de soulagement a ceux qui souffrent.

eng: If we feel for the wretched, enough to do all we can for them, the rest is empty sympathy, only distressing to ourselves.
fr: Si nous avons pour les malheureux assez de pitie pour les aider selon nos moyens, nous faisons notre devoir ; au dela ce n'est qu'une vaine sympathie, inutile aux autres et nuisible a soi-meme.

eng: Harriet could just answer, "Oh! dear, yes," before the gentleman joined them.
fr: Elles furent alors rejointes par le promeneur.

eng: The wants and sufferings of the poor family, however, were the first subject on meeting. He had been going to call on them.
fr: M. Elton se disposait precisement a aller voir la malheureuse famille a laquelle Emma s'interessait. Ils chercherent ensemble quels remedes on pouvait apporter a une aussi triste situation et deciderent les mesures a prendre.

eng: His visit he would now defer; but they had a very interesting parley about what could be done and should be done.
fr: Puis remettant sa visite au lendemain, M. Elton demanda l'autorisation de les accompagner.

eng: Mr. Elton then turned back to accompany them.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "To fall in with each other on such an errand as this," thought Emma; "to meet in a charitable scheme; this will bring a great increase of love on each side.'
fr: Cette rencontre, pensa Emma, a laquelle la charite preside est particulierement heureuse.

eng: 'They did as they were desired; and by the time she judged it reasonable to have done with her boot, she had the comfort of farther delay in her power, being overtaken by a child from the cottage, setting out, according to orders, with her pitcher, to fetch broth from Hartfield.'
fr: 'Au moment ou elle jugeait raisonnable d'avoir termine son occupation, elle eut la chance de trouver une nouvelle raison pour s'attarder : elle fut, en effet, saluee par un des enfants de la famille qu'elle venait de visiter et qui conformement aux instructions recues, se dirigeait vers Hartfield en emportant un recipient pour rapporter du bouillon.'

eng: 'To walk by the side of this child, and talk to and question her, was the most natural thing in the world, or would have been the most natural, had she been acting just then without design; and by this means the others were still able to keep ahead, without any obligation of waiting for her.'
fr: 'Rien de plus naturel que de marcher a cote de la petite fille et de la questionner ; pourtant Emma gagnait involontairement du terrain sur ses deux compagnons qui ne se pressaient pas ;'

eng: 'She gained on them, however, involuntarily: the child's pace was quick, and theirs rather slow; and she was the more concerned at it, from their being evidently in a conversation which interested them.'
fr: 'elle le regretta d'autant plus qu'ils paraissaient absorbes dans une conversation interessante.'

eng: 'Mr. Elton was speaking with animation, Harriet listening with a very pleased attention; and Emma, having sent the child on, was beginning to think how she might draw back a little more, when they both looked around, and she was obliged to join them.'
fr: 'M. Elton parlait avec animation, Harriet ecoutait avec une attention enjouee. Emma, ayant expedie l'enfant en avant, se demandait comment elle pourrait faire pour se changer en statue de sel quand, au meme instant, ils se retournerent tous deux et elle fut obligee de se rapprocher.'

eng: 'Mr. Elton was still talking, still engaged in some interesting detail; and Emma experienced some disappointment when she found that he was only giving his fair companion an account of the yesterday's party at his friend Cole's, and that she was come in herself for the Stilton cheese, the north Wiltshire, the butter, the celery, the beet-root, and all the dessert.'
fr: 'M. Elton continua sa phrase et Emma fut desappointee d'entendre qu'il faisait a sa blonde compagne un recit de la fete chez M. Cole ; elle arrivait elle-meme pour le fromage de stilton, le beurre, la betterave et le dessert !'

eng: '"This would soon have led to something better, of course," was her consoling reflection; "any thing interests between those who love; and any thing will serve as introduction to what is near the heart. If I could but have kept longer away!"'
fr: '<< Ce debut aurait evidemment pu amener a une conclusion satisfaisante, se dit-elle en guise de consolation ; tous les sujets sont bons pour les amoureux et toute espece de conversation peut servir de pretexte aux confidences sentimentales. Si seulement j'avais pu rester un peu plus longtemps absente. >>'

eng: 'They now walked on together quietly, till within view of the vicarage pales, when a sudden resolution, of at least getting Harriet into the house, made her again find something very much amiss about her boot, and fall behind to arrange it once more.'
fr: 'Ils marcherent ensemble jusqu'a ce qu'ils fussent en vue de l'enceinte du presbytere : a ce moment Emma eut une inspiration subite et elle decouvrit le moyen de faire penetrer Harriet dans la maison : elle s'apercut d'un nouveau defaut dans l'arrangement de sa chaussure et s'arreta une fois encore ;'

eng: 'She then broke the lace off short, and dexterously throwing it into a ditch, was presently obliged to entreat them to stop, and acknowledged her inability to put herself to rights so as to be able to walk home in tolerable comfort.'
fr: 'elle arracha alors le lacet et le jeta a la derobee dans le fosse. Ceci fait, elle pria ses compagnons de s'arreter et leur avoua son embarras : -- La plus grande partie de mon lacet n'existe plus, dit-elle, et je ne sais pas trop comment je vais faire.'

eng: '"Part of my lace is gone," said she, "and I do not know how I am to contrive. ~~~ I really am a most troublesome companion to you both, but I hope I am not often so ill-equipped.'
fr: 'En verite, je suis pour vous deux une compagnie bien encombrante, mais j'espere que vous voudrez bien admettre que je suis rarement si mal equipee.'

eng: The room they were taken into was the one he chiefly occupied, and looking forwards;
fr: La piece ou il les conduisit etait celle qu'il occupait habituellement ;

eng: behind it was another with which it immediately communicated;
fr: la porte de communication se trouvait ouverte et elle fut forcee de la laisser entrebaillee :

eng: the door between them was open, and Emma passed into it with the housekeeper to receive her assistance in the most comfortable manner.
fr: ils causerent quelques instants, puis Emma suivie de la femme de charge, qui s'etait mise entierement a sa disposition, penetra dans une chambre attenante ;

eng: She was obliged to leave the door ajar as she found it;
fr: elle s'attendait a ce que M. Elton la fermat ;

eng: but she fully intended that Mr. Elton should close it.
fr: s'apercevant qu'il n'intervenait pas, Emma engagea aussitot avec la femme de charge une conversation animee, afin de donner a M. Elton la possibilite d'aborder avec Harriet le sujet qu'il lui plairait.

eng: It was not closed, however, it still remained ajar;
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: but by engaging the housekeeper in incessant conversation, she hoped to make it practicable for him to chuse his own subject in the adjoining room.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: For ten minutes she could hear nothing but herself.
fr: Au bout de dix minutes elle dut mettre un terme a l'entretien et a ses arrangements.

eng: It could be protracted no longer.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She was then obliged to be finished, and make her appearance.
fr: Elle trouva les amoureux debout devant une des fenetres ;

eng: The lovers were standing together at one of the windows.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It had a most favourable aspect;
fr: les apparences etaient favorables et pendant une demi-minute elle gouta la gloire du triomphe.

eng: and, for half a minute, Emma felt the glory of having schemed successfully.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: But it would not do; he had not come to the point.
fr: Elle apprit bientot pourtant qu'aucun pas decisif n'avait ete fait.

eng: He had been most agreeable, most delightful;
fr: M. Elton s'etait montre particulierement aimable et charmant ;

eng: he had told Harriet that he had seen them go by, and had purposely followed them;
fr: il avait confie a Harriet qu'il les avait vues passer et que ce n'etait pas sans intention qu'il avait pris le meme chemin ;

eng: other little gallantries and allusions had been dropt, but nothing serious.
fr: il avait fait quelques allusions galantes, mais rien de serieux.

eng: The coming of her sister's family was so very near at hand, that first in anticipation, and then in reality, it became henceforth her prime object of interest;
fr: La prochaine arrivee de sa soeur primait ses autres preoccupations ;

eng: and during the ten days of their stay at Hartfield it was not to be expected--she did not herself expect--that any thing beyond occasional, fortuitous assistance could be afforded by her to the lovers.
fr: pendant le sejour d'Isabelle a Hartfield elle prevoyait que les amoureux passeraient au second plan ;

eng: They might advance rapidly if they would; however; they must advance somehow or other whether they would or no.
fr: rien du reste ne les empecherait d'avancer rapidement leurs affaires s'il leur plaisait.

eng: She hardly wished to have more leisure for them.
fr: Elle commencait a trouver que certaines personnes s'en remettent trop volontiers aux autres du soin de leurs propres interets.

eng: There are people, who the more you do for them, the less they will do for themselves.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley, from having been longer than usual absent from Surry, were exciting of course rather more than the usual interest.
fr: La venue de M. et Mme John Knightley provoquait cette annee la un interet inaccoutume.

eng: Till this year, every long vacation since their marriage had been divided between Hartfield and Donwell Abbey;
fr: En effet depuis leur mariage ils avaient l'habitude de passer toutes leurs vacances, partie a Hartfield et partie a Donwell Abbey.

eng: but all the holidays of this autumn had been given to sea-bathing for the children,
fr: Mais l'ete precedent, sur le conseil du medecin, ils avaient conduit leurs enfants au bord de la mer.

eng: and it was therefore many months since they had been seen in a regular way by their Surry connexions, or seen at all by Mr. Woodhouse, who could not be induced to get so far as London, even for poor Isabella's sake;
fr: Il y avait donc plusieurs mois que M. Woodhouse n'avait pas vu sa fille et les enfants ;

eng: and who consequently was now most nervously and apprehensively happy in forestalling this too short visit.
fr: il etait tout emu et nerveux a la pensee de cette trop courte visite.

eng: (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: Pour le moment il etait tres preoccupe des risques auxquels selon lui etaient exposes les voyageurs et son inquietude s'etendait a ses chevaux et a son cocher qui avaient ete envoyes en relai a mi-chemin.

eng: She was not a woman of strong understanding or any quickness;
fr: Elle etait d'intelligence moyenne et sans grande vivacite d'esprit ;

eng: and with this resemblance of her father, she inherited also much of his constitution;
fr: outre cette ressemblance avec son pere, elle tenait aussi de lui une constitution delicate ;

eng: was delicate in her own health, over-careful of that of her children, had many fears and many nerves, and was as fond of her own Mr. Wingfield in town as her father could be of Mr. Perry.
fr: elle se preoccupait sans cesse de la sante de ses enfants, etait aussi entichee de son docteur, M. Wingfield, que son pere l'etait de M. Perry ;

eng: They were alike too, in a general benevolence of temper, and a strong habit of regard for every old acquaintance.
fr: ils avaient l'un et l'autre une extreme bienveillance de caractere et la meme consideration pour leurs vieux amis.

eng: Mr. John Knightley was a tall, gentleman-like, and very clever man;
fr: M. Jean Knightley etait un homme grand, distingue et tres intelligent ;

eng: rising in his profession, domestic, and respectable in his private character;
fr: il occupait une des premieres places dans sa profession et en meme temps il avait toutes les qualites d'un homme d'interieur ;

eng: but with reserved manners which prevented his being generally pleasing;
fr: ses manieres un peu froides et reservees l'empechaient au premier abord de paraitre aimable, et il etait susceptible de marquer, a l'occasion, quelque mauvaise humeur :

eng: and capable of being sometimes out of humour.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He was not an ill-tempered man, not so often unreasonably cross as to deserve such a reproach;
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: but his temper was not his great perfection;
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: and, indeed, with such a worshipping wife, it was hardly possible that any natural defects in it should not be increased.
fr: sa femme, du reste, avait pour lui une veritable idolatrie qui contribuait a developper cette tendance ;

eng: The extreme sweetness of her temper must hurt his.
fr: elle accueillait avec une douceur inalterable les manifestations souvent brusques des opinions maritales.

eng: He had all the clearness and quickness of mind which she wanted, and he could sometimes act an ungracious, or say a severe thing.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He was not a great favourite with his fair sister-in-law.
fr: Sa belle-soeur n'avait pas pour lui une bien vive sympathie ;

eng: Nothing wrong in him escaped her.
fr: aucun de ses defauts n'echappait a la clairvoyance d'Emma ;

eng: She was quick in feeling the little injuries to Isabella, which Isabella never felt herself.
fr: elle ressentait les legeres injures infligees a Isabelle et dont celle-ci n'avait pas conscience.

eng: Perhaps she might have passed over more had his manners been flattering to Isabella's sister,
fr: Peut-etre eut-elle temoigne moins de severite a l'egard de son beau-frere si ce dernier s'etait montre mieux dispose pour elle,

eng: but they were only those of a calmly kind brother and friend, without praise and without blindness;
fr: mais ses manieres etaient au contraire celles d'un frere et d'un ami qui ne loue qu'a propos et que l'affection n'aveugle pas.

eng: but hardly any degree of personal compliment could have made her regardless of that greatest fault of all in her eyes which he sometimes fell into, the want of respectful forbearance towards her father.
fr: Elle lui reprochait surtout de manquer de respectueuse tolerance vis-a-vis de son pere :

eng: There he had not always the patience that could have been wished.
fr: les manieres de M. Woodhouse faisaient parfois perdre patience a M. John Knightley et provoquaient chez lui un rappel a la raison ou une replique un peu vive.

eng: Mr. Woodhouse's peculiarities and fidgetiness were sometimes provoking him to a rational remonstrance or sharp retort equally ill-bestowed.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It did not often happen;
fr: Cela arrivait rarement,

eng: for Mr. John Knightley had really a great regard for his father-in-law, and generally a strong sense of what was due to him;
fr: car, en realite, il avait parfaitement conscience des egards dus a son beau-pere ;

eng: but it was too often for Emma's charity, especially as there was all the pain of apprehension frequently to be endured, though the offence came not.
fr: trop souvent cependant pour conserver la bienveillance d'Emma qui ne cessait d'apprehender quelque parole offensante au cours de leurs conversations.

eng: The beginning, however, of every visit displayed none but the properest feelings, and this being of necessity so short might be hoped to pass away in unsullied cordiality.
fr: Le debut neanmoins de chaque visite etait toujours parfaitement cordial, et celle-ci devant par necessite etre extremement breve, il etait permis d'esperer que nul ne se departirait des sentiments actuels d'effusion.

eng: They had not been long seated and composed when Mr. Woodhouse, with a melancholy shake of the head and a sigh, called his daughter's attention to the sad change at Hartfield since she had been there last.
fr: Il n'y avait pas longtemps qu'ils etaient assis ensemble lorsque M. Woodhouse, en secouant melancoliquement la tete et en soupirant, fit remarquer a sa fille le changement qui s'etait produit depuis son depart.

eng: "Ah, my dear," said he, "poor Miss Taylor--It is a grievous business."
fr: -- Ah ! ma chere, dit-il, pauvre Mlle Taylor ! Voila une triste affaire.

eng: "Oh yes, sir," cried she with ready sympathy, "how you must miss her! And dear Emma, too!--What a dreadful loss to you both!--I have been so grieved for you.--I could not imagine how you could possibly do without her.--It is a sad change indeed.--But I hope she is pretty well, sir."
fr: -- Oh ! certainement, reprit Isabelle pleine de sympathie. Comme elle doit vous manquer ! Et a ma chere Emma ! Quelle affreuse perte pour vous deux ! J'ai bien pris part a votre chagrin. Je ne pouvais m'imaginer comment vous arriveriez a vous passer d'elle. J'espere qu'elle se porte bien ?

eng: "Pretty well, my dear--I hope--pretty well.--I do not know but that the place agrees with her tolerably."
fr: -- Elle va assez bien, ma chere ; je ne suis pas sur pourtant si l'endroit qu'elle habite lui convient.

eng: Mr. John Knightley here asked Emma quietly whether there were any doubts of the air of Randalls.
fr: M. Jean Knightley intervint alors pour demander a Emma si l'air de Randalls etait malsain.

eng: "Oh!
fr: -- Oh !

eng: I never saw Mrs. Weston better in my life--never looking so well.
fr: Je n'ai jamais vu Mme Weston en meilleure sante.

eng: Papa is only speaking his own regret.
fr: Papa fait allusion a son regret.

eng: "Very much to the honour of both," was the handsome reply.
fr: -- Qui leur fait honneur a tous deux, repondit-il a la vive satisfaction d'Emma.

eng: "And do you see her, sir, tolerably often?" asked Isabella in the plaintive tone which just suited her father.
fr: -- Est-ce que vous la voyez quelquefois ? reprit Isabelle du ton plaintif qui agreait particulierement a son pere.

eng: Mr. Woodhouse hesitated.--"Not near so often, my dear, as I could wish."
fr: M. Woodhouse hesita, puis il repondit : -- Pas si souvent, ma chere, que je le desirerais.

eng: "Oh! papa, we have missed seeing them but one entire day since they married.
fr: -- Oh ! papa, comment pouvez-vous parler ainsi ? Depuis leur mariage nous n'avons passe qu'un jour entier sans voir M. ou Mme Weston

eng: Either in the morning or evening of every day, excepting one, have we seen either Mr. Weston or Mrs. Weston, and generally both, either at Randalls or here--and as you may suppose, Isabella, most frequently here.
fr: et souvent les deux, soit a Randall, soit ici et comme vous pouvez le supposer, Isabelle, plus generalement ici.

eng: They are very, very kind in their visits.
fr: Ils ont fait preuve de l'empressement le plus affectueux.

eng: Mr. Weston is really as kind as herself.
fr: M. Weston est vraiment aussi attentif qu'elle.

eng: Papa, if you speak in that melancholy way, you will be giving Isabella a false idea of us all.
fr: Si vous prenez cet air melancolique, papa, vous donnerez a Isabelle une idee tout a fait fausse de ce qui se passe.

eng: Every body must be aware that Miss Taylor must be missed, but every body ought also to be assured that Mr. and Mrs. Weston do really prevent our missing her by any means to the extent we ourselves anticipated--which is the exact truth.
fr: Tout le monde, bien entendu, comprend combien Mlle Taylor doit nous manquer, mais tout le monde en meme temps doit savoir que M. et Mme Weston ont reussi a attenuer les effets de la separation plus que nous ne l'esperions nous-memes.

eng: "Just as it should be," said Mr. John Knightley, "and just as I hoped it was from your letters.
fr: -- Il etait naturel qu'il en fut ainsi, dit M. Jean Knightley, c'est bien du reste ce que j'avais compris d'apres vos lettres.

eng: Her wish of shewing you attention could not be doubted, and his being a disengaged and social man makes it all easy.
fr: Je ne doutais pas du desir de Mme Weston de se montrer pleine de prevenances ; d'autre part, son mari etant inoccupe et d'un naturel sociable, la tache lui etait rendue facile.

eng: I have been always telling you, my love, that I had no idea of the change being so very material to Hartfield as you apprehended; and now you have Emma's account, I hope you will be satisfied.
fr: Je vous ai toujours dit, ma cherie, que vos apprehensions etaient exagerees ; vous avez entendu le recit d'Emma et j'espere que vous etes rassuree.

eng: "Why, to be sure," said Mr. Woodhouse--"yes, certainly--I cannot deny that Mrs. Weston, poor Mrs. Weston, does come and see us pretty often--but then--she is always obliged to go away again."
fr: -- Certainement, dit M. Woodhouse, je ne doute pas que cette pauvre Mme Weston ne vienne nous voir assez souvent, mais ce ne sont que des visites et il faut toujours qu'elle s'en aille !

eng: "It would be very hard upon Mr. Weston if she did not, papa.--You quite forget poor Mr. Weston."
fr: -- Ce serait bien dur pour ce pauvre M. Weston, papa, dit Emma, s'il en etait autrement. Vous oubliez tout a fait l'existence de M. Weston.

eng: "I think, indeed," said John Knightley pleasantly, "that Mr. Weston has some little claim.
fr: -- Il me semble en effet, dit M. Jean Knightley en riant, que M. Weston a egalement quelques droits.

eng: You and I, Emma, will venture to take the part of the poor husband.
fr: Il nous appartient, Emma, de prendre la defense du pauvre mari ;

eng: I, being a husband, and you not being a wife, the claims of the man may very likely strike us with equal force.
fr: par etat je suis qualifie pour intervenir et vous qui etes encore libre il ne vous est pas interdit de faire preuve d'impartialite.

eng: As for Isabella, she has been married long enough to see the convenience of putting all the Mr. Westons aside as much as she can.
fr: Quant a Isabelle, il y a assez longtemps qu'elle est mariee pour comprendre tout l'avantage qu'il y aurait a mettre les MM. Weston de cote.

eng: "Me, my love," cried his wife, hearing and understanding only in part.-- "Are you talking about me?--I am sure nobody ought to be, or can be, a greater advocate for matrimony than I am; and if it had not been for the misery of her leaving Hartfield, I should never have thought of Miss Taylor but as the most fortunate woman in the world; and as to slighting Mr. Weston, that excellent Mr. Weston, I think there is nothing he does not deserve.
fr: -- Moi, mon cheri, reprit sa femme, est-ce que vous faites allusion a moi ? Personne ne peut etre plus a meme que je le suis de parler en faveur du mariage, et s'il ne s'etait agi de quitter Hartfield j'aurais toujours considere Mlle Taylor comme une femme tres fortunee.

eng: I shall never forget his flying Henry's kite for him that very windy day last Easter--and ever since his particular kindness last September twelvemonth in writing that note, at twelve o'clock at night, on purpose to assure me that there was no scarlet fever at Cobham, I have been convinced there could not be a more feeling heart nor a better man in existence.--If any body can deserve him, it must be Miss Taylor.
fr: Je n'oublierai jamais la bonne grace qu'il a mise a lancer le cerf-volant d'Henri un jour de grand vent pendant les dernieres vacances de Paques ; et depuis le jour ou il a pris la peine de m'ecrire en rentrant chez lui, a minuit, pour me rassurer au sujet d'une rumeur relative a des cas de fievre typhoide a Cobham, j'ai toujours eu la conviction qu'il n'y a pas un meilleur coeur sur la terre. Personne plus que Mlle Taylor ne meritait un pareil mari !

eng: "Where is the young man?"
fr: "Ou est le jeune homme ?

eng: "Has he been here on this occasion--or has he not?"
fr: ~~~ dit M. Jean Knightley ; a-t-il fait son apparition, oui ou non ?

eng: "He has not been here yet,"
fr: -- Il a ete question d'une visite au moment du mariage, repondit Emma ;

eng: "There was a strong expectation of his coming soon after the marriage, but it ended in nothing; and I have not heard him mentioned lately."
fr: mais notre attente a ete decue. Depuis je n'ai plus entendu parler de lui.

eng: "But you should tell them of the letter, my dear,"
fr: -- Vous oubliez la lettre, ma chere ! reprit M. Woodhouse.

eng: "He wrote a letter to poor Mrs. Weston, to congratulate her, and a very proper, handsome letter it was. She shewed it to me. I thought it very well done of him indeed. Whether it was his own idea you know, one cannot tell. He is but young, and his uncle, perhaps--"
fr: Il a ecrit une lettre de felicitations a cette pauvre Mme Weston qui me l'a montree et je l'ai trouvee fort bien tournee. Je ne puis affirmer que l'idee vienne de lui : il est jeune, et c'est peut-etre son oncle...

eng: "My dear papa, he is three-and-twenty.
fr: -- Mon cher papa, il a vingt-trois ans ;

eng: You forget how time passes."
fr: vous oubliez que le temps passe.

eng: "Three-and-twenty!--is he indeed?--Well, I could not have thought it--and he was but two years old when he lost his poor mother! Well, time does fly indeed!--and my memory is very bad.
fr: Vingt-trois ans ! ~~~ Est-ce possible ? Je ne l'aurais jamais cru ; il n'avait que deux ans quand sa pauvre mere est morte ; les annees s'envolent veritablement et ma memoire est bien mauvaise.

eng: However, it was an exceeding good, pretty letter, and gave Mr. and Mrs. Weston a great deal of pleasure. I remember it was written from Weymouth, and dated Sept. 28th--and began, 'My dear Madam,' but I forget how it went on; and it was signed 'F. C. Weston Churchill.' --I remember that perfectly."
fr: Quoiqu'il en soit, la lettre etait parfaite ; je me rappelle qu'elle etait datee de Weymouth et qu'elle commencait ainsi : << Ma chere Madame >>, mais je ne me rappelle pas la suite ; elle etait signee : << Fr. C. Weston Churchill. >>

eng: "How very pleasing and proper of him!"
fr: -- C'est tout a sa louange, s'ecria Mme Jean Knightley, toujours prete a approuver.

eng: '"Nobody ever did think well of the Churchills, I fancy," observed Mr. John Knightley coolly.
fr: '-- Personne n'a jamais eu bonne opinion des Churchill, dit froidement M. Jean Knightley,

eng: "But you need not imagine Mr. Weston to have felt what you would feel in giving up Henry or John.
fr: mais ne vous imaginez pas, ma chere Isabelle, que M. Weston ait ressenti, en laissant partir son fils, ce que vous eprouveriez en vous separant d'Henri ou de Jean.

eng: Mr. Weston is rather an easy, cheerful-tempered man, than a man of strong feelings; he takes things as he finds them, and makes enjoyment of them somehow or other, depending, I suspect, much more upon what is called society for his comforts, that is, upon the power of eating and drinking, and playing whist with his neighbours five times a week, than upon family affection, or any thing that home affords."
fr: M. Weston a un caractere enjoue et conciliant, mais sans profondeur ; il prend les choses comme elles viennent et en tire le meilleur parti possible ; je pense qu'il attache plus d'importance aux satisfactions de ce qu'on appelle le monde, c'est-a-dire a la possibilite, de prendre ses repas et de jouer au whist cinq fois par semaine avec ses voisins, qu'aux affections de famille ou aux satisfactions de son interieur.

eng: Emma could not like what bordered on a reflection on Mr. Weston, and had half a mind to take it up; but she struggled, and let it pass.
fr: Emma ne pouvait qu'etre blessee d'une remarque aussi desobligeante pour M. Weston et elle avait grande envie d'y repondre, mais elle se retint et laissa tomber le sujet.

eng: She would keep the peace if possible; and there was something honourable and valuable in the strong domestic habits, the all-sufficiency of home to himself, whence resulted her brother's disposition to look down on the common rate of social intercourse, and those to whom it was important.--It had a high claim to forbearance.
fr: Elle etait desireuse de conserver la paix, si c'etait possible ; d'autre part, elle ne pouvait s'empecher d'admirer la force du lien de famille chez son beau-frere et le sentiment qui lui faisait tenir ce langage.

eng: CHAPTER XII
fr: XII

eng: Mr. Knightley was to dine with them--rather against the inclination of Mr. Woodhouse, who did not like that any one should share with him in Isabella's first day.
fr: M. Knightley devait diner a Hartfield, un peu contre l'inclination de M. Woodhouse qui n'aimait a partager avec personne le premier soir d'Isabelle.

eng: Emma's sense of right however had decided it; and besides the consideration of what was due to each brother, she had particular pleasure, from the circumstance of the late disagreement between Mr. Knightley and herself, in procuring him the proper invitation.
fr: Mais Emma qui avait l'esprit droit en avait decide ainsi. En dehors des egards qu'il etait naturel de temoigner aux deux freres, elle avait eu un plaisir particulier a faire cette invitation a cause du desaccord survenu entre elle et M. Knightley.

eng: She hoped they might now become friends again.
fr: Elle esperait que le moment de la reconciliation etait venu ;

eng: She thought it was time to make up.
fr: a vrai dire, le mot n'etait pas exact, car elle ne se considerait pas comme ayant eu des torts et elle savait que, de son cote, il ne voudrait jamais reconnaitre les siens ;

eng: ~~~ Making-up indeed would not do. ~~~
fr: les concessions reciproques etaient donc hors de question ;

eng: _She_ certainly had not been in the wrong, and _he_ would never own that he had.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Concession must be out of the question; but it was time to appear to forget that they had ever quarrelled; and she hoped it might rather assist the restoration of friendship, that when he came into the room she had one of the children with her--the youngest, a nice little girl about eight months old, who was now making her first visit to Hartfield, and very happy to be danced about in her aunt's arms.
fr: mais il etait temps de paraitre avoir oublie qu'ils s'etaient jamais querelles ; elle comptait que la presence des enfants servirait de pretexte a la reprise de leurs relations d'amitie : quand il entra dans le salon, Emma tenait sur ses genoux une gentille petite fille d'environ huit mois qui faisait sa premiere visite a Hartfield et paraissait tres satisfaite de sauter dans les bras de sa tante ;

eng: ~~~ It did assist; for though he began with grave looks and short questions, he was soon led on to talk of them all in the usual way, and to take the child out of her arms with all the unceremoniousness of perfect amity.
fr: tout en debitant avec un visage grave des reponses concises, il fut vite amene a parler des nouveaux arrivants sur un ton habituel : il finit par lui prendre l'enfant des bras de la facon la moins ceremonieuse.

eng: Emma felt they were friends again; and the conviction giving her at first great satisfaction, and then a little sauciness, she could not help saying, as he was admiring the baby, "What a comfort it is, that we think alike about our nephews and nieces.
fr: Emma sentit qu'ils etaient de nouveau amis ; cette conviction lui rendit toute sa confiance en elle-meme. Elle ne put s'empecher de faire allusion a leur recent malentendu et elle dit, pendant qu'il admirait l'enfant : -- Nos opinions sur les adultes different parfois essentiellement, mais j'ai remarque que, quand il s'agit de nos neveux et nieces, nous sommes toujours d'accord.'

eng: As to men and women, our opinions are sometimes very different; but with regard to these children, I observe we never disagree."'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Tell your aunt, little Emma, that she ought to set you a better example than to be renewing old grievances, and that if she were not wrong before, she is now.
fr: Dites a votre tante, petite Emma, qu'elle devrait vous donner un meilleur exemple que de reveiller de vieux griefs et que, si elle n'etait pas dans son tort auparavant, elle l'est aujourd'hui.

eng: "That's true," she cried--"very true. Little Emma, grow up a better woman than your aunt.
fr: -- C'est juste, dit-elle, devenez meilleure que votre tante, ma petite Emma ; soyez plus intelligente et moins vaniteuse.

eng: Be infinitely cleverer and not half so conceited.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Now, Mr. Knightley, a word or two more, and I have done.
fr: Encore un mot, Monsieur Knightley, et j'ai fini :

eng: As far as good intentions went, we were _both_ right, and I must say that no effects on my side of the argument have yet proved wrong.
fr: je me plais a reconnaitre que nous etions tous les deux bien intentionnes, et je desire savoir si M. Martin n'a pas ete cruellement desappointe.

eng: I only want to know that Mr. Martin is not very, very bitterly disappointed.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "A man cannot be more so," was his short, full answer.
fr: -- Il est impossible de l'etre plus.

eng: "Ah!--Indeed I am very sorry.--Come, shake hands with me."
fr: -- Vraiment ! ~~~ Je le regrette beaucoup. Allons, serrons-nous la main.

eng: This had just taken place and with great cordiality, when John Knightley made his appearance, and "How d'ye do, George?" and "John, how are you?" succeeded in the true English style, burying under a calmness that seemed all but indifference, the real attachment which would have led either of them, if requisite, to do every thing for the good of the other.
fr: Cette effusion venait de prendre fin, quand Jean Knightley fit son entree ; et les : << Comment va Georges ? Jean, comment allez-vous ? >> se succederent selon la vraie tradition anglaise ; ils cachaient sous une froideur apparente leur reel attachement qui aurait conduit chacun a faire tout pour le bien de l'autre.

eng: The evening was quiet and conversable, as Mr. Woodhouse declined cards entirely for the sake of comfortable talk with his dear Isabella, and the little party made two natural divisions; on one side he and his daughter; on the other the two Mr. Knightleys; their subjects totally distinct, or very rarely mixing--and Emma only occasionally joining in one or the other.
fr: La soiree se passa tranquillement et M. Woodhouse se refusa a jouer aux cartes pour se consacrer tout entier a la conversation de sa chere Isabelle. ~~~ La petite societe se divisa en deux parties : d'un cote M. Woodhouse et sa fille, de l'autre les deux messieurs Knightley. Les sujets de conversation respectifs ne se melaient que tres rarement ; Emma se joignait alternativement a l'un ou a l'autre groupe.

eng: The brothers talked of their own concerns and pursuits, but principally of those of the elder, whose temper was by much the most communicative, and who was always the greater talker.
fr: Les deux freres parlaient de leurs affaires, mais surtout de celles de l'aine comme magistrat, celui-ci avait souvent a interroger son frere sur quelque point de droit, ou bien une anecdote curieuse a raconter ;

eng: As a magistrate, he had generally some point of law to consult John about, or, at least, some curious anecdote to give; and as a farmer, as keeping in hand the home-farm at Donwell, he had to tell what every field was to bear next year, and to give all such local information as could not fail of being interesting to a brother whose home it had equally been the longest part of his life, and whose attachments were strong.
fr: comme fermier dirigeant l'exploitation du domaine de famille, il etait tenu de dire ce que chaque champ devait produire l'annee suivante et de donner toutes les informations locales susceptibles d'interesser son frere : les questions que ce dernier posait relativement au plan d'une canalisation, au changement d'une barriere, a l'abatage d'un arbre, temoignaient du soin avec lequel il suivait tous les details des travaux agricoles.

eng: The plan of a drain, the change of a fence, the felling of a tree, and the destination of every acre for wheat, turnips, or spring corn, was entered into with as much equality of interest by John, as his cooler manners rendered possible; and if his willing brother ever left him any thing to inquire about, his inquiries even approached a tone of eagerness.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "My poor dear Isabella," said he, fondly taking her hand, and interrupting, for a few moments, her busy labours for some one of her five children--"How long it is, how terribly long since you were here!
fr: '-- Ma pauvre chere Isabelle, dit-il affectueusement en prenant la main de sa fille, interrompant quelques instants l'ouvrage destine a un des cinq enfants, comme il y a longtemps que nous n'avons ete reunis ici

eng: And how tired you must be after your journey!
fr: et comme vous devez etre fatiguee du voyage !

eng: You must go to bed early, my dear--and I recommend a little gruel to you before you go.
fr: Il faudra vous coucher de bonne heure, ma chere, et je vous recommande de prendre un peu de bouillie ayant de monter.

eng: You and I will have a nice basin of gruel together.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: My dear Emma, suppose we all have a little gruel."
fr: Ma chere Emma, si vous faisiez preparer la bouillie pour tout le monde ?

eng: Emma could not suppose any such thing, knowing as she did, that both the Mr. Knightleys were as unpersuadable on that article as herself;--and two basins only were ordered.
fr: Emma ne put entrer dans ces vues, sachant que les deux messieurs Knightley etaient aussi irreductibles qu'elle sur ce point, et deux assiettees seulement furent commandees.

eng: After a little more discourse in praise of gruel, with some wondering at its not being taken every evening by every body, he proceeded to say, with an air of grave reflection, "It was an awkward business, my dear, your spending the autumn at South End instead of coming here.
fr: Apres avoir fait l'eloge de cet aliment et s'etre etonne de ne pas rencontrer une approbation unanime, M. Woodhouse dit d'un air grave : -- Quelle etrange idee, ma chere, vous avez eue de passer votre ete a South End au lieu de venir ici.

eng: I never had much opinion of the sea air."
fr: Je n'ai jamais eu grande confiance dans l'air de la mer.'

eng: It makes me envious and miserable;--I who have never seen it!
fr: Cela m'attriste et me rend envieuse, moi qui ne l'ai jamais vue.

eng: South End is prohibited, if you please.
fr: Voila un sujet prohibe.

eng: My dear Isabella, I have not heard you make one inquiry about Mr. Perry yet; and he never forgets you.
fr: Ma chere Isabelle, je ne vous ai pas encore entendu demander des nouvelles de M. Perry et lui ne vous oublie jamais !

eng: Oh! good Mr. Perry--how is he, sir?
fr: -- Oh ! cet excellent M. Perry ! Comment se porte-t-il, Monsieur !

eng: Why, pretty well; but not quite well.
fr: -- Mais assez bien ; pas tout a fait bien pourtant ;

eng: Poor Perry is bilious, and he has not time to take care of himself--he tells me he has not time to take care of himself--which is very sad--but he is always wanted all round the country.
fr: ce pauvre Perry a mal au foie et il n'a pas le temps de se soigner ; il est appele d'un bout a l'autre du pays :

eng: I suppose there is not a man in such practice anywhere.
fr: je pense qu'il n'y a pas un autre medecin qui ait une pareille clientele

eng: But then there is not so clever a man any where.
fr: mais il faut dire aussi qu'il n'y a nulle part un medecin plus intelligent.

eng: And Mrs. Perry and the children, how are they? do the children grow?
fr: -- Et Mme Perry, et les enfants, comment vont-ils ? Ont-ils grandi ?

eng: I have a great regard for Mr. Perry.
fr: J'ai beaucoup d'amitie pour M. Perry.

eng: I hope he will be calling soon.
fr: J'espere qu'il viendra bientot a Hartfield ;

eng: He will be so pleased to see my little ones.
fr: il sera si content de voir mes petits.

eng: I hope he will be here to-morrow, for I have a question or two to ask him about myself of some consequence.
fr: Je compte sur lui demain : j'ai a le consulter sur un ou deux points

eng: And, my dear, whenever he comes, you had better let him look at little Bella's throat.
fr: et, ma chere, je vous conseille de lui laisser examiner la gorge de la petite Bella.

eng: Oh! my dear sir, her throat is so much better that I have hardly any uneasiness about it.
fr: -- Oh, Monsieur, sa gorge va tellement mieux que je n'ai plus d'inquietude a ce sujet ;

eng: Either bathing has been of the greatest service to her, or else it is to be attributed to an excellent embrocation of Mr. Wingfield's, which we have been applying at times ever since August.
fr: j'attribue cette amelioration soit aux bains de mer qui lui ont tres bien reussi soit a l'application d'un liniment ordonne par M. Wingfield.

eng: It is not very likely, my dear, that bathing should have been of use to her--and if I had known you were wanting an embrocation, I would have spoken to--
fr: Si j'avais su, ma chere, que vous aviez besoin d'un liniment je n'aurais pas manque d'en parler a...

eng: You seem to me to have forgotten Mrs. and Miss Bates," said Emma, "I have not heard one inquiry after them.
fr: Vous semblez, Isabelle, avoir tout a fait oublie les Bates, interrompit Emma, je ne vous ai pas entendu prononcer leur nom.

eng: Oh! the good Bateses--I am quite ashamed of myself--but you mention them in most of your letters.
fr: Je suis honteuse de ma negligence, mais vous me donnez de leurs nouvelles dans la plupart de vos lettres.

eng: I hope they are quite well.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Good old Mrs. Bates--I will call upon her to-morrow, and take my children.--They are always so pleased to see my children.--And that excellent Miss Bates!--such thorough worthy people!--How are they, sir?
fr: J'irai demain rendre visite a cette excellente Mme Bates et je lui conduirai mes enfants ; elle et Mlle Bates sont toujours si heureuses de les voir. Quelles braves creatures ! Comment vont-elles, Monsieur ?

eng: Why, pretty well, my dear, upon the whole. But poor Mrs. Bates had a bad cold about a month ago.
fr: -- Mais assez bien, ma chere ; toutefois la pauvre Mme Bates a eu un tres fort rhume, le mois dernier.

eng: How sorry I am! But colds were never so prevalent as they have been this autumn.
fr: Comme j'en suis fachee ! Mais les rhumes n'ont jamais ete aussi nombreux que cet automne.

eng: Mr. Wingfield told me that he has never known them more general or heavy--except when it has been quite an influenza.
fr: M. Wingfield a rarement vu autant de malades, sauf dans une periode d'influenza.

eng: That has been a good deal the case, my dear; but not to the degree you mention.
fr: C'est, en effet, un peu ce qui s'est passe ici, mais pas a ce point ;

eng: Perry says that colds have been very general, but not so heavy as he has very often known them in November.
fr: Perry dit que les rhumes ont ete assez frequents, mais qu'il a vu de plus mauvais mois de novembre ;

eng: Perry does not call it altogether a sickly season.
fr: dans l'ensemble, Perry ne considere pas cette annee comme particulierement mauvaise.

eng: No, I do not know that Mr. Wingfield considers it _very_ sickly except--
fr: -- Mais je crois que M. Wingfield partage cette opinion, sauf en ce qui concerne...

eng: Ah! my poor dear child, the truth is, that in London it is always a sickly season.
fr: La verite, ma chere enfant, c'est qu'a Londres la saison est toujours mauvaise.

eng: Nobody is healthy in London, nobody can be.
fr: Personne ne se porte bien a Londres ;

eng: It is a dreadful thing to have you forced to live there! so far off!--and the air so bad!
fr: c'est une chose terrible que vous soyez forcee d'y vivre : si loin et au mauvais air !

eng: No, indeed--_we_ are not at all in a bad air.
fr: Il ne faut pas, Monsieur, confondre notre quartier avec le reste de Londres ;

eng: Our part of London is very superior to most others!--You must not confound us with London in general, my dear sir.
fr: le voisinage de Brunswick Square fait toute la difference !

eng: The neighbourhood of Brunswick Square is very different from almost all the rest.
fr: M. Wingfield est tout a fait d'avis qu'on ne pourrait trouver un quartier plus aere.

eng: We are so very airy! I should be unwilling, I own, to live in any other part of the town;--there is hardly any other that I could be satisfied to have my children in: but _we_ are so remarkably airy!--Mr. Wingfield thinks the vicinity of Brunswick Square decidedly the most favourable as to air.
fr: Ah ! ma chere, ce n'est pas Hartfield ! Vous avez beau dire, apres une semaine passee ici, vous etes transformee ; vous n'avez plus la meme mine.

eng: "I am sorry to hear you say so, sir; but I assure you, excepting those little nervous head-aches and palpitations which I am never entirely free from anywhere, I am quite well myself; and if the children were rather pale before they went to bed, it was only because they were a little more tired than usual, from their journey and the happiness of coming."
fr: '-- Je suis fachee de vous entendre parler ainsi ; mais je puis vous assurer qu'en dehors de mes palpitations et de mes maux de tete nerveux, auxquels je suis toujours sujette, je me sens parfaitement bien ; et si les enfants etaient un peu pales avant de se coucher, c'est simplement parce qu'ils etaient fatigues du voyage.'

eng: "I hope you will think better of their looks to-morrow; for I assure you Mr. Wingfield told me, that he did not believe he had ever sent us off altogether, in such good case."
fr: 'Je suis persuadee que vous aurez meilleure opinion de leur mine demain ; M. Wingfield m'a dit qu'il ne se souvenait nous avoir vus nous mettre en route en meilleure sante.'

eng: "I trust, at least, that you do not think Mr. Knightley looking ill," turning her eyes with affectionate anxiety towards her husband.
fr: 'Il ne vous semble pas au moins, ajouta-t-elle en se tournant avec une affectueuse sollicitude vers son mari, que M. ~~~ Jean Knightley ait l'air malade ?'

eng: "Middling, my dear; I cannot compliment you. I think Mr. John Knightley very far from looking well."
fr: '-- Je ne puis vous faire mon compliment ma chere, je trouve que M. Jean Knightley est loin d'avoir bonne mine.'

eng: "What is the matter, sir?--Did you speak to me?" cried Mr. John Knightley, hearing his own name.
fr: '-- Qu'y a-t-il, Monsieur, est-ce que vous me parlez ? ~~~ dit M. Jean Knightley en entendant prononcer son nom.'

eng: "I am sorry to find, my love, that my father does not think you looking well--but I hope it is only from being a little fatigued."
fr: '-- Je regrette bien, mon cheri, d'apprendre que mon pere ne vous trouve pas bonne mine, mais j'espere que ce n'est qu'un peu de fatigue.'

eng: "My dear Isabella,"--exclaimed he hastily--"pray do not concern yourself about my looks. Be satisfied with doctoring and coddling yourself and the children, and let me look as I chuse."
fr: '-- Ma chere Isabelle, reprit vivement M. ~~~ Jean Knightley, je vous prie de ne pas vous occuper de ma mine. Contentez-vous de vous soigner, vous et vos enfants. '

eng: "I did not thoroughly understand what you were telling your brother," cried Emma, "about your friend Mr. Graham's intending to have a bailiff from Scotland, to look after his new estate. ~~~ What will it answer? Will not the old prejudice be too strong?"
fr: '-- Je n'ai pas bien compris ce que vous disiez a votre frere, interrompit Emma, au sujet de votre ami M. Graham : a-t-il l'intention de faire venir un regisseur d'Ecosse pour son nouveau domaine ? Est-ce que le vieux prejuge ne sera pas trop fort ?'

eng: "That sweet, amiable Jane Fairfax!" said Mrs. John Knightley.
fr: '-- Cette aimable et douce Jane Fairfax dit M. Jean Knightley,

eng: "It is so long since I have seen her, except now and then for a moment accidentally in town!"
fr: il y a bien longtemps que je ne l'ai vue. Je la rencontre quelquefois par hasard a Londres,

eng: "What happiness it must be to her good old grandmother and excellent aunt, when she comes to visit them!"
fr: mais je n'ai pas eu le plaisir de m'entretenir avec elle depuis plus d'un an. Quel bonheur ce doit etre pour sa vieille grand'mere et son excellente tante quand elle vient leur rendre visite !

eng: "She would be such a delightful companion for Emma."
fr: 'Jane Fairfax aurait pu etre une delicieuse compagne pour Emma.'

eng: Mr. Woodhouse agreed to it all, but added, "Our little friend Harriet Smith, however, is just such another pretty kind of young person.
fr: M. Woodhouse souscrivit volontiers a tous les eloges, mais ajouta : -- Notre petite amie, Harriet Smith, est egalement une charmante personne ;

eng: You will like Harriet.
fr: je suis certain, ma chere, qu'Harriet vous plaira.

eng: Emma could not have a better companion than Harriet."
fr: Emma ne pourrait avoir une plus agreable amie.

eng: "I am most happy to hear it--but only Jane Fairfax one knows to be so very accomplished and superior!--and exactly Emma's age."
fr: -- Je suis heureuse de l'apprendre ; je pensais a Jane Fairfax parce que c'est une jeune fille accomplie et qu'elle a exactement le meme age qu'Emma.

eng: This topic was discussed very happily, and others succeeded of similar moment, and passed away with similar harmony;
fr: Divers sujets furent abordes et discutes avec calme ;

eng: but the evening did not close without a little return of agitation.
fr: mais la soiree ne devait pas prendre fin sans que l'harmonie fut de nouveau troublee.

eng: The gruel came and supplied a great deal to be said--much praise and many comments--undoubting decision of its wholesomeness for every constitution, and pretty severe Philippics upon the many houses where it was never met with tolerably;
fr: Quand on apporta la bouillie d'avoine, Isabelle raconta

eng: --but, unfortunately, among the failures which the daughter had to instance, the most recent, and therefore most prominent, was in her own cook at South End, a young woman hired for the time, who never had been able to understand what she meant by a basin of nice smooth gruel, thin, but not too thin.
fr: qu'il ne lui avait jamais ete possible d'obtenir que la cuisiniere, engagee pendant son sejour a South End, lui servit une bouillie convenablement delayee et de la consistance voulue.'

eng: Often as she had wished for and ordered it, she had never been able to get any thing tolerable.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I shall always be very sorry that you went to the sea this autumn, instead of coming here.
fr: Je regretterai toujours que vous ayez ete a la mer cet ete au lieu de venir ici.

eng: But why should you be sorry, sir?--I assure you, it did the children a great deal of good.
fr: Mais a quel propos vous tourmentez-vous, Monsieur ? Je vous assure que ce sejour a tres bien reussi aux enfants.

eng: And, moreover, if you must go to the sea, it had better not have been to South End.
fr: En tous cas, du moment que vous etiez decidee a aller a la mer, j'estime qu'il est facheux que vous ayez donne la preference a South End : c'est un endroit malsain.

eng: South End is an unhealthy place.
fr: South End is an unhealthy place.

eng: Perry was surprized to hear you had fixed upon South End.
fr: Perry a ete surpris de ce choix.

eng: I know there is such an idea with many people, but indeed it is quite a mistake, sir.--We all had our health perfectly well there, never found the least inconvenience from the mud; and Mr. Wingfield says it is entirely a mistake to suppose the place unhealthy; and I am sure he may be depended on, for he thoroughly understands the nature of the air, and his own brother and family have been there repeatedly.
fr: Je sais que quelques personnes ont cette idee, mais c'est une erreur ; nous nous y sommes toujours tres bien portes et M. Wingfield m'a affirme que c'etait un prejuge sans fondement : il connait parfaitement les conditions climatiques de ce pays ou son frere et sa famille ont ete a plusieurs reprises.

eng: You should have gone to Cromer, my dear, if you went anywhere.--Perry was a week at Cromer once, and he holds it to be the best of all the sea-bathing places.
fr: Vous auriez du aller a Cromer, ma chere. Perry a ete une fois a Cromer qu'il considere comme la plage la plus saine de la cote : la mer y est tres belle, m'a-t-il dit, l'air excellent.

eng: A fine open sea, he says, and very pure air.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: And, by what I understand, you might have had lodgings there quite away from the sea--a quarter of a mile off--very comfortable.
fr: Vous auriez trouve la un logement confortable et suffisamment eloigne de la plage.

eng: You should have consulted Perry.
fr: Que n'avez-vous consulte Perry ?

eng: But, my dear sir, the difference of the journey;--only consider how great it would have been.--An hundred miles, perhaps, instead of forty.
fr: Mais, monsieur, considerez la difference du voyage : cent cinquante kilometres au moins au lieu de soixante.

eng: Ah! my dear, as Perry says, where health is at stake, nothing else should be considered; and if one is to travel, there is not much to chuse between forty miles and an hundred.--Better not move at all, better stay in London altogether than travel forty miles to get into a worse air.
fr: Ah, ma chere ! quand il s'agit de la sante ; comme dit Perry, aucune consideration ne doit entrer en ligne de compte, et du moment que l'on voyage, il importe peu de faire cent cinquante kilometres au lieu de soixante. Il eut ete preferable de rester simplement a Londres plutot que de faire soixante kilometres pour trouver un air plus malsain.

eng: This is just what Perry said.
fr: Telle a ete du moins l'opinion de Perry qui n'a pas approuve ce deplacement.

eng: It seemed to him a very ill-judged measure.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Emma's attempts to stop her father had been vain; and when he had reached such a point as this, she could not wonder at her brother-in-law's breaking out.
fr: Depuis quelques instants Emma s'efforcait en vain d'arreter son pere et quand celui-ci eut prononce ces dernieres paroles, elle ne put s'etonner de l'intervention de son beau-frere.

eng: "Mr. Perry," said he, in a voice of very strong displeasure, "would do as well to keep his opinion till it is asked for.
fr: "M. Perry, dit-il d'une voix qui exprimait son profond mecontentement, ferait bien de garder ses appreciations pour ceux qui les lui demandent.

eng: Why does he make it any business of his, to wonder at what I do?--at my taking my family to one part of the coast or another?--I may be allowed, I hope, the use of my judgment as well as Mr. Perry.--I want his directions no more than his drugs."
fr: A quel titre se croit-il autorise a commenter mes decisions ? Je crois etre capable de me diriger d'apres mes propres lumieres et je n'ai besoin ni de ses conseils ni de ses remedes.

eng: He paused--and growing cooler in a moment, added, with only sarcastic dryness, "If Mr. Perry can tell me how to convey a wife and five children a distance of an hundred and thirty miles with no greater expense or inconvenience than a distance of forty, I should be as willing to prefer Cromer to South End as he could himself."
fr: Puis se calmant, il ajouta : << Si M. Perry peut m'indiquer le moyen de transporter une femme et cinq enfants a cent cinquante kilometres pour le meme prix et sans plus de fatigue qu'a soixante, je serais dispose a donner la preference a Cromer.

eng: "True, true," cried Mr. Knightley, with most ready interposition--"very true. That's a consideration indeed.--But John, as to what I was telling you of my idea of moving the path to Langham, of turning it more to the right that it may not cut through the home meadows, I cannot conceive any difficulty.
fr: "C'est bien vrai, interrompit M. Knightley fort opportunement, toute la question est la. Mais pour revenir, Jean, a ce que je vous disais : mon idee est de modifier le trace du sentier qui conduit a Langham afin d'eviter qu'il ne traverse la prairie ; je ne pense pas que ce changement puisse gener d'aucune facon les habitants d'Highbury ;

eng: I should not attempt it, if it were to be the means of inconvenience to the Highbury people, but if you call to mind exactly the present line of the path.... The only way of proving it, however, will be to turn to our maps.
fr: du reste, demain matin, nous consulterons les cartes quand vous viendrez a l'abbaye et vous me donnerez votre avis.

eng: I shall see you at the Abbey to-morrow morning I hope, and then we will look them over, and you shall give me your opinion."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Mr. Woodhouse was rather agitated by such harsh reflections on his friend Perry, to whom he had, in fact, though unconsciously, been attributing many of his own feelings and expressions;--but the soothing attentions of his daughters gradually removed the present evil, and the immediate alertness of one brother, and better recollections of the other, prevented any renewal of it.
fr: M. Woodhouse manifestait quelque nervosite a la suite des reflexions peu obligeantes dirigees contre son ami Perry, auquel, sans s'en rendre compte, il n'avait cesse de preter ses propres sentiments et sa maniere de voir, mais les soins attentifs dont ses filles l'entouraient eurent vite fait de l'apaiser ; de sorte que, grace a l'esprit d'a propos de l'aine des deux freres et aux sentiments de contribution du cadet, l'incident n'eut pas d'autre suite.

eng: It was a delightful visit;--perfect, in being much too short.
fr: Ce fut une visite delicieuse, parfaite, peut-etre a cause de sa brievete meme.

eng: In general their evenings were less engaged with friends than their mornings; but one complete dinner engagement, and out of the house too, there was no avoiding, though at Christmas.
fr: Les soirees avaient ete d'un commun accord reservees a la famille ; pourtant il n'y eut pas moyen d'eviter un diner en ville, malgre la saison.

eng: Mr. Weston would take no denial; they must all dine at Randalls one day;--even Mr. Woodhouse was persuaded to think it a possible thing in preference to a division of the party.
fr: M. Weston ne voulut pas entendre parler d'un refus a l'invitation qu'il venait faire : ils etaient tous pries de venir diner a Randalls un jour de leur choix.

eng: She had not advanced many yards from Mrs. Goddard's door, when she was met by Mr. Elton himself, evidently coming towards it, and as they walked on slowly together in conversation about the invalid--of whom he, on the rumour of considerable illness, had been going to inquire, that he might carry some report of her to Hartfield--
fr: En sortant, a quelques metres de la grille, Emma rencontra M. Elton qui venait chez Mme Goddard ; << il allait precisement, lui dit-il, prendre des nouvelles de la malade et il comptait les transmettre a Hartfield >> ;

eng: they were overtaken by Mr. John Knightley returning from the daily visit to Donwell, with his two eldest boys, whose healthy, glowing faces shewed all the benefit of a country run, and seemed to ensure a quick despatch of the roast mutton and rice pudding they were hastening home for.
fr: pendant qu'ils causaient ils furent rejoints par M. ~~~ Jean Knightley et ses fils, qui revenaient de faire leur visite quotidienne a Donwell ; les deux garcons avaient une mine resplendissante a la suite de leur marche rapide et paraissaient devoir faire honneur au roti de mouton et au pudding au riz vers lesquels ils se hataient.

eng: They joined company and proceeded together.
fr: Ils continuerent leur route tous ensemble.

eng: Emma was just describing the nature of her friend's complaint;--"a throat very much inflamed, with a great deal of heat about her, a quick, low pulse, &c. and she was sorry to find from Mrs. Goddard that Harriet was liable to very bad sore-throats, and had often alarmed her with them."
fr: Emma etait en train de decrire la nature de l'indisposition de son amie : << La gorge est enflammee, le pouls agite. ~~~ J'ai appris avec regret par Mme Goddard que Harriet etait assez sujette aux maux de gorge. >>

eng: Mr. Elton looked all alarm on the occasion, as he exclaimed, "A sore-throat!--I hope not infectious. I hope not of a putrid infectious sort. Has Perry seen her?
fr: M. Elton manifesta aussitot son alarme. ~~~ -- Un mal de gorge ! j'espere que ce n'est pas infectieux. Est-ce que Perry a vu Mlle Smith ?

eng: Indeed you should take care of yourself as well as of your friend. Let me entreat you to run no risks. Why does not Perry see her?"
fr: je vous en prie, ne songez pas qu'a soigner votre amie mais prenez des precautions pour vous-meme. Ne vous exposez pas a attraper une angine.

eng: Emma, who was not really at all frightened herself, tranquillised this excess of apprehension by assurances of Mrs. Goddard's experience and care;
fr: Emma, qui n'etait en realite nullement effrayee, calma cet exces d'inquietude en l'assurant des capacites et des soins de Mme Goddard ;

eng: but as there must still remain a degree of uneasiness which she could not wish to reason away, which she would rather feed and assist than not, she added soon afterwards--as if quite another subject, "It is so cold, so very cold--and looks and feels so very much like snow, that if it were to any other place or with any other party, I should really try not to go out to-day--and dissuade my father from venturing; but as he has made up his mind, and does not seem to feel the cold himself, I do not like to interfere, as I know it would be so great a disappointment to Mr. and Mrs. Weston.'
fr: elle ne desirait pas toutefois faire disparaitre entierement les apprehensions de M. Elton et elle ajouta : -- Il fait si froid et la neige menace si evidemment que s'il s'agissait d'une autre invitation j'essayerais de ne pas sortir aujourd'hui et de detourner mon pere de courir ce risque ; mais comme il a pris son parti et ne parait pas se soucier du froid, je n'aime guere intervenir, car je sais combien grand serait le desappointement de M. et de Mme Weston.'

eng: Mr. Elton looked as if he did not very well know what answer to make; which was exactly the case; for though very much gratified by the kind care of such a fair lady, and not liking to resist any advice of her's, he had not really the least inclination to give up the visit;
fr: M. Elton parut tres perplexe : d'une part il etait extremement flatte de la sollicitude que lui temoignait une si jolie personne et il lui deplaisait de ne pas acceder a son desir, mais d'un autre cote il ne se sentait nullement dispose a renoncer a cette soiree.

eng: but Emma, too eager and busy in her own previous conceptions and views to hear him impartially, or see him with clear vision, was very well satisfied with his muttering acknowledgment of its being "very cold, certainly very cold," and walked on, rejoicing in having extricated him from Randalls, and secured him the power of sending to inquire after Harriet every hour of the evening.
fr: Quoi qu'il en soit, Emma, trop engagee dans ses idees preconcues pour l'ecouter impartialement, fut tres satisfaite quand il acquiesca vaguement en murmurant : << Il fait bien froid en effet.

eng: "You do quite right," said she;--"we will make your apologies to Mr. and Mrs. Weston."
fr: -- Vous avez bien raison, dit-elle, nous ferons vos excuses a M. et a Mme Weston.

eng: But hardly had she so spoken, when she found her brother was civilly offering a seat in his carriage, if the weather were Mr. Elton's only objection, and Mr. Elton actually accepting the offer with much prompt satisfaction.
fr: A peine avait-elle acheve sa phrase qu'elle entendit son beau-frere offrir poliment une place dans sa voiture a M. Elton, au cas ou le temps serait le seul obstacle a sa venue ; celui-ci accepta immediatement de l'air le plus satisfait.

eng: It was a done thing; Mr. Elton was to go, and never had his broad handsome face expressed more pleasure than at this moment; never had his smile been stronger, nor his eyes more exulting than when he next looked at her.
fr: C'etait une chose decidee ; M. Elton irait a Randalls ; jamais son beau visage n'avait exprime plus clairement un entier contentement ; jamais son sourire n'avait ete plus expressif et ses yeux plus rayonnants que quand il les leva vers Emma.

eng: "Well," said she to herself, "this is most strange!--After I had got him off so well, to chuse to go into company, and leave Harriet ill behind!--Most strange indeed!--
fr: << Voila qui est etrange !

eng: But there is, I believe, in many men, especially single men, such an inclination--such a passion for dining out--a dinner engagement is so high in the class of their pleasures, their employments, their dignities, almost their duties, that any thing gives way to it--and this must be the case with Mr. Elton; a most valuable, amiable, pleasing young man undoubtedly, and very much in love with Harriet; but still, he cannot refuse an invitation, he must dine out wherever he is asked.
fr: Il y a j'imagine, chez beaucoup d'hommes, et particulierement chez les celibataires, un gout immodere, une passion veritable pour diner en ville : c'est pour eux une fonction sociale, une sorte de sacerdoce, devant lequel s'efface toute autre consideration. ~~~ Ce doit etre le cas pour M. Elton, un jeune homme tres serieux pourtant et extremement amoureux d'Harriet : toutefois, il n'a pas le courage de renoncer a cette invitation. Il trouve de l'esprit a Harriet et il ne peut se resigner a diner seul a cause d'elle ! Voila bien les contradictions de l'amour !

eng: What a strange thing love is! he can see ready wit in Harriet, but will not dine alone for her.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Soon afterwards Mr. Elton quitted them, and she could not but do him the justice of feeling that there was a great deal of sentiment in his manner of naming Harriet at parting; in the tone of his voice while assuring her that he should call at Mrs. Goddard's for news of her fair friend, the last thing before he prepared for the happiness of meeting her again, when he hoped to be able to give a better report; and he sighed and smiled himself off in a way that left the balance of approbation much in his favour.
fr: Peu apres, M. Elton prit conge, et Emma constata avec satisfaction l'emotion avec laquelle il fit allusion a Harriet au moment des adieux ; son dernier mot fut qu'il irait prendre des nouvelles de son amie, avant de rentrer, et qu'il esperait etre en mesure de la rassurer.

eng: After a few minutes of entire silence between them, John Knightley began with-- "I never in my life saw a man more intent on being agreeable than Mr. Elton.
fr: Tout considere, il laissa a Emma une bonne impression. Apres quelques instants de silence, Jean Knightley dit : -- Je n'ai jamais rencontre de ma vie un homme plus desireux de se faire bien venir que M. Elton ;

eng: It is downright labour to him where ladies are concerned.
fr: il apporte a gagner la bonne grace des dames une application presque penible.

eng: With men he can be rational and unaffected, but when he has ladies to please, every feature works.
fr: Entre hommes, il peut etre raisonnable et simple, mais en presence de personnes du sexe, il se depense avec exces : chacun des traits de son visage est en mouvement.

eng: "Yes," said Mr. John Knightley presently, with some slyness, "he seems to have a great deal of good-will towards you."
fr: '-- Oui, repondit M. John Knightley apres un moment d'hesitation, il semble etre particulierement bien dispose a votre egard.'

eng: "Me!" she replied with a smile of astonishment, "are you imagining me to be Mr. Elton's object?"
fr: '-- A mon egard, reprit-elle en souriant, vous imaginez-vous que je sois l'objet des preoccupations de M. Elton ?'

eng: "Such an imagination has crossed me, I own, Emma; and if it never occurred to you before, you may as well take it into consideration now."
fr: 'J'ai eu en effet cette impression, je l'avoue ; et si vous n'y avez jamais songe jusqu'a present vous ferez bien d'y reflechir.'

eng: "I do not say it is so; but you will do well to consider whether it is so or not, and to regulate your behaviour accordingly."
fr: '-- Je ne pretends pas affirmer qu'il en soit ainsi, mais il sera sage de vous en assurer et de regler votre conduite en consequence.'

eng: "I think your manners to him encouraging."
fr: 'Je trouve que vos manieres vis-a-vis de lui sont faites pour l'encourager.'

eng: "I speak as a friend, Emma."
fr: 'Je vous parle en ami, Emma.'

eng: "You had better look about you, and ascertain what you do, and what you mean to do."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I thank you; but I assure you you are quite mistaken. Mr. Elton and I are very good friends, and nothing more;"
fr: 'Je vous remercie ; mais je vous certifie que vous vous trompez completement. M. Elton et moi sommes de tres bons amis et rien de plus.'

eng: "and she walked on, amusing herself in the consideration of the blunders which often arise from a partial knowledge of circumstances, of the mistakes which people of high pretensions to judgment are for ever falling into; and not very well pleased with her brother for imagining her blind and ignorant, and in want of counsel."
fr: 'Emma ne se sentait guere flattee que son beau-frere la supposat aveugle a ce point et elle se fut bien passe de ses conseils, mais ne voulant pas l'eclairer sur la veritable situation, elle n'insista pas et ils marcherent en silence jusqu'a Highbury.'

eng: "He said no more."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Mr. Woodhouse had so completely made up his mind to the visit, that in spite of the increasing coldness, he seemed to have no idea of shrinking from it, and set forward at last most punctually with his eldest daughter in his own carriage, with less apparent consciousness of the weather than either of the others; too full of the wonder of his own going, and the pleasure it was to afford at Randalls to see that it was cold, and too well wrapt up to feel it."
fr: 'M. Woodhouse etait si bien habitue a la perspective de diner en ville ce soir la, qu'en depit de la temperature, il n'eut pas l'idee de s'y derober ; il se mit en route tres exactement avec sa fille ainee dans sa propre voiture ; il semblait moins preoccupe du temps qu'aucun des autres et ne songeait qu'a s'emerveiller de son etonnante equipee et escomptait le plaisir qu'il allait procurer a Randalls ; il etait du reste si bien couvert qu'il ne sentait pas le froid.'

eng: "The cold, however, was severe; and by the time the second carriage was in motion, a few flakes of snow were finding their way down, and the sky had the appearance of being so overcharged as to want only a milder air to produce a very white world in a very short time."
fr: 'Quand la seconde voiture, ou avaient pris place Emma et M. ~~~ Jean Knightley, se rangea devant le perron, quelques flocons de neige commencaient a tomber ; il etait facile de prevoir qu'avant peu la terre aurait revetu un manteau blanc.'

eng: "Emma soon saw that her companion was not in the happiest humour."
fr: 'Emma s'apercut bientot que son compagnon n'etait pas d'une humeur sereine ; l'obligation de s'habiller, de sortir par un temps pareil, la privation de ses enfants apres diner constituaient une serie de derangements que M. Jean Knightley supportait mal volontiers.'

eng: "A man," said he, "must have a very good opinion of himself when he asks people to leave their own fireside, and encounter such a day as this, for the sake of coming to see him.
fr: '-- Il faut, dit-il, qu'un homme ait une bien bonne opinion de lui-meme pour inviter les gens a quitter le coin de leur feu et a affronter un temps pareil, pour le plaisir de le venir voir.

eng: He must think himself a most agreeable fellow; I could not do such a thing.
fr: Quelle presomption !

eng: It is the greatest absurdity--Actually snowing at this moment!--
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The folly of not allowing people to be comfortable at home--and the folly of people's not staying comfortably at home when they can!
fr: ~~~ Et quelle folie de se soumettre a ce desir tyrannique.

eng: If we were obliged to go out such an evening as this, by any call of duty or business, what a hardship we should deem it;--
