fr: Le ressentiment ne pouvait etre plus clairement exprime qu'au moyen de cette missive nominativement adressee a son pere et ou son nom n'etait meme pas prononce ! Il y avait dans cette maniere de faire un changement si notoire et une solennite de si mauvais gout que la rupture etait manifeste.

eng: It did, however.--Her father was quite taken up with the surprize of so sudden a journey, and his fears that Mr. Elton might never get safely to the end of it, and saw nothing extraordinary in his language.
fr: Il n'en arriva rien cependant. M. Woodhouse, tout entier a la surprise que lui causait l'annonce d'un voyage si soudain et preoccupe des dangers auxquels M. Elton selon lui allait se trouver expose, ne vit quoi que ce soit d'extraordinaire aux formules de la lettre.

eng: Her tears fell abundantly--but her grief was so truly artless, that no dignity could have made it more respectable in Emma's eyes--and she listened to her and tried to console her with all her heart and understanding--really for the time convinced that Harriet was the superior creature of the two--and that to resemble her would be more for her own welfare and happiness than all that genius or intelligence could do.
fr: Emma l'ecouta et essaya de la consoler avec tout son coeur et son intelligence ; Elle etait veritablement convaincue dans cet instant qu'Harriet etait des deux la creature superieure. Elle aurait voulu lui ressembler.

eng: It was rather too late in the day to set about being simple-minded and ignorant; but she left her with every previous resolution confirmed of being humble and discreet, and repressing imagination all the rest of her life.
fr: Il etait un peu tard pour devenir simple d'esprit et ignorante, mais elle prit la resolution d'etre humble et modeste et de moderer son imagination pour le reste de sa vie.

eng: Her second duty now, inferior only to her father's claims, was to promote Harriet's comfort, and endeavour to prove her own affection in some better method than by match-making.
fr: Dorenavant, apres les devoirs qu'elle avait vis-a-vis de son pere, elle se considerait comme tenue de prouver a Harriet son affection d'une maniere efficace.

eng: She got her to Hartfield, and shewed her the most unvarying kindness, striving to occupy and amuse her, and by books and conversation, to drive Mr. Elton from her thoughts.
fr: Elle l'invita a Hartfield et lui temoigna une invariable tendresse, s'efforcant de l'occuper et de l'amuser.

eng: Time, she knew, must be allowed for this being thoroughly done; and she could suppose herself but an indifferent judge of such matters in general, and very inadequate to sympathise in an attachment to Mr. Elton in particular; but it seemed to her reasonable that at Harriet's age, and with the entire extinction of all hope, such a progress might be made towards a state of composure by the time of Mr. Elton's return, as to allow them all to meet again in the common routine of acquaintance, without any danger of betraying sentiments or increasing them.
fr: Emma savait que le temps seul pourrait amener l'oubli et, sans pretendre etre juge de la force d'un attachement inspire par M. Elton, il lui semblait raisonnable de supposer qu'a l'age d'Harriet ce resultat pourrait etre obtenu a peu pres a l'epoque du retour de ce dernier.

eng: Harriet did think him all perfection, and maintained the non-existence of any body equal to him in person or goodness--and did, in truth, prove herself more resolutely in love than Emma had foreseen; but yet it appeared to her so natural, so inevitable to strive against an inclination of that sort _unrequited_, that she could not comprehend its continuing very long in equal force.
fr: Harriet, il est vrai, continuait a voir en M. Elton toutes les perfections et elle persistait a le considerer comme superieur a tout le monde, au physique comme au moral ; mais comme d'autre part Harriet acceptait sans aucune arriere-pensee la necessite de lutter contre un attachement aussi sterile, Emma jugeait impossible que, dans ces conditions, Harriet persistat a placer son bonheur dans un amour sans espoir.

eng: If Mr. Elton, on his return, made his own indifference as evident and indubitable as she could not doubt he would anxiously do, she could not imagine Harriet's persisting to place her happiness in the sight or the recollection of him.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Their being fixed, so absolutely fixed, in the same place, was bad for each, for all three.
fr: Sans doute il etait facheux qu'ils fussent etablis tous trois dans le meme pays mais puisqu'aucun d'eux n'etait a meme de changer de milieu il fallait se resigner a l'inevitable et se preparer a se retrouver souvent.

eng: Not one of them had the power of removal, or of effecting any material change of society.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They must encounter each other, and make the best of it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Harriet was farther unfortunate in the tone of her companions at Mrs. Goddard's; Mr. Elton being the adoration of all the teachers and great girls in the school; and it must be at Hartfield only that she could have any chance of hearing him spoken of with cooling moderation or repellent truth.
fr: Harriet etait particulierement mal placee a ce point de vue chez Mme Goddard : M. Elton etant un objet d'admiration perpetuelle pour les maitresses et les eleves de l'ecole ; aussi Emma prit-elle resolution de faire venir son amie a Hartfield le plus souvent possible.

eng: Where the wound had been given, there must the cure be found if anywhere; and Emma felt that, till she saw her in the way of cure, there could be no true peace for herself.
fr: C'etait dans le lieu meme ou la blessure avait ete faite qu'il fallait appliquer le pansement ! Emma sentait qu'elle ne retrouverait la paix de l'esprit que le jour ou elle pourrait constater la guerison de son amie.

eng: She then proceeded to say a good deal more than she felt, of the advantage of such an addition to their confined society in Surry; the pleasure of looking at somebody new; the gala-day to Highbury entire, which the sight of him would have made; and ending with reflections on the Churchills again, found herself directly involved in a disagreement with Mr. Knightley; and, to her great amusement, perceived that she was taking the other side of the question from her real opinion, and making use of Mrs. Weston's arguments against herself.
fr: Elle se trouva bientot en desaccord, a son grand amusement, avec M. Knightley et s'apercut qu'elle soutenait precisement la contre-partie de sa veritable opinion, se preparant a se servir des arguments que M. Weston avait employes contre elle-meme.

eng: "The Churchills are very likely in fault," said Mr. Knightley, coolly; "but I dare say he might come if he would."
fr: -- Je ne doute pas que les Churchill ne soient dans le tort, dit M. Knightley, << mais je pense neanmoins que si le jeune homme voulait, il pourrait venir >>.

eng: "I do not know why you should say so. He wishes exceedingly to come; but his uncle and aunt will not spare him."
fr: -- Je ne sais pourquoi vous parlez ainsi : il a le plus grand desir de faire cette visite mais son oncle et sa tante ne veulent pas se priver de lui.

eng: "I cannot believe that he has not the power of coming, if he made a point of it. It is too unlikely, for me to believe it without proof."
fr: -- C'est bien improbable ; il faudrait que j'eusse la preuve de cette opposition pour excuser le neveu.

eng: "How odd you are! What has Mr. Frank Churchill done, to make you suppose him such an unnatural creature?"
fr: -- Qu'est-ce que M. Frank Churchill vous a donc fait pour que vous lui supposiez des sentiments aussi denatures ?

eng: If Frank Churchill had wanted to see his father, he would have contrived it between September and January.
fr: Si Frank Churchill avait desire voir son pere il se serait arrange a le faire entre le mois de septembre et le mois de janvier.

eng: A man at his age--what is he?--three or four-and-twenty--cannot be without the means of doing as much as that.
fr: Un homme de son age - vingt-trois ou vingt-quatre ans, n'est-ce pas ? - trouve toujours moyen d'arriver a ses fins lorsqu'elles sont aussi legitimes.

eng: "It is impossible." "That's easily said, and easily felt by you, who have always been your own master.
fr: -- C'est facile a dire ; c'est bien la maniere de voir d'un homme qui a toujours ete son maitre.

eng: You are the worst judge in the world, Mr. Knightley, of the difficulties of dependence.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He cannot want money--he cannot want leisure.
fr: -- Il est impossible d'imaginer qu'un homme de vingt-quatre ans soit a ce point prive de sa liberte physique et morale ; ce n'est pas l'argent qui lui manque ni le loisir ;

eng: We know, on the contrary, that he has so much of both, that he is glad to get rid of them at the idlest haunts in the kingdom.
fr: nous savons au contraire qu'il a l'un et l'autre et qu'il aime a les gaspiller dans les endroits ou l'on s'amuse ;

eng: We hear of him for ever at some watering-place or other.
fr: de temps a autre nous apprenons qu'il villegiature dans telle ou telle ville d'eau :

eng: A little while ago, he was at Weymouth.
fr: dernierement il etait a Weymouth ;

eng: This proves that he can leave the Churchills.
fr: ce qui prouve qu'il peut quitter les Churchill.

eng: "Yes, sometimes he can."
fr: -- Oui, quelquefois.

eng: "And those times are whenever he thinks it worth his while; whenever there is any temptation of pleasure."
fr: -- Et ce sont precisement toutes les fois qu'il estime que le deplacement en vaut la peine ou bien lorsque son plaisir est en jeu.

eng: Nobody, who has not been in the interior of a family, can say what the difficulties of any individual of that family may be.
fr: Personne, a moins d'avoir vecu dans l'intimite d'une famille, ne peut dire avec quelles difficultes un membre de cette famille peut se trouver aux prises.

eng: We ought to be acquainted with Enscombe, and with Mrs. Churchill's temper, before we pretend to decide upon what her nephew can do.
fr: Il faudrait que nous fussions au courant de ce qui se passe a Enscombe et exactement renseignes sur le caractere de Mme Churchill pour apprecier ce qui est possible et ce qui ne l'est pas.

eng: "There is one thing, Emma, which a man can always do, if he chuses, and that is, his duty; not by manoeuvring and finessing, but by vigour and resolution.
fr: -- Un homme peut toujours faire son devoir ;

eng: It is Frank Churchill's duty to pay this attention to his father.
fr: M. Frank Churchill a celui de donner a son pere cette preuve de respect.

eng: He knows it to be so, by his promises and messages; but if he wished to do it, it might be done.
fr: Il le sait bien, comme il appert de ses lettres et de ses messages ; rien ne lui serait plus facile que d'agir en conformite.

eng: A man who felt rightly would say at once, simply and resolutely, to Mrs. Churchill--'Every sacrifice of mere pleasure you will always find me ready to make to your convenience; but I must go and see my father immediately.'
fr: Un homme de sens droit dirait de suite avec simplicite et resolution a Mme Churchill : << Vous me trouverez toujours pret a vous faire le sacrifice d'un plaisir, mais il faut que j'aille voir mon pere immediatement.'

eng: He may, at times, be able to do a great deal more than he can at others."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: --If he would say so to her at once, in the tone of decision becoming a man, there would be no opposition made to his going.
fr: >> S'il avait parle sur le ton qui convient a un homme, aucune opposition n'eut ete faite a son voyage.

eng: "No," said Emma, laughing; "but perhaps there might be some made to his coming back again.
fr: -- Non, dit Emma en riant, mais peut-etre en revanche se fut-on oppose a son retour.

eng: Such language for a young man entirely dependent, to use!--
fr: Ce serait un etrange langage dans la bouche d'un jeune homme absolument dependant ;

eng: Nobody but you, Mr. Knightley, would imagine it possible.
fr: il n'y a que vous, Monsieur Knightley, qui puissiez imaginer une chose de ce genre ;

eng: But you have not an idea of what is requisite in situations directly opposite to your own.
fr: mais vous ne vous rendez pas compte de ce que commande une situation si differente de la votre.

eng: Mr. Frank Churchill to be making such a speech as that to the uncle and aunt, who have brought him up, and are to provide for him!--
fr: Je vois d'ici M. Frank Churchill tenant un discours de ce genre a l'oncle et a la tante qui l'ont eleve et dont son avenir depend !

eng: Standing up in the middle of the room, I suppose, and speaking as loud as he could!--
fr: Il se placerait debout au milieu de la chambre, je suppose, en elevant la voix.

eng: How can you imagine such conduct practicable?
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Depend upon it, Emma, a sensible man would find no difficulty in it.
fr: Croyez-moi, Emma, ce desir fermement exprime avec, bien entendu, toutes les formes du respect,

eng: He would feel himself in the right; and the declaration--made, of course, as a man of sense would make it, in a proper manner--would do him more good, raise him higher, fix his interest stronger with the people he depended on, than all that a line of shifts and expedients can ever do.
fr: lui aurait gagne l'estime de ceux dont il depend et n'aurait fait qu'augmenter l'interet et l'affection qu'ils lui portent.

eng: Respect would be added to affection.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They would feel that they could trust him; that the nephew who had done rightly by his father, would do rightly by them; for they know, as well as he does, as well as all the world must know, that he ought to pay this visit to his father; and while meanly exerting their power to delay it, are in their hearts not thinking the better of him for submitting to their whims.
fr: Ils connaissent, comme tout le monde les devoirs d'un fils vis-a-vis son pere, et tout en employant leur influence d'une facon mesquine pour retarder ce voyage, ils ne doivent pas avoir au fond du coeur bonne opinion du neveu chez qui il trouve si peu de resistance a leurs caprices ;

eng: Respect for right conduct is felt by every body.
fr: si ce dernier s'inspirait toujours de sentiments aussi naturels, il aurait vite fait de plier, selon son gre, leurs esprits retrecis.

eng: If he would act in this sort of manner, on principle, consistently, regularly, their little minds would bend to his.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I rather doubt that.
fr: J'en doute fort :

eng: You are very fond of bending little minds; but where little minds belong to rich people in authority, I think they have a knack of swelling out, till they are quite as unmanageable as great ones.
fr: quand les esprits retrecis sont ceux de gens considerables par la situation et la fortune, ils ont une tendance a s'enfler demesurement et deviennent aussi difficiles a influencer que les grands.

eng: I can imagine, that if you, as you are, Mr. Knightley, were to be transported and placed all at once in Mr. Frank Churchill's situation, you would be able to say and do just what you have been recommending for him; and it might have a very good effect.
fr: D'autre part, je puis imaginer que si vous, Monsieur Knightley, vous vous trouviez transporte tel que vous etes a la place de Frank Churchill, vous seriez peut-etre a meme de dire et de faire precisement ce que vous suggerez ; vous pourriez obtenir un excellent resultat ;

eng: The Churchills might not have a word to say in return; but then, you would have no habits of early obedience and long observance to break through.
fr: les Churchill ne trouveraient sans doute rien a repondre, mais vous vous n'auriez pas a lutter contre des habitudes inveterees d'obeissance et de soumission.

eng: To him who has, it might not be so easy to burst forth at once into perfect independence, and set all their claims on his gratitude and regard at nought.
fr: Pour lui, au contraire, ce ne doit pas etre si facile d'entrer de plain pied dans un ton de parfaite independance et d'oublier en un instant tous les titres qu'ont son oncle et sa tante a sa reconnaissance et a son respect.

eng: He may have as strong a sense of what would be right, as you can have, without being so equal, under particular circumstances, to act up to it.
fr: Dans ce cas, il ne sent pas comme moi ;

eng: Then it would not be so strong a sense.
fr: sa conviction n'est pas si forte,

eng: If it failed to produce equal exertion, it could not be an equal conviction.
fr: sinon elle produirait le meme effet.

eng: Oh, the difference of situation and habit!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I can allow for the fears of the child, but not of the man.
fr: Je comprends la crainte chez l'enfant, mais je ne l'admets pas chez l'homme :

eng: As he became rational, he ought to have roused himself and shaken off all that was unworthy in their authority.
fr: il pouvait continuer a se soumettre a leur autorite, il ne devait pas se plier a leur tyrannie ;

eng: He ought to have opposed the first attempt on their side to make him slight his father.
fr: il aurait du s'opposer fermement a la premiere tentative faite pour l'amener a negliger son pere.

eng: Had he begun as he ought, there would have been no difficulty now."
fr: S'il avait, des le debut, pris l'attitude qui convenait, il ne se trouverait pas embarrasse aujourd'hui.

eng: "We shall never agree about him," cried Emma; "but that is nothing extraordinary.
fr: -- Nous ne serons jamais d'accord a son sujet, repondit Emma, je ne me le figure pas du tout

eng: I have not the least idea of his being a weak young man: I feel sure that he is not.
fr: d'apres ce que m'a dit M. Weston comme ayant un caractere faible, mais probablement sa nature est plus douce, plus aimable, plus soumise que vous ne le jugez convenable chez l'homme ideal ;

eng: Mr. Weston would not be blind to folly, though in his own son; but he is very likely to have a more yielding, complying, mild disposition than would suit your notions of man's perfection.
fr: il perdra peut-etre de ce fait certains avantages mais il doit avoir les qualites de ses defauts.

eng: I dare say he has; and though it may cut him off from some advantages, it will secure him many others."'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He can sit down and write a fine flourishing letter, full of professions and falsehoods, and persuade himself that he has hit upon the very best method in the world of preserving peace at home and preventing his father's having any right to complain.
fr: Quand il s'est assis a son bureau et qu'il a ecrit une belle lettre emphatique, remplie de protestations et de faussetes, il est persuade qu'il a trouve le meilleur moyen du monde pour conserver la paix en famille, tout en empechant son pere d'avoir aucun droit de se plaindre.

eng: His letters disgust me.
fr: Je ne puis souffrir ses lettres.

eng: Your feelings are singular.
fr: Voila qui est singulier ;

eng: They seem to satisfy every body else.
fr: vous etes seul de votre avis ; tout le monde est d'accord pour se montrer satisfait de ses lettres.

eng: I suspect they do not satisfy Mrs. Weston.
fr: J'ai idee qu'elles ne satisfont pas Mme Weston.

eng: They hardly can satisfy a woman of her good sense and quick feelings: standing in a mother's place, but without a mother's affection to blind her.
fr: Et comment pourraient-elles contenter une femme de bon sens et de coeur qui tient la place d'une mere sans etre aveuglee par l'amour maternel.

eng: It is on her account that attention to Randalls is doubly due, and she must doubly feel the omission.
fr: C'est a cause d'elle que des egards particuliers s'imposaient en cette circonstance et elle doit doublement souffrir de leur absence.

eng: Had she been a person of consequence herself, he would have come I dare say; and it would not have signified whether he did or no.
fr: Si elle avait ete elle-meme une personne d'importance il serait probablement venu ; dans ce cas, du reste, la signification d'une telle demarche eut ete tres amoindrie.

eng: Can you think your friend behindhand in these sort of considerations?
fr: Croyez-vous que votre amie n'ait pas fait ces memes reflexions ?

eng: Do you suppose she does not often say all this to herself?
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: No, Emma, your amiable young man can be amiable only in French, not in English. He may be very 'amiable,' have very good manners, and be very agreeable; but he can have no English delicacy towards the feelings of other people: nothing really amiable about him.
fr: Non, Emma, votre jeune homme peut etre aimable et expert dans l'art de se faire bien venir, mais il manque absolument de delicatesse de sentiment et n'a rien de ce qu'il faut pour inspirer de l'affection.

eng: "Well, if he have nothing else to recommend him, he will be a treasure at Highbury."
fr: 'S'il n'a d'autres avantages que ceux-la, ce sera encore un tresor pour Highbury.'

eng: "We do not often look upon fine young men, well-bred and agreeable."
fr: 'Nous ne voyons pas tous les jours d'agreables jeunes gens bien eleves et de bonnes manieres ;'

eng: "We must not be nice and ask for all the virtues into the bargain."
fr: 'ne soyons pas trop exigeants et ne reclamons pas toutes les vertus par dessus le marche !'

eng: "Cannot you imagine, Mr. Knightley, what a _sensation_ his coming will produce?"
fr: 'Vous imaginez-vous, Monsieur Knightley, la sensation que son arrivee produira ?'

eng: "There will be but one subject throughout the parishes of Donwell and Highbury; but one interest--one object of curiosity; it will be all Mr. Frank Churchill; we shall think and speak of nobody else."
fr: 'Dans les paroisses de Donwell et d'Highbury, il n'y aura pas d'autre sujet de conversation ; tout l'interet sera concentre sur lui ; nous ne parlerons plus que de M. Frank Churchill !'

eng: "You will excuse my being so much over-powered."
fr: '-- Vous m'excuserez de ne pas etre ebloui a ce point.'

eng: "If I find him conversable, I shall be glad of his acquaintance; but if he is only a chattering coxcomb, he will not occupy much of my time or thoughts."
fr: 'Si je trouve ce jeune homme d'un commerce agreable, je serai content d'avoir fait sa connaissance ; mais s'il n'est que fat et bavard il ne me prendra pas beaucoup de mon temps ni de mon attention.'

eng: at three-and-twenty to be the king of his company--the great man--the practised politician, who is to read every body's character, and make every body's talents conduce to the display of his own superiority; to be dispensing his flatteries around, that he may make all appear like fools compared with himself!
fr: A vingt-quatre ans, se poser comme le roi de son milieu, le grand homme, le politicien avise qui lit dans l'esprit de chacun et qui se sert des talents de tous pour la glorification de sa propre superiorite !

eng: My dear Emma, your own good sense could not endure such a puppy when it came to the point.
fr: Ma chere Emma, votre bon sens s'accommoderait mal d'un personnage aussi ridicule.

eng: "I will say no more about him," cried Emma, "you turn every thing to evil.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: We are both prejudiced; you against, I for him; and we have no chance of agreeing till he is really here.
fr: Nous avons tous deux des preventions : vous, contre lui ; moi, en sa faveur, et nous ne pourrons pas nous mettre d'accord tant qu'il ne sera pas la pour nous departager.

eng: "Prejudiced!
fr: -- Quant a moi, je n'ai pas de preventions !

eng: I am not prejudiced.
fr: -- Mais moi j'en ai et je n'en rougis pas.

eng: But I am very much, and without being at all ashamed of it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: My love for Mr. and Mrs. Weston gives me a decided prejudice in his favour.
fr: Mon affection pour M. et Mme Weston m'incite a me montrer partiale a son egard.

eng: Emma and Harriet had been walking together one morning, and, in Emma's opinion, had been talking enough of Mr. Elton for that day.
fr: Les deux amies marchaient ensemble un matin et Emma jugeait le moment venu de changer de conversation :

eng: She could not think that Harriet's solace or her own sins required more; and she was therefore industriously getting rid of the subject as they returned;--but it burst out again when she thought she had succeeded,
fr: elle me pensait pas qu'il fut necessaire pour le soulagement d'Harriet et l'expiation de son propre peche de parler plus longtemps de M. Elton ; en consequence elle s'efforcait habilement de se debarrasser de ce sujet et elle croyait avoir reussi lorsqu'il revint inopinement a la surface :

eng: and after speaking some time of what the poor must suffer in winter, and receiving no other answer than a very plaintive--"Mr. Elton is so good to the poor!"
fr: Emma ayant parle non sans eloquence des souffrances que les pauvres endurent pendant l'hiver n'avait obtenu pour reponse qu'un plaintif << M. Elton est si bon pour les pauvres ! >>

eng: she found something else must be done.
fr: Il fallait chercher un autre derivatif.

eng: They were just approaching the house where lived Mrs. and Miss Bates.
fr: Elle eut l'idee de faire une visite a Mme et Mlle Bates, dont la maison se trouvait precisement sur son itineraire.

eng: She determined to call upon them and seek safety in numbers.
fr: Peut-etre trouverait-elle le salut dans le nombre !

eng: But now she made the sudden resolution of not passing their door without going in--observing, as she proposed it to Harriet, that, as well as she could calculate, they were just now quite safe from any letter from Jane Fairfax.
fr: Avant d'entrer, Emma fit observer a Harriet que, d'apres ses precisions, judicieusement etablies sur les donnees du calendrier, elles avaient bien des chances, ce jour-la, d'echapper a une lettre de Jane Fairfax.

eng: The house belonged to people in business.
fr: La maison, appartenait a des commercants et les magasins occupaient tout le rez-de-chaussee.

eng: Mrs. and Miss Bates occupied the drawing-room floor; and there, in the very moderate-sized apartment, which was every thing to them, the visitors were most cordially and even gratefully welcomed;
fr: Mme et Mlle Bates habitaient l'appartement du premier etage ; elles accueillirent les visiteuses avec une extreme cordialite et une reconnaissance attendrie ;

eng: the quiet neat old lady, who with her knitting was seated in the warmest corner, wanting even to give up her place to Miss Woodhouse, and her more active, talking daughter, almost ready to overpower them with care and kindness, thanks for their visit, solicitude for their shoes, anxious inquiries after Mr. Woodhouse's health, cheerful communications about her mother's, and sweet-cake from the beaufet--
fr: la vieille dame paisible et soignee qui etait assise, en train de tricoter, dans le coin le plus abrite de la chambre voulait absolument donner sa place a Mlle Woodhouse et Mlle Bates les accabla litteralement de prevenances de tous genres, de remerciements pour leur visite, d'anxieuses interrogations concernant la sante de M. Woodhouse, de joyeuses communications sur celles de sa mere, de sucreries et de gateaux.

eng: "Mrs. Cole had just been there, just called in for ten minutes, and had been so good as to sit an hour with them, and _she_ had taken a piece of cake and been so kind as to say she liked it very much; and, therefore, she hoped Miss Woodhouse and Miss Smith would do them the favour to eat a piece too."
fr: << Mme Cole venait de partir : elle etait entree pour dix minutes et avait eu la bonte de rester plus d'une heure ; elle avait pris un morceau de gateau qu'elle avait trouve excellent ; elle esperait donc que Mlle Woodhouse et Mlle Smith leur ferait egalement la faveur d'en accepter un morceau. >>

eng: The mention of the Coles was sure to be followed by that of Mr. Elton.
fr: Emma comprit de suite que l'allusion a Mme Cole devait necessairement en amener une concernant M. Elton :

eng: There was intimacy between them, and Mr. Cole had heard from Mr. Elton since his going away.
fr: M. Cole, en effet etait l'ami intime de M. Elton et Emma n'ignorait pas qu'il avait recu des nouvelles de ce dernier.

eng: Emma knew what was coming; they must have the letter over again, and settle how long he had been gone, and how much he was engaged in company, and what a favourite he was wherever he went, and how full the Master of the Ceremonies' ball had been; and she went through it very well, with all the interest and all the commendation that could be requisite, and always putting forward to prevent Harriet's being obliged to say a word.
fr: Inevitablement le contenu de la lettre serait revele ; en effet, elles furent mises au courant des engagements mondains de M. Elton, de l'accueil qui lui avait ete fait, etc. Emma ecouta avec tout l'interet voulu et se mit sans cesse en avant pour eviter a Harriet d'avoir a parler ;

eng: This she had been prepared for when she entered the house; but meant, having once talked him handsomely over, to be no farther incommoded by any troublesome topic, and to wander at large amongst all the Mistresses and Misses of Highbury, and their card-parties.
fr: elle se preparait, une fois ce sujet dangereux epuise, a entrer dans l'intimite des dames et des demoiselles d'Highbury et a assister a leurs parties de cartes ;

eng: She had not been prepared to have Jane Fairfax succeed Mr. Elton; but he was actually hurried off by Miss Bates, she jumped away from him at last abruptly to the Coles, to usher in a letter from her niece.
fr: mais elle ne s'attendait pas a voir Jane Fairfax succeder a M. Elton ; quoi qu'il en soit, ce dernier fut rapidement expedie par Mlle Bates qui l'abandonna brusquement au profit d'une lettre de sa niece.

eng: "Oh! yes--Mr. Elton, I understand--certainly as to dancing--Mrs. Cole was telling me that dancing at the rooms at Bath was--Mrs. Cole was so kind as to sit some time with us, talking of Jane; for as soon as she came in, she began inquiring after her, Jane is so very great a favourite there. Whenever she is with us, Mrs. Cole does not know how to shew her kindness enough; and I must say that Jane deserves it as much as any body can.
fr: -- Mme Cole a ete assez bonne pour nous faire une longue visite : des son arrivee elle a demande des nouvelles de Jane, elle a une vraie predilection pour elle. Quand Jane est ici, Mme Cole ne sait comment lui temoigner son affection. Je disais donc qu'elle avait demande des nouvelles en arrivant :

eng: And so she began inquiring after her directly, saying, 'I know you cannot have heard from Jane lately, because it is not her time for writing;' and when I immediately said, 'But indeed we have, we had a letter this very morning,' I do not know that I ever saw any body more surprized. 'Have you, upon your honour?' said she; 'well, that is quite unexpected.
fr: << Je sais que vous ne pouvez pas avoir des nouvelles recentes de Jane ; ce n'est pas le moment de sa lettre >> et quand j'ai repondu : << Mais vraiment nous avons recu une lettre ce matin meme >>, je n'ai jamais vu quelqu'un de plus surpris : << Est-ce possible, dit-elle, voila qui est tout a fait inattendu.

eng: Do let me hear what she says.'"
fr: Et que vous dit-elle ? >>

eng: Emma's politeness was at hand directly, to say, with smiling interest-- "Have you heard from Miss Fairfax so lately?
fr: Emma fit preuve de son habituelle politesse, en souriant d'un air d'interet et repondit : -- Je me rejouis de cette surprise ;

eng: I am extremely happy.
fr: j'espere qu'elle est en bonne sante ?

eng: I hope she is well?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Thank you.
fr: -- Merci, vous etes bien bonne !

eng: You are so kind!"
fr: reprit la credule demoiselle en cherchant fievreusement la lettre.

eng: replied the happily deceived aunt, while eagerly hunting for the letter.--"Oh! here it is.
fr: La voici ; je savais bien qu'elle n'etait pas loin, mais j'avais mis mon carnet a aiguilles dessus de sorte qu'elle etait un peu cachee ;

eng: I was sure it could not be far off; but I had put my huswife upon it, you see, without being aware, and so it was quite hid, but I had it in my hand so very lately that I was almost sure it must be on the table.
fr: je l'avais eue en main il y a si peu de temps, que j'etais a peu pres sure qu'elle ne pouvait etre que sur la table.

eng: I was reading it to Mrs. Cole, and since she went away, I was reading it again to my mother, for it is such a pleasure to her--a letter from Jane--that she can never hear it often enough; so I knew it could not be far off, and here it is, only just under my huswife--and since you are so kind as to wish to hear what she says;--but, first of all, I really must, in justice to Jane, apologise for her writing so short a letter--only two pages you see--hardly two--and in general she fills the whole paper and crosses half.
fr: Je l'ai lue a Mme Cole et depuis son depart je la relisais a ma mere, car une lettre de Jane est un si grand plaisir pour elle qu'elle ne se lasse pas de l'entendre. Je dois avant tout m'expliquer touchant la brievete de cette lettre ; il est de toute justice que vous sachiez qu'en general Jane couvre les quatre feuilles et qu'elle croise ; aujourd'hui, tout a fait par exception, vous voyez, il n'y a que deux feuilles.

eng: My mother often wonders that I can make it out so well.
fr: Ma mere est etonnee que je puisse si bien dechiffrer les lettres de Jane ;

eng: She often says, when the letter is first opened, 'Well, Hetty, now I think you will be put to it to make out all that checker-work'--don't you, ma'am?--And then I tell her, I am sure she would contrive to make it out herself, if she had nobody to do it for her--every word of it--I am sure she would pore over it till she had made out every word.
fr: elle dit souvent quand on ouvre la lettre : << Allons, Hetty, cette fois je crois que vous allez avoir fort a faire pour dechiffrer cette mosaique. >> N'est-ce pas maman ? Et je lui reponds que je suis bien sure qu'elle s'arrangerait a faire ce travail elle-meme si je n'etais pas la ; en effet, bien que les yeux de ma mere ne soient plus aussi bons qu'ils etaient, elle voit encore, grace a Dieu, extraordinairement bien a l'aide de lunettes.

eng: And, indeed, though my mother's eyes are not so good as they were, she can see amazingly well still, thank God!
fr: C'est une benediction.

eng: with the help of spectacles.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It is such a blessing!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: My mother's are really very good indeed.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Jane often says, when she is here, 'I am sure, grandmama, you must have had very strong eyes to see as you do--and so much fine work as you have done too!--I only wish my eyes may last me as well.'
fr: Jane dit souvent lorsqu'elle est ici : << Grand'mere, vous devez avoir joui d'une excellente vue pour voir encore comme vous voyez apres avoir execute a l'aiguille tant de travaux minutieux ; je souhaite que mes yeux me fassent un aussi long service que les votres.'

eng: She was pondering, in the meanwhile, upon the possibility, without seeming very rude, of making her escape from Jane Fairfax's letter, and had almost resolved on hurrying away directly under some slight excuse, when Miss Bates turned to her again and seized her attention.
fr: Pendant ce temps, elle reflechissait a la maniere d'echapper, sans paraitre impolie, a la lecture de la lettre, et elle etait sur le point de formuler une excuse quelconque et de se retirer quand Mlle Bates se retourna soudainement vers elle et reprit :

eng: "My mother's deafness is very trifling you see--just nothing at all.
fr: -- La surdite de ma mere est insignifiante comme vous pouvez le constater :

eng: By only raising my voice, and saying any thing two or three times over, she is sure to hear; but then she is used to my voice.
fr: il suffit d'elever la voix et de repeter deux ou trois fois la phrase pour qu'elle entende ; il est vrai qu'elle est accoutumee a ma voix.

eng: But it is very remarkable that she should always hear Jane better than she does me.
fr: Pourtant, chose curieuse, elle entend toujours Jane mieux que moi :

eng: Jane speaks so distinct!
fr: Jane parle si distinctement !

eng: However, she will not find her grandmama at all deafer than she was two years ago; which is saying a great deal at my mother's time of life--and it really is full two years, you know, since she was here.
fr: Celle-ci ne trouvera pas sa grand'mere plus sourde qu'il y a deux ans ; on ne saurait desirer mieux, a l'age de ma mere ; et il y a reellement deux ans, vous savez que Jane n'est venue ici.

eng: We never were so long without seeing her before, and as I was telling Mrs. Cole, we shall hardly know how to make enough of her now."
fr: Jamais nous n'avions ete si longtemps sans la voir et, comme je disais a Mme Cole, je ne sais pas comment nous ferons pour lui temoigner tout notre plaisir. --

eng: "Are you expecting Miss Fairfax here soon?"
fr: Est-ce que vous attendez Mlle Fairfax ?

eng: "Oh yes; next week."
fr: -- Mais oui : la semaine prochaine.

eng: "Indeed!--that must be a very great pleasure."
fr: -- Vraiment ! Ce sera une vraie joie pour vous.

eng: "Thank you. You are very kind. ~~~ Yes, next week. Every body is so surprized; and every body says the same obliging things. I am sure she will be as happy to see her friends at Highbury, as they can be to see her.
fr: -- Tous nos amis sont surpris et nous temoignent le meme interet. Je suis sure que Jane sera aussi heureuse de retrouver ses amis d'Highbury que ceux-ci pourront l'etre.

eng: Yes, Friday or Saturday; she cannot say which, because Colonel Campbell will be wanting the carriage himself one of those days.
fr: Elle arrivera vendredi ou samedi ; elle ne peut preciser, le colonel ayant lui-meme besoin de la voiture un des deux jours :

eng: So very good of them to send her the whole way! But they always do, you know. Oh yes, Friday or Saturday next. That is what she writes about.
fr: les Campbell sont assez bons pour la faire conduire jusqu'ici ! C'est ce qu'ils font toujours du reste. Voila la raison qui lui a fait ecrire aujourd'hui :

eng: That is the reason of her writing out of rule, as we call it; for, in the common course, we should not have heard from her before next Tuesday or Wednesday."
fr: hors de regle, comme nous disons ; en temps ordinaire, nous n'aurions pas recu de nouvelles avant mardi ou mercredi. --

eng: "Yes, so I imagined. I was afraid there could be little chance of my hearing any thing of Miss Fairfax to-day."
fr: C'est ce que je pensais ; je n'esperais pas avoir le plaisir d'entendre parler de Mlle Fairfax aujourd'hui. --

eng: "So obliging of you! No, we should not have heard, if it had not been for this particular circumstance, of her being to come here so soon.
fr: Vous etes trop bonne ! Sans cette circonstance speciale en effet nous n'aurions pas eu de lettre aujourd'hui.

eng: My mother is so delighted!--for she is to be three months with us at least. Three months, she says so, positively, as I am going to have the pleasure of reading to you.
fr: Ma mere est bien heureuse car Jane doit rester au moins trois mois avec nous ; trois mois ! Elle le dit positivement et je vais avoir le plaisir de vous lire la phrase meme de sa lettre.

eng: The case is, you see, that the Campbells are going to Ireland.
fr: Les Campbell vont en Irlande.

eng: Mrs. Dixon has persuaded her father and mother to come over and see her directly. They had not intended to go over till the summer, but she is so impatient to see them again--for till she married, last October, she was never away from them so much as a week, which must make it very strange to be in different kingdoms, I was going to say, but however different countries, and so she wrote a very urgent letter to her mother--or her father, I declare I do not know which it was, but we shall see presently in Jane's letter--wrote in Mr. Dixon's name as well as her own, to press their coming over directly, and they would give them the meeting in Dublin, and take them back to their country seat, Baly-craig, a beautiful place, I fancy.
fr: Mme Dixon a persuade son pere et sa mere de venir la voir de suite ; ils n'avaient pas l'intention de faire la traversee avant l'ete, mais elle est impatiente de les revoir ! C'est bien naturel, car jusqu'a son mariage au mois d'octobre dernier elle ne les avait jamais quittes pour plus d'une semaine et elle a du eprouver une etrange sensation en se trouvant transportee soudain, j'allais dire dans un autre royaume, en tout cas dans un autre pays. ~~~ Elle ecrivit donc d'une facon tres pressante a son pere ou a sa mere (je ne sais pas precisement auquel des deux, mais nous le saurons tout a l'heure par la lettre de Jane) tant en son nom qu'en celui de son mari pour les inviter.

eng: He is a most amiable, charming young man, I believe.
fr: C'est un jeune homme charmant.

eng: Jane was quite longing to go to Ireland, from his account of things.
fr: Elle desirait beaucoup aller en Irlande a la suite de ces descriptions.

eng: At this moment, an ingenious and animating suspicion entering Emma's brain with regard to Jane Fairfax, this charming Mr. Dixon, and the not going to Ireland, she said, with the insidious design of farther discovery, "You must feel it very fortunate that Miss Fairfax should be allowed to come to you at such a time.
fr: A ce moment, un soupcon ingenieux traversa l'esprit d'Emma, relatif a Jane Fairfax, a l'aimable M. Dixon et au fait de ne pas aller en Irlande ; elle dit avec le dessein d'en decouvrir davantage : -- Vous devez vous considerer comme tres heureuse, que Mlle Fairfax ait la possibilite de venir si longtemps chez vous ;

eng: Considering the very particular friendship between her and Mrs. Dixon, you could hardly have expected her to be excused from accompanying Colonel and Mrs. Campbell."
fr: etant donne la particuliere amitie qui existe entre elle et Mme Dixon, vous ne pouviez guere esperer qu'elle put se dispenser d'accompagner le colonel et Mme Campbell. --

eng: "Very true, very true, indeed.
fr: C'est precisement ce que nous avons toujours craint,

eng: The very thing that we have always been rather afraid of; for we should not have liked to have her at such a distance from us, for months together--not able to come if any thing was to happen.
fr: car nous n'aurions pas aime la sentir si loin de nous pendant plusieurs mois ;

eng: But you see, every thing turns out for the best.
fr: mais, vous voyez, tout tourne pour le mieux.

eng: They want her (Mr. and Mrs. Dixon) excessively to come over with Colonel and Mrs. Campbell; quite depend upon it; nothing can be more kind or pressing than their joint invitation, Jane says, as you will hear presently;
fr: M. et Mme Dixon desiraient vivement que Jane accompagna le colonel et Mme Campbell ; soyez sure que rien ne pouvait etre plus affectueuse et plus pressante que leur double invitation ;

eng: Mr. Dixon does not seem in the least backward in any attention.
fr: M. Dixon est un si charmant jeune homme !

eng: '--But ever since we had the history of that day, I have been so fond of Mr. Dixon!"
fr: 'Je ne puis jamais penser a cet accident sans trembler, et depuis, je ressens une veritable affection pour M. Dixon !

eng: "But, in spite of all her friends' urgency, and her own wish of seeing Ireland, Miss Fairfax prefers devoting the time to you and Mrs. Bates?"
fr: '-- Mais somme toute, malgre les instances de ses amis et son propre desir de connaitre l'Irlande, Mlle Fairfax prefere consacrer son temps a sa famille.

eng: "Yes--entirely her own doing, entirely her own choice; and Colonel and Mrs. Campbell think she does quite right, just what they should recommend; and indeed they particularly _wish_ her to try her native air, as she has not been quite so well as usual lately."
fr: '-- Oui, c'est absolument son choix et le colonel et Mme Campbell approuvent sa decision ; ils esperent que l'air natal lui sera salutaire ; elle n'a pas ete bien depuis quelque temps.

eng: "I am concerned to hear of it. I think they judge wisely. But Mrs. Dixon must be very much disappointed. Mrs. Dixon, I understand, has no remarkable degree of personal beauty; is not, by any means, to be compared with Miss Fairfax."
fr: '-- Je regrette de l'apprendre. Mme Dixon doit etre bien desappointee. Mme Dixon, d'apres ce que j'ai compris, n'est pas d'une grande beaute, et ne peut pas etre comparee a Mlle Fairfax.

eng: "Oh! no. You are very obliging to say such things--but certainly not. There is no comparison between them. Miss Campbell always was absolutely plain--but extremely elegant and amiable."
fr: '-- Oh non. Vous etes bien bonne de parler de Jane en termes si flatteurs, mais en verite il ne peut y avoir de comparaison entre elles. Mlle Campbell a toujours ete laide, mais extremement elegante et aimable.

eng: "Yes, that of course."
fr: '-- Oui, naturellement.

eng: "Jane caught a bad cold, poor thing! so long ago as the 7th of November, (as I am going to read to you,) and has never been well since. A long time, is not it, for a cold to hang upon her? She never mentioned it before, because she would not alarm us. Just like her! so considerate!--But however, she is so far from well, that her kind friends the Campbells think she had better come home, and try an air that always agrees with her; and they have no doubt that three or four months at Highbury will entirely cure her--and it is certainly a great deal better that she should come here, than go to Ireland, if she is unwell. Nobody could nurse her, as we should do."
fr: '-- Jane a attrape un mauvais rhume, pauvre enfant, au mois de novembre dernier, et elle n'a jamais ete bien depuis ; elle n'y avait jamais fait allusion pour ne pas nous tourmenter. Je reconnais sa delicatesse habituelle ! Nous pensons que trois ou quatre mois d'Highbury la remettront entierement ; personne ne pourrait la soigner comme nous le faisons.

eng: "It appears to me the most desirable arrangement in the world."
fr: '-- Il me semble que cet arrangement est parfait a tous les points de vue.

eng: "And so she is to come to us next Friday or Saturday, and the Campbells leave town in their way to Holyhead the Monday following--as you will find from Jane's letter. So sudden!--You may guess, dear Miss Woodhouse, what a flurry it has thrown me in! If it was not for the drawback of her illness--but I am afraid we must expect to see her grown thin, and looking very poorly."
fr: '-- Elle arrivera vendredi ou samedi et les Campbell quittent la ville pour aller a Holyhead le lundi suivant comme vous le verrez dans la lettre de Jane. Vous pouvez comprendre, chere Mademoiselle Woodhouse, dans quelle agitation cette nouvelle inopinee m'a jetee ! Il faut nous attendre a lui trouver mauvaise mine.

eng: "I must tell you what an unlucky thing happened to me, as to that. I always make a point of reading Jane's letters through to myself first, before I read them aloud to my mother, you know, for fear of there being any thing in them to distress her.'
fr: 'Il faut que je vous raconte ce qui m'est arrive de malheureux a ce propos : j'ai toujours soin de parcourir les lettres de Jane avant de les lire a ma mere de crainte qu'il n'y ait quelque chose qui puisse l'attrister.'

eng: "Well, now I have just given you a hint of what Jane writes about, we will turn to her letter, and I am sure she tells her own story a great deal better than I can tell it for her."
fr: 'Eh bien, maintenant que je vous ai donne une idee sommaire de la lettre de Jane, je vais vous la lire, ce qui sera beaucoup plus interessant.'

eng: "I am afraid we must be running away," said Emma, glancing at Harriet, and beginning to rise--"My father will be expecting us.
fr: 'Je crains que nous ne soyons forcees de nous sauver, dit Emma en jetant un coup d'oeil a Harriet et en se levant, mon pere nous attend ;'

eng: I had no intention, I thought I had no power of staying more than five minutes, when I first entered the house.
fr: 'je n'avais pas l'intention, je ne pensais meme pas avoir la possibilite de rester plus de cinq minutes. Je suis entree parce que je n'ai pas voulu passer votre porte sans prendre des nouvelles de Mme Bates,'

eng: I merely called, because I would not pass the door without inquiring after Mrs. Bates; but I have been so pleasantly detained!
fr: 'mais le temps a passe si agreablement que j'ai oublie ma resolution.'

eng: "Now, however, we must wish you and Mrs. Bates good morning."
fr: 'Il nous faut pourtant vous dire au revoir, a vous et a Mme Bates.'

eng: And not all that could be urged to detain her succeeded.
fr: 'Malgre les plus vives instances, Mlle Bates ne parvint pas a retenir Emma ;'

eng: She regained the street--happy in this, that though much had been forced on her against her will, though she had in fact heard the whole substance of Jane Fairfax's letter, she had been able to escape the letter itself.
fr: 'celle-ci, une fois dehors, ne dissimula pas sa satisfaction d'avoir echappe, a la lecture in extenso de la lettre prealablement resumee !'

eng: By birth she belonged to Highbury: and when at three years old, on losing her mother, she became the property, the charge, the consolation, the foundling of her grandmother and aunt, there had seemed every probability of her being permanently fixed there;
fr: La petite Jane avait trois ans quand elle perdit sa mere ; elle devint la consolation de sa grand'mere et de sa tante et tout semblait presager qu'elle etait fixee a Highbury pour la vie ;

eng: of her being taught only what very limited means could command, and growing up with no advantages of connexion or improvement, to be engrafted on what nature had given her in a pleasing person, good understanding, and warm-hearted, well-meaning relations.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: But the compassionate feelings of a friend of her father gave a change to her destiny.
fr: mais l'intervention d'un ami de son pere modifia sa destinee ;

eng: This was Colonel Campbell, who had very highly regarded Fairfax, as an excellent officer and most deserving young man;
fr: le colonel Campbell tenait en grande estime le lieutenant Fairfax et, de plus, il considerait devoir la vie aux soins dont son compagnon d'armes l'avait entoure pendant les acces d'une fievre contractee au cours d'une campagne.

eng: and farther, had been indebted to him for such attentions, during a severe camp-fever, as he believed had saved his life.
fr: Il demeura fidele a la memoire de son ami et, bien que plusieurs annees se fussent ecoulees entre la mort du pauvre Fairfax et le retour du colonel en Angleterre, sa reconnaissance n'en fut pas affaiblie :

eng: These were claims which he did not learn to overlook, though some years passed away from the death of poor Fairfax, before his own return to England put any thing in his power.
fr: des son arrivee, il s'occupa de rechercher l'enfant et s'interessa a elle.

eng: When he did return, he sought out the child and took notice of her.
fr: Le colonel etait marie et avait une fille a peu pres de l'age de Jane ;

eng: He was a married man, with only one living child, a girl, about Jane's age: and Jane became their guest, paying them long visits and growing a favourite with all;
fr: cette derniere fut invitee a venir passer de longs mois chez les Campbell ; elle etait jolie et intelligente et fut prise en affection par toute la famille ;

eng: and before she was nine years old, his daughter's great fondness for her, and his own wish of being a real friend, united to produce an offer from Colonel Campbell of undertaking the whole charge of her education.
fr: quand Jane eut neuf ans, la grande tendresse que leur fille manifestait pour sa petite compagne et en meme temps leur desir de se montrer de veritables amis amenerent le colonel et Mme Campbell a proposer de prendre la charge entiere de l'enfant.

eng: The affection of the whole family, the warm attachment of Miss Campbell in particular, was the more honourable to each party from the circumstance of Jane's decided superiority both in beauty and acquirements.
fr: L'affection de toute la famille et en particulier la tendresse de Miss Campbell faisait d'autant plus honneur aux deux parties que la superiorite de Jane tant par la beaute que par les dons intellectuels etait evidente.

eng: That nature had given it in feature could not be unseen by the young woman, nor could her higher powers of mind be unfelt by the parents.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They continued together with unabated regard however, till the marriage of Miss Campbell, who by that chance, that luck which so often defies anticipation in matrimonial affairs, giving attraction to what is moderate rather than to what is superior, engaged the affections of Mr. Dixon, a young man, rich and agreeable, almost as soon as they were acquainted; and was eligibly and happily settled, while Jane Fairfax had yet her bread to earn.
fr: Neanmoins leur intimite demeura aussi etroite jusqu'au mariage de Mlle Campbell ; celle-ci attira l'affection d'un jeune homme riche et agreable, M. Dixon, peu apres avoir fait sa connaissance ; elle fut demandee en mariage sans delai et se trouva heureusement etablie tandis que Jane Fairfax, restait, malgre son charme incontestable, avec la seule perspective d'avoir a gagner sa vie.

eng: This event had very lately taken place; too lately for any thing to be yet attempted by her less fortunate friend towards entering on her path of duty; though she had now reached the age which her own judgment had fixed on for beginning.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She had long resolved that one-and-twenty should be the period.
fr: Jane avait resolu qu'a l'age de vingt et un ans une nouvelle periode commencerait pour elle :

eng: With the fortitude of a devoted novitiate, she had resolved at one-and-twenty to complete the sacrifice, and retire from all the pleasures of life, of rational intercourse, equal society, peace and hope, to penance and mortification for ever.
fr: elle accomplirait le sacrifice complet pour lequel elle se preparait depuis longtemps, elle renoncerait aux plaisirs de la vie, aux satisfactions du monde pour accepter le joug de sa nouvelle existence.

eng: The good sense of Colonel and Mrs. Campbell could not oppose such a resolution, though their feelings did.
fr: Le bon sens du colonel et de Mme Campbell ne pouvait pas s'opposer a cette resolution qui leur etait pourtant penible.

eng: Perhaps they began to feel it might have been kinder and wiser to have resisted the temptation of any delay, and spared her from a taste of such enjoyments of ease and leisure as must now be relinquished.
fr: Peut-etre meme commencaient-ils a sentir qu'ils auraient mieux fait d'epargner a la jeune fille l'occasion de prendre gout a une vie de loisirs a laquelle elle devait renoncer aujourd'hui.

eng: Still, however, affection was glad to catch at any reasonable excuse for not hurrying on the wretched moment.
fr: Neanmoins, ils furent heureux de se raccrocher a une excuse raisonnable pour prolonger de quelques mois la bienfaisante treve ;

eng: She had never been quite well since the time of their daughter's marriage; and till she should have completely recovered her usual strength, they must forbid her engaging in duties, which, so far from being compatible with a weakened frame and varying spirits, seemed, under the most favourable circumstances, to require something more than human perfection of body and mind to be discharged with tolerable comfort.
fr: Jane n'avait jamais ete tout a fait bien portante depuis le mariage de leur fille et, en consequence ils declarerent s'opposer a ce qu'elle assumat de nouveaux devoirs tant qu'elle n'aurait pas retrouve toutes ses forces.

eng: "But "she could never get acquainted with her: she did not know how it was, but there was such coldness and reserve--such apparent indifference whether she pleased or not--and then, her aunt was such an eternal talker!--and she was made such a fuss with by every body!--and it had been always imagined that they were to be so intimate--because their ages were the same, every body had supposed they must be so fond of each other."
fr: 'Il lui avait toujours ete impossible d'arriver avec Jane a des relations d'intimite ; elle s'etonnait de trouver chez la jeune fille une sorte de froideur, une reserve qui pouvait a bon droit passer pour de l'indifference ; un autre de ses griefs contre Jane etait le bavardage eternel de Mlle Bates !'

eng: "These were her reasons--she had no better."
fr: 'Elle n'avait pas de meilleures raisons a invoquer.'

eng: "It was a dislike so little just--every imputed fault was so magnified by fancy, that she never saw Jane Fairfax the first time after any considerable absence, without feeling that she had injured her;"
fr: 'En realite, cette antipathie etait si injustifiee qu'elle ne revoyait jamais Jane Fairfax, apres une longue absence, sans se rendre compte qu'elle l'avait mal jugee.'

eng: "and now, when the due visit was paid, on her arrival, after a two years' interval, she was particularly struck with the very appearance and manners, which for those two whole years she had been depreciating."
fr: 'Ce fut precisement l'impression qu'elle ressentit lors de la premiere visite qu'elle fit aux Bates apres l'arrivee de Jane Fairfax. Emma fut particulierement frappee par l'apparence et les manieres de celle qu'elle s'ingeniait a deprecier depuis deux ans.'

eng: "Jane Fairfax was very elegant, remarkably elegant; and she had herself the highest value for elegance."
fr: 'La taille de Jane Fairfax etait au-dessus de la moyenne, sa tournure particulierement gracieuse ; elle etait parfaitement proportionnee.'

eng: "Her height was pretty, just such as almost every body would think tall, and nobody could think very tall; her figure particularly graceful; her size a most becoming medium, between fat and thin, though a slight appearance of ill-health seemed to point out the likeliest evil of the two."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Emma could not but feel all this; and then, her face--her features--there was more beauty in them altogether than she had remembered; it was not regular, but it was very pleasing beauty."
fr: 'Emma dut reconnaitre que les traits du visage etaient plus parfaits chez l'original que dans sa memoire ; on ne pouvait nier la beaute des grands yeux gris ombres de longs cils ; et meme le teint, dont elle se complaisait a souligner la paleur, avait acquis une fraicheur et un eclat que rehaussait la delicatesse de l'epiderme.'

eng: "Her eyes, a deep grey, with dark eye-lashes and eyebrows, had never been denied their praise; but the skin, which she had been used to cavil at, as wanting colour, had a clearness and delicacy which really needed no fuller bloom."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: In short, she sat, during the first visit, looking at Jane Fairfax with twofold complacency; the sense of pleasure and the sense of rendering justice, and was determining that she would dislike her no longer.
fr: En somme, pendant cette premiere visite chez les Bates elle ne cessa de regarder Jane avec complaisance ; outre le plaisir des yeux, elle eprouvait la satisfaction de reparer son injustice, et elle resolut de ne plus se laisser aller a son antipathie irraisonnee.

eng: When she took in her history, indeed, her situation, as well as her beauty; when she considered what all this elegance was destined to, what she was going to sink from, how she was going to live, it seemed impossible to feel any thing but compassion and respect; especially, if to every well-known particular entitling her to interest, were added the highly probable circumstance of an attachment to Mr. Dixon, which she had so naturally started to herself.
fr: Elle ne pouvait s'empecher de ressentir du respect et de la compassion en considerant le sort qui etait reserve a tant de beaute et d'elegance.

eng: In that case, nothing could be more pitiable or more honourable than the sacrifices she had resolved on.
fr: Dans ce cas, elle jugeait que rien ne pouvait etre plus honorable que le sacrifice auquel la jeune fille s'etait resolue ;

eng: Emma was very willing now to acquit her of having seduced Mr. Dixon's actions from his wife, or of any thing mischievous which her imagination had suggested at first.
fr: Emma n'hesita pas a renoncer a l'idee de seduction vis-a-vis de M. Dixon que son imagination lui avait tout d'abord suggeree ;

eng: If it were love, it might be simple, single, successless love on her side alone.
fr: il lui paraissait probable maintenant que cet amour n'etait pas partage.

eng: She might have been unconsciously sucking in the sad poison, while a sharer of his conversation with her friend; and from the best, the purest of motives, might now be denying herself this visit to Ireland, and resolving to divide herself effectually from him and his connexions by soon beginning her career of laborious duty.
fr: et afin de se separer definitivement de lui et de toute la famille, qu'elle avait decide de commencer sans nouveau delai sa carriere de devoirs.

eng: There, not to be vulgar, was distinction, and merit.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: These were charming feelings--but not lasting.
fr: Ces charmantes dispositions ne furent point de longue duree.

eng: Before she had committed herself by any public profession of eternal friendship for Jane Fairfax, or done more towards a recantation of past prejudices and errors, than saying to Mr. Knightley, "She certainly is handsome; she is better than handsome!"
fr: En effet, avant qu'Emma ne se fut publiquement compromise par une protestation d'amitie pour Jane Fairfax, qu'elle n'eut fait amende honorable et retracte ses anciens prejuges d'une facon plus explicite qu'en disant a M. Knightley << elle est certainement tres belle >> ;

eng: Jane had spent an evening at Hartfield with her grandmother and aunt, and every thing was relapsing much into its usual state.
fr: ses sentiments s'etaient de nouveau modifies : Jane etait venue passer une soiree a Hartfield avec sa grand-mere et sa tante.

eng: Former provocations reappeared.
fr: Emma avait pu constater que les causes d'agacement subsistaient toujours.

eng: The aunt was as tiresome as ever; more tiresome, because anxiety for her health was now added to admiration of her powers; and they had to listen to the description of exactly how little bread and butter she ate for breakfast, and how small a slice of mutton for dinner, as well as to see exhibitions of new caps and new workbags for her mother and herself; and Jane's offences rose again.
fr: La tante etait aussi ennuyeuse que d'habitude, plus meme, car a son admiration pour les facultes de Jane venait s'ajouter maintenant l'anxiete pour la sante de sa niece ; ils eurent a subir l'evaluation de l'exacte quantite de pain et de beurre que Jane mangeait a dejeuner, de la petite tranche de mouton qu'elle pouvait supporter a diner ; il fallut examiner les nouveaux bonnets et les sacs a ouvrage que Jane avait confectionnes pour ses parentes !

eng: They had music; Emma was obliged to play; and the thanks and praise which necessarily followed appeared to her an affectation of candour, an air of greatness, meaning only to shew off in higher style her own very superior performance.
fr: On fit de la musique : Emma fut forcee de s'asseoir la premiere au piano et elle eut l'impression que les remerciements et les compliments de rigueur n'etaient pas absolument depourvus d'une certaine affectation de modestie tres apte a mettre en valeur le jeu impeccable de sa rivale.

eng: She was, besides, which was the worst of all, so cold, so cautious!
fr: De plus, et c'etait le point capital, Jane se montrait si froide, si reservee !

eng: There was no getting at her real opinion.
fr: Il n'y avait pas moyen de connaitre sa veritable opinion :

eng: Wrapt up in a cloak of politeness, she seemed determined to hazard nothing.
fr: enveloppee d'un manteau de politesse, elle se tenait sur une sorte de defensive qui autorisait tous les soupcons.

eng: She was disgustingly, was suspiciously reserved.
fr: Il semblait que Jane affectat une reserve particuliere au sujet de Weymouth et des Dixon ;

eng: If any thing could be more, where all was most, she was more reserved on the subject of Weymouth and the Dixons than any thing.
fr: elle etait absolument impenetrable sur le caractere de M. Dixon et sur les avantages de ce mariage.

eng: She seemed bent on giving no real insight into Mr. Dixon's character, or her own value for his company, or opinion of the suitableness of the match.
fr: Ce n'etait qu'approbations vagues, sans un detail precis.

eng: It was all general approbation and smoothness; nothing delineated or distinguished.
fr: Toute sa prudence ne lui servit de rien.

eng: It did her no service however.
fr: Emma en devina l'artifice et revint a sa premiere idee :

eng: Her caution was thrown away.
fr: Qui sait si M. Dixon n'avait pas ete bien pres de remplacer une amie par l'autre !

eng: Emma saw its artifice, and returned to her first surmises.
fr: La meme reserve, du reste, s'etendait a tous les sujets :

eng: There probably _was_ something more to conceal than her own preference; Mr. Dixon, perhaps, had been very near changing one friend for the other, or been fixed only to Miss Campbell, for the sake of the future twelve thousand pounds.
fr: Jane s'etait trouvee a Weymouth en meme temps que M. Frank Churchill ; on apprit qu'ils avaient fait connaissance, mais il fut impossible a Emma d'obtenir un mot d'information sur le caractere du jeune homme.

eng: The like reserve prevailed on other topics.
fr: Etait-il bien physiquement ? -- Elle croyait que l'opinion generale s'accordait a le trouver bien. -- Etait-il aimable ? -- On le jugeait generalement de manieres agreables. -- Est-ce qu'il paraissait intelligent, cultive ? -- A la suite d'une frequentation dans une ville d'eau ou de rencontres peu frequentes a Londres, il etait bien difficile de porter un jugement de ce genre. Il n'y avait guere que les manieres qu'on put se permettre d'apprecier dans ces conditions.

eng: She and Mr. Frank Churchill had been at Weymouth at the same time.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It was known that they were a little acquainted; but not a syllable of real information could Emma procure as to what he truly was.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Was he handsome?" --"She believed he was reckoned a very fine young man." "Was he agreeable?" --"He was generally thought so." "Did he appear a sensible young man; a young man of information?" --"At a watering-place, or in a common London acquaintance, it was difficult to decide on such points. Manners were all that could be safely judged of, under a much longer knowledge than they had yet had of Mr. Churchill. She believed every body found his manners pleasing."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Emma could not forgive her.
fr: Emma ne pardonna pas a Jane Fairfax ces diverses reticences diplomatiques.

eng: Emma could not forgive her;--but as neither provocation nor resentment were discerned by Mr. Knightley, who had been of the party, and had seen only proper attention and pleasing behaviour on each side, he was expressing the next morning, being at Hartfield again on business with Mr. Woodhouse, his approbation of the whole; not so openly as he might have done had her father been out of the room, but speaking plain enough to be very intelligible to Emma.
fr: XXI M. Knightley qui avait passe la soiree a Hartfield avec les Bates ne s'etait pas rendu compte des nouveaux griefs que Jane Fairfax avait fournis a Emma ; il n'avait vu que les gracieuses attentions du debut et le lendemain matin, venu pour causer affaires avec M. Woodhouse, il s'empressa de manifester son approbation ; a cause de la presence de M. Woodhouse il ne pouvait parler aussi librement qu'il l'eut fait a d'autres moments, mais Emma saisissait fort bien les intentions de son interlocuteur.

eng: "A very pleasant evening," he began, as soon as Mr. Woodhouse had been talked into what was necessary, told that he understood, and the papers swept away;--"particularly pleasant.
fr: 'Des que M. Woodhouse eut ete mis au courant de l'affaire au sujet de laquelle son voisin venait l'entretenir, les papiers furent mis de cote et M. Knightley s'adressa a Emma : -- Ce fut une agreable soiree, Emma ;

eng: You and Miss Fairfax gave us some very good music.
fr: vous et Mlle Fairfax vous nous avez fait d'excellente musique.

eng: I do not know a more luxurious state, sir, than sitting at one's ease to be entertained a whole evening by two such young women; sometimes with music and sometimes with conversation.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I am sure Miss Fairfax must have found the evening pleasant, Emma.
fr: Je suis sur que Mlle Fairfax a ete contente de sa visite ;

eng: You left nothing undone.
fr: rien ne manquait pour le plaisir de tous.

eng: I was glad you made her play so much, for having no instrument at her grandmother's, it must have been a real indulgence."
fr: Vous avez bien fait de la laisser jouer assez longtemps, car elle n'a pas de piano chez sa grand'mere et cette occasion a du etre pour elle une vraie fete. --

eng: "I am happy you approved," said Emma, smiling; "but I hope I am not often deficient in what is due to guests at Hartfield."
fr: -- Je me rejouis de votre approbation, dit Emma en souriant, mais j'espere que je suis rarement en defaut quand il s'agit d'accueillir mes hotes a Hartfield. --

eng: "No, my dear," said her father instantly; "_that_ I am sure you are not.
fr: -- Non, ma chere, repondit vivement son pere, ce n'est jamais le cas ;

eng: There is nobody half so attentive and civil as you are.
fr: personne ne fait preuve d'autant de bonne grace que vous.

eng: If any thing, you are too attentive.
fr: Si j'avais un reproche a vous faire, c'est d'exagerer parfois les attentions ;

eng: The muffin last night--if it had been handed round once, I think it would have been enough."
fr: par exemple, hier soir, il aurait ete plus sage de n'offrir qu'une fois des muffins. --

eng: "No," said Mr. Knightley, nearly at the same time; "you are not often deficient; not often deficient either in manner or comprehension.
fr: C'est vrai, ajouta M. Knightley presque au meme instant, vous etes rarement en defaut.

eng: I think you understand me, therefore."
fr: Je pense que vous me comprenez.

eng: An arch look expressed--"I understand you well enough;"
fr: Le regard disait : << Je vous comprends fort bien >>,

eng: but she said only, "Miss Fairfax is reserved."
fr: mais elle repondit seulement : -- Mlle Fairfax est reservee. --

eng: "I always told you she was--a little; but you will soon overcome all that part of her reserve which ought to be overcome, all that has its foundation in diffidence.
fr: Je vous ai toujours dit qu'elle l'etait un peu, mais vous aurez vite fait de dissiper cette gene et cette excessive discretion. --

eng: What arises from discretion must be honoured."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "You think her diffident. I do not see it."
fr: Vous croyez donc qu'elle manque de confiance en elle-meme ? Ce n'est pas mon avis. --

eng: "My dear Emma," said he, moving from his chair into one close by her, "you are not going to tell me, I hope, that you had not a pleasant evening."
fr: Ma chere Emma, dit-il en s'asseyant sur une chaise plus proche d'elle. ~~~ Vous n'allez pas me dire, j'espere, que vous n'avez pas passe une agreable soiree. --

eng: "Oh! no; I was pleased with my own perseverance in asking questions; and amused to think how little information I obtained."
fr: -- Oh non ; j'ai ete satisfaite de ma perseverance a poser des questions et amusee du peu de profit que j'en ai tire.

eng: "I hope every body had a pleasant evening," said Mr. Woodhouse, in his quiet way.
fr: '-- J'espere que tout le monde a passe une bonne soiree, dit M. Woodhouse de sa voix la plus douce.

eng: "I had. Once, I felt the fire rather too much; but then I moved back my chair a little, a very little, and it did not disturb me."
fr: Il en a ete ainsi pour ma part. A un moment donne la chaleur du feu m'a legerement incommode, mais je n'ai eu qu'a reculer un peu ma chaise pour me sentir parfaitement a mon aise ;

eng: "Miss Bates was very chatty and good-humoured, as she always is, though she speaks rather too quick."
fr: Mlle Bates etait tres causante et de bonne humeur comme d'habitude : elle est toujours agreable bien qu'elle parle un peu vite ;

eng: "However, she is very agreeable, and Mrs. Bates too, in a different way."
fr: Mme Bates et egalement une excellente personne.

eng: "I like old friends; and Miss Jane Fairfax is a very pretty sort of young lady, a very pretty and a very well-behaved young lady indeed."
fr: J'aime les vieux amis. Mlle Fairfax est une tres jolie personne et parfaitement bien elevee.

eng: "She must have found the evening agreeable, Mr. Knightley, because she had Emma."
fr: Elle a du etre contente, Monsieur Knightley, puisqu'Emma etait la pour lui tenir compagnie.

eng: "True, sir; and Emma, because she had Miss Fairfax."
fr: C'est bien vrai, Monsieur ! Et Emma de son cote avait la chance d'avoir Jane Fairfax.

eng: "Emma saw his anxiety, and wishing to appease it, at least for the present, said, and with a sincerity which no one could question--"
fr: Emma vit l'anxiete de son pere et pour l'apaiser elle dit avec une sincerite evidente :

eng: ""She is a sort of elegant creature that one cannot keep one's eyes from. I am always watching her to admire; and I do pity her from my heart.""
fr: -- C'est une creature si elegante qu'il est impossible de ne pas prendre plaisir a la regarder. Je l'admire sans cesse et je la plains de tout mon coeur.

eng: "Mr. Knightley looked as if he were more gratified than he cared to express; and before he could make any reply, Mr. Woodhouse, whose thoughts were on the Bates's, said--"
fr: M. Knightley hesita un instant ; il ne trouvait pas de mots pour exprimer sa satisfaction et, avant qu'il eut pu repondre, M. Woodhouse dont la pensee etait occupee par les Bates reprit :

eng: ""It is a great pity that their circumstances should be so confined! a great pity indeed! and I have often wished--but it is so little one can venture to do--small, trifling presents, of any thing uncommon--Now we have killed a porker, and Emma thinks of sending them a loin or a leg; it is very small and delicate--Hartfield pork is not like any other pork--but still it is pork--and, my dear Emma, unless one could be sure of their making it into steaks, nicely fried, as ours are fried, without the smallest grease, and not roast it, for no stomach can bear roast pork--I think we had better send the leg--do not you think so, my dear?""
fr: -- C'est un grand malheur que leurs moyens soient si restreints, un grand malheur ! Et j'ai souvent eu le desir... mais on ne peut se permettre que des petits presents insignifiants. Nous avons tue un porc et Emma a l'intention de leur envoyer une longe ou un jambon. Il est tres petit et delicat (le porc d'Hartfield ne ressemble a aucun autre) mais pourtant c'est du porc et, ma chere Emma, a moins que vous ne soyiez sure qu'elles sachent l'accommoder en cotelettes bien grillees sans l'ombre de graisse, comme les notres, et qu'il n'y ait pas de danger qu'elles le fassent rotir, car aucun estomac ne peut supporter le porc roti, je crois que vous feriez mieux d'envoyer le jambon. N'est-ce pas votre avis, ma chere ?

eng: ""My dear papa, I sent the whole hind-quarter. I knew you would wish it."
fr: -- Mon cher papa, j'ai envoye tout l'arriere-train ; j'ai pense que vous m'approuveriez ;

eng: "There will be the leg to be salted, you know, which is so very nice, and the loin to be dressed directly in any manner they like."
fr: il y aura le jambon qui est excellent et la longe qu'elles pourront preparer a leur guise.

eng: ""That's right, my dear, very right. I had not thought of it before, but that is the best way. They must not over-salt the leg; and then, if it is not over-salted, and if it is very thoroughly boiled, just as Serle boils ours, and eaten very moderately of, with a boiled turnip, and a little carrot or parsnip, I do not consider it unwholesome.""
fr: -- Tres bien, ma chere, vous ne pouviez mieux faire. Surtout qu'elles ne salent pas le jambon exagerement ; s'il n'est pas trop sale et s'il est cuit a point, comme Serle nous le cuit, et pourvu qu'on en mange avec moderation, je ne considere point cet aliment comme malsain.

eng: ""Emma," said Mr. Knightley presently, "I have a piece of news for you. You like news--and I heard an article in my way hither that I think will interest you.""
fr: -- Emma, dit M. Knightley, j'ai une nouvelle a vous annoncer. Vous aimez les nouvelles et je viens d'apprendre un evenement qui, je crois, vous interessera.

eng: ""News! Oh! yes, I always like news. What is it?--why do you smile so?--where did you hear it?--at Randalls?""
fr: -- Oh ! oui, j'aime les nouvelles. Qu'est-ce que c'est ? ~~~ Pourquoi souriez-vous ? Est-ce a Randalls que vous l'avez apprise ?

eng: "He had time only to say, "No, not at Randalls; I have not been near Randalls," when the door was thrown open, and Miss Bates and Miss Fairfax walked into the room."
fr: Il n'eut que le temps de repondre : -- Non, je n'ai pas ete a Randalls. Quand la porte s'ouvrit, Mlle Bates et Mlle Fairfax firent leur entree.

eng: "Full of thanks, and full of news, Miss Bates knew not which to give quickest."
fr: M. Knightley se rendit compte immediatement qu'il avait manque l'occasion et qu'il ne lui serait pas possible de continuer sa communication. Mlle Bates debordait de reconnaissance et en meme temps elle brulait de faire part a ses amis d'une nouvelle qu'elle detenait ; elle ne savait par ou commencer.

eng: ""Oh! my dear sir, how are you this morning? My dear Miss Woodhouse--I come quite over-powered. Such a beautiful hind-quarter of pork! You are too bountiful! Have you heard the news?""
fr: -- Cher Monsieur, comment allez-vous ce matin ? Ma chere Mademoiselle Woodhouse, je suis confuse ; un si magnifique arriere-train de porc ! Vous etes trop genereuse ! Connaissez-vous la nouvelle ?'

eng: 'Emma had not had time even to think of Mr. Elton, and she was so completely surprized that she could not avoid a little start, and a little blush, at the sound.'
fr: 'Emma etait si loin de penser a M. Elton qu'elle fut toute surprise et ne put s'empecher de sursauter et de rougir legerement en entendant prononcer ce nom.'

eng: '"There is my news:--I thought it would interest you," said Mr. Knightley, with a smile which implied a conviction of some part of what had passed between them.'
fr: '-- C'etait precisement la nouvelle que j'allais vous annoncer, dit M. Knightley.'

eng: '"But where could _you_ hear it?"'
fr: '-- Mais ou avez-vous pu en avoir connaissance ?'

eng: "Where could you possibly hear it, Mr. Knightley?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "For it is not five minutes since I received Mrs. Cole's note--no, it cannot be more than five--or at least ten--for I had got my bonnet and spencer on, just ready to come out"
fr: "-- Il n'y a pas plus de cinq minutes, que j'ai recu la lettre de Mme Cole, non il ne peut pas y avoir plus de cinq ou dix minutes ; j'avais mon chapeau et mon manteau et j'etais prete a sortir"
