How would he bear to have Miss Bates belonging to him?--To have her haunting the Abbey, and thanking him all day long for his great kindness in marrying Jane?--'So very kind and obliging!--But he always had been such a very kind neighbour!' And then fly off, through half a sentence, to her mother's old petticoat. 'Not that it was such a very old petticoat either--for still it would last a great while--and, indeed, she must thankfully say that their petticoats were all very strong.'"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "For shame, Emma! Do not mimic her. You divert me against my conscience. And, upon my word, I do not think Mr. Knightley would be much disturbed by Miss Bates.'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The interest he takes in her--his anxiety about her health--his concern that she should have no happier prospect!
fr: Son anxiete, concernant la sante et l'avenir de la jeune fille, indiquent clairement tout l'interet qu'il lui porte.

eng: I have heard him express himself so warmly on those points!--Such an admirer of her performance on the pianoforte, and of her voice!
fr: C'est un grand admirateur du talent de Mlle Fairfax : il m'a souvent dit qu'il ne se lasserait jamais de l'entendre chanter.

eng: I have heard him say that he could listen to her for ever.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Oh! and I had almost forgotten one idea that occurred to me--this pianoforte that has been sent here by somebody--though we have all been so well satisfied to consider it a present from the Campbells, may it not be from Mr. Knightley?
fr: Oh ! j'allais oublier une autre idee. Le piano anonyme, benevolement attribue aux Campbell ne peut-il pas etre un cadeau de M. Knightley ?

eng: I cannot help suspecting him.
fr: Je ne puis m'empecher de le soupconner.

eng: I think he is just the person to do it, even without being in love."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: ~~~ "Then it can be no argument to prove that he is in love.
fr: -- M. Knightley ne fait rien mysterieusement.

eng: But I do not think it is at all a likely thing for him to do.
fr: -- Je l'ai entendu plusieurs fois exprimer son regret que Jane n'eut pas un piano.

eng: Mr. Knightley does nothing mysteriously."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I have heard him lamenting her having no instrument repeatedly; oftener than I should suppose such a circumstance would, in the common course of things, occur to him."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Very well; and if he had intended to give her one, he would have told her so."
fr: -- C'est possible, mais s'il avait eu l'intention de lui faire ce cadeau, il le lui aurait dit.

eng: "There might be scruples of delicacy, my dear Emma.
fr: -- Il peut avoir eu des scrupules de delicatesse.

eng: I have a very strong notion that it comes from him.
fr: Il me semble me rappeler qu'il s'est montre particulierement silencieux et reserve pendant le recit de Mme Cole.

eng: I am sure he was particularly silent when Mrs. Cole told us of it at dinner."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "You take up an idea, Mrs. Weston, and run away with it; as you have many a time reproached me with doing.
fr: -- Vous vous emparez d'une idee, ma chere madame Weston, et vous vous echappez avec comme vous me l'avez bien souvent reproche.

eng: I see no sign of attachment--I believe nothing of the pianoforte--and proof only shall convince me that Mr. Knightley has any thought of marrying Jane Fairfax."
fr: Je ne distingue aucun signe d'attachement ; je ne crois pas au cadeau et l'evidence seule pourra me faire admettre que M. Knightley ait l'intention d'epouser Jane Fairfax.

eng: They combated the point some time longer in the same way; Emma rather gaining ground over the mind of her friend; for Mrs. Weston was the most used of the two to yield;
fr: Peu a peu, Emma gagnait du terrain ; Mme Weston avait l'habitude de ceder dans leurs discussions.

eng: till a little bustle in the room shewed them that tea was over, and the instrument in preparation;--and at the same moment Mr. Cole approaching to entreat Miss Woodhouse would do them the honour of trying it.
fr: A ce moment, il se fit dans le salon un leger brouhaha : on venait, en effet, d'enlever la table a the et on preparait le piano. M. Cole s'approcha pour prier Mlle Woodhouse de leur faire l'honneur d'essayer le nouvel instrument.

eng: Frank Churchill, of whom, in the eagerness of her conversation with Mrs. Weston, she had been seeing nothing, except that he had found a seat by Miss Fairfax, followed Mr. Cole, to add his very pressing entreaties;
fr: Frank Churchill, dont on ne s'etait plus occupe pendant sa conversation animee avec Mme Weston et qui avait pris une chaise aupres de Mlle Fairfax, s'approcha a son tour et joignit ses instances a celles de M. Cole.

eng: and as, in every respect, it suited Emma best to lead, she gave a very proper compliance.
fr: Comme a tous les points de vue, Emma preferait commencer, elle accepta sans difficulte.

eng: She knew the limitations of her own powers too well to attempt more than she could perform with credit; she wanted neither taste nor spirit in the little things which are generally acceptable, and could accompany her own voice well.
fr: Elle connaissait trop bien elle-meme les limites de son talent pour tenter plus qu'elle ne pouvait accomplir avec succes ; elle ne manquait pas de gout dans l'execution des petits morceaux generalement apprecies et elle s'accompagnait bien.

eng: One accompaniment to her song took her agreeably by surprize--a second, slightly but correctly taken by Frank Churchill.
fr: Frank Churchill lui fit la surprise de chanter un duo avec elle ;

eng: Her pardon was duly begged at the close of the song, and every thing usual followed.
fr: il s'excusa en terminant et recut les compliments d'usage.

eng: He was accused of having a delightful voice, and a perfect knowledge of music; which was properly denied; and that he knew nothing of the matter, and had no voice at all, roundly asserted.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They sang together once more; and Emma would then resign her place to Miss Fairfax, whose performance, both vocal and instrumental, she never could attempt to conceal from herself, was infinitely superior to her own.
fr: Emma insista ensuite pour ceder la place a Mlle Fairfax et elle s'assit non loin du piano. Frank Churchill donna egalement son concours a cette partie du concert.

eng: With mixed feelings, she seated herself at a little distance from the numbers round the instrument, to listen.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Frank Churchill sang again.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: ~~~ They had sung together once or twice, it appeared, at Weymouth.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: But the sight of Mr. Knightley among the most attentive, soon drew away half Emma's mind; and she fell into a train of thinking on the subject of Mrs. Weston's suspicions, to which the sweet sounds of the united voices gave only momentary interruptions.
fr: M. Knightley se tenait au premier rang des auditeurs, Emma l'apercut et des lors ne preta plus qu'une oreille distraite a la musique et au chant. Elle se prit a reflechir aux confidences de son amie ;

eng: Her objections to Mr. Knightley's marrying did not in the least subside.
fr: ses objections au mariage de M. Knightley ne diminuaient pas ;

eng: She could see nothing but evil in it.
fr: elle en voyait tous les inconvenients ;

eng: ~~~ It would be a great disappointment to Mr. John Knightley; consequently to Isabella.
fr: ce serait un grand desappointement pour M. John Knightley et par consequent pour Isabelle,

eng: ~~~ A real injury to the children--a most mortifying change, and material loss to them all;--a very great deduction from her father's daily comfort--and, as to herself, she could not at all endure the idea of Jane Fairfax at Donwell Abbey.
fr: un veritable prejudice pour les enfants, un changement des plus penibles et une perte materielle pour tous, un grand vide pour M. Woodhouse ; quant a elle-meme, elle ne pouvait pas supporter l'idee d'une Mme Knightley a laquelle tout le monde devrait ceder le pas !

eng: A Mrs. Knightley for them all to give way to!--No--Mr.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Knightley must never marry.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Little Henry must remain the heir of Donwell.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Presently Mr. Knightley looked back, and came and sat down by her.
fr: A ce moment M. Knightley se retourna et vint s'asseoir aupres d'elle.

eng: They talked at first only of the performance.
fr: Ils parlerent d'abord des qualites du jeu de Mlle Fairfax ;

eng: ~~~ His admiration was certainly very warm; yet she thought, but for Mrs. Weston, it would not have struck her.
fr: l'admiration de son interlocuteur etait certainement tres vive, mais sans les remarques de Mme Weston, Emma n'en eut sans doute pas ete frappee ;

eng: ~~~ As a sort of touchstone, however, she began to speak of his kindness in conveying the aunt and niece; and though his answer was in the spirit of cutting the matter short, she believed it to indicate only his disinclination to dwell on any kindness of his own.
fr: neanmoins en guise de pierre de touche, elle fit allusion a la bonte dont il avait fait preuve a l'egard de Mlle Bates et de Mlle Fairfax.

eng: "I often feel concern," said she, "that I dare not make our carriage more useful on such occasions.
fr: -- Je regrette souvent, dit-elle, de ne pas oser offrir notre voiture dans ces circonstances ; ce n'est pas que je n'en aie le desir ;

eng: ~~~ It is not that I am without the wish; but you know how impossible my father would deem it that James should put-to for such a purpose."
fr: mais vous savez combien mon pere verrait de difficultes a faire atteler pour cette raison.

eng: "Quite out of the question, quite out of the question," he replied;--"but you must often wish it, I am sure."
fr: -- Il ne peut en etre question, reprit-il en souriant.

eng: And he smiled with such seeming pleasure at the conviction, that she must proceed another step.
fr: Il parut tout a fait satisfait de cette bonne volonte, aussi Emma continua-t-elle :

eng: ~~~ "This present from the Campbells," said she--"this pianoforte is very kindly given."
fr: -- Ce present des Campbell est vraiment offert avec beaucoup de coeur ?...

eng: "Yes," he replied, and without the smallest apparent embarrassment.--"But they would have done better had they given her notice of it.
fr: -- Oui, repondit-il sans le moindre embarras, mais pourquoi ne pas lui en avoir donne avis ?

eng: Surprizes are foolish things.
fr: Les surprises ne signifient rien :

eng: ~~~ The pleasure is not enhanced, and the inconvenience is often considerable.'
fr: le plaisir n'est pas augmente et ces cachotteries ont de nombreux inconvenients.'

eng: From that moment, Emma could have taken her oath that Mr. Knightley had had no concern in giving the instrument.
fr: Depuis ce moment Emma demeura persuadee que M. Knightley n'etait pour rien dans l'envoi du piano,

eng: But whether he were entirely free from peculiar attachment--whether there were no actual preference--remained a little longer doubtful.
fr: mais il lui manquait encore quelques donnees pour etre fixee sur les sentiments intimes de son interlocuteur.

eng: Towards the end of Jane's second song, her voice grew thick.
fr: A la fin du second morceau, la voix de Mlle Fairfax faiblit.

eng: "That will do," said he, when it was finished, thinking aloud--"you have sung quite enough for one evening--now be quiet."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Another song, however, was soon begged for.
fr: On la pressait pourtant de continuer ;

eng: "One more;--they would not fatigue Miss Fairfax on any account, and would only ask for one more."
fr: Frank Churchill intervint pour dire : << Je crois que vous pourriez chanter ce morceau sans grande fatigue, la premiere partie est insignifiante, tout porte sur la seconde. >>

eng: And Frank Churchill was heard to say, "I think you could manage this without effort; the first part is so very trifling. The strength of the song falls on the second."
fr: (Already aligned above)

eng: Mr. Knightley grew angry.
fr: M. Knightley se facha :

eng: "That fellow," said he, indignantly, "thinks of nothing but shewing off his own voice. This must not be."
fr: -- Ce jeune homme dit-il avec indignation ne pense qu'a mettre sa voix en evidence. Mlle Fairfax a chante suffisamment pour ce soir.

eng: And touching Miss Bates, who at that moment passed near--"Miss Bates, are you mad, to let your niece sing herself hoarse in this manner?
fr: Et touchant Mlle Bates. -- Etes-vous folle de laisser votre niece se fatiguer de la sorte ?

eng: Mrs. Weston, capital in her country-dances, was seated, and beginning an irresistible waltz; and Frank Churchill, coming up with most becoming gallantry to Emma, had secured her hand, and led her up to the top.
fr: 'Mme Weston, incomparable pour la musique de danse, entama une valse irresistible ; Frank Churchill s'approchant d'Emma le plus galamment du monde l'invita et la conduisit au milieu du salon.

eng: While waiting till the other young people could pair themselves off, Emma found time, in spite of the compliments she was receiving on her voice and her taste, to look about, and see what became of Mr. Knightley.
fr: Emma trouva le temps, en depit des compliments que son partenaire lui debitait sur la maniere dont elle avait chante, d'observer Knightley ;

eng: This would be a trial. He was no dancer in general.
fr: ce dernier ne dansait pas en general et, s'il invitait Jane Fairfax, cette avance aurait une veritable signification.

eng: If he were to be very alert in engaging Jane Fairfax now, it might augur something.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: There was no immediate appearance. No; he was talking to Mrs. Cole--he was looking on unconcerned; Jane was asked by somebody else, and he was still talking to Mrs. Cole.
fr: Pour le moment, M. Knightley parlait a Mme Cole et ne paraissait prendre aucun interet a ce qui se passait autour de lui. Jane fut invitee sans qu'il y pretat attention.

eng: Emma had no longer an alarm for Henry; his interest was yet safe; and she led off the dance with genuine spirit and enjoyment.
fr: Emma interpreta cette abstention comme un presage favorable et se sentit rassuree sur l'avenir du petit Henri ; elle avait un cavalier digne d'elle et s'elanca sans arriere-pensee.

eng: Not more than five couple could be mustered; but the rarity and the suddenness of it made it very delightful, and she found herself well matched in a partner. They were a couple worth looking at.
fr: On etait parvenu a rassembler cinq couples, nombre respectable etant donne le caractere impromptu de la sauterie.

eng: Two dances, unfortunately, were all that could be allowed. It was growing late, and Miss Bates became anxious to get home, on her mother's account.
fr: Il fallut malheureusement s'arreter au bout de deux danses ; il se faisait tard et Mlle Bates commenca a etre inquiete de sa mere.

eng: After some attempts, therefore, to be permitted to begin again, they were obliged to thank Mrs. Weston, look sorrowful, and have done.
fr: Apres quelques essais infructueux pour prolonger la soiree, on dut se resigner a clore la fete.

eng: "Perhaps it is as well," said Frank Churchill, as he attended Emma to her carriage. "I must have asked Miss Fairfax, and her languid dancing would not have agreed with me, after yours."
fr: -- C'est mieux ainsi, dit Frank Churchill en mettant Emma en voiture, j'aurais ete oblige d'inviter Mlle Fairfax et sa danse languissante m'eut paru bien fade apres la votre.

eng: CHAPTER IX Emma did not repent her condescension in going to the Coles.
fr: XXVII

eng: The visit afforded her many pleasant recollections the next day; and all that she might be supposed to have lost on the side of dignified seclusion, must be amply repaid in the splendour of popularity.
fr: Emma ne regretta pas d'avoir eu la condescendance d'aller chez les Cole. Cette soiree lui laissa d'agreables souvenirs pour le lendemain, et si elle devait perdre une partie de son prestige de recluse volontaire, elle avait, en revanche, gagne une solide popularite.

eng: She must have delighted the Coles--worthy people, who deserved to be made happy!--And left a name behind her that would not soon die away.
fr: Elle savait que les Cole avaient ete ravis et elle ne doutait pas d'avoir laisse derriere elle un sillage d'admiration.

eng: Perfect happiness, even in memory, is not common; and there were two points on which she was not quite easy.
fr: Le bonheur parfait, meme en imagination, est rare. Il y avait deux points sur lesquels Emma n'etait pas parfaitement tranquille,

eng: She doubted whether she had not transgressed the duty of woman by woman, in betraying her suspicions of Jane Fairfax's feelings to Frank Churchill.
fr: elle craignait d'avoir transgresse les regles de la solidarite feminine en confiant ses soupcons sur les sentiments intimes de Jane Fairfax a Frank Churchill ;

eng: It was hardly right; but it had been so strong an idea, that it would escape her, and his submission to all that she told, was a compliment to her penetration, which made it difficult for her to be quite certain that she ought to have held her tongue.
fr: toutefois elle se sentait flattee d'avoir gagne si completement le jeune homme a ses vues et le succes la portait a se montrer indulgente pour elle-meme.

eng: The other circumstance of regret related also to Jane Fairfax; and there she had no doubt.
fr: L'autre raison de remords avait aussi rapport a Mlle Fairfax ; et cette fois, il n'y avait pas d'hesitation :

eng: She did unfeignedly and unequivocally regret the inferiority of her own playing and singing. She did most heartily grieve over the idleness of her childhood--and sat down and practised vigorously an hour and a half.
fr: elle regrettait sincerement l'inferiorite de son propre jeu et de son chant ; elle s'assit et etudia pendant deux heures serieusement.

eng: She was then interrupted by Harriet's coming in; and if Harriet's praise could have satisfied her, she might soon have been comforted. "Oh!'
fr: Elle fut interrompue par l'arrivee d'Henriette, et si les eloges de cette derniere avaient pu la satisfaire, elle eut ete tout a fait reconfortee. -- Oh !'

eng: "Don't class us together, Harriet. My playing is no more like her's, than a lamp is like sunshine."
fr: '-- Ne nous mettez pas sur le meme rang, Henriette ; mon jeu ne ressemble pas plus a celui de Jane Fairfax que la lumiere d'une lampe a celle du soleil.'

eng: "Oh! dear--I think you play the best of the two. I think you play quite as well as she does. I am sure I had much rather hear you. Every body last night said how well you played."
fr: '-- Est-ce possible ? Il me semble, au contraire, que vous jouez mieux. Tout le monde hier soir admirait votre talent.'

eng: "Those who knew any thing about it, must have felt the difference. The truth is, Harriet, that my playing is just good enough to be praised, but Jane Fairfax's is much beyond it."
fr: '-- Les gens competents ont du s'apercevoir de la difference. La verite, Henriette, c'est que mon jeu est juste assez bon pour meriter d'etre loue et que le sien est au-dessus de tout eloge.'

eng: "Well, I always shall think that you play quite as well as she does, or that if there is any difference nobody would ever find it out. Mr. Cole said how much taste you had; and Mr. Frank Churchill talked a great deal about your taste, and that he valued taste much more than execution."
fr: '-- M. Cole a dit que vous aviez tant de gout, M. Frank Churchill a egalement admire votre style et il a ajoute qu'il mettait cette qualite bien au-dessus du mecanisme.'

eng: "Ah! but Jane Fairfax has them both, Harriet."
fr: '-- Oui, mais Jane Fairfax possede les deux.'

eng: "Are you sure? I saw she had execution, but I did not know she had any taste. Nobody talked about it. And I hate Italian singing.--There is no understanding a word of it. Besides, if she does play so very well, you know, it is no more than she is obliged to do, because she will have to teach."
fr: '-- Etes-vous sure ? Je ne sais pas si elle a du gout : personne n'en a parle ; de plus, j'ai horreur d'entendre chanter en italien, on ne comprend pas un mot. D'autre part, si elle joue bien, c'est qu'aussi elle y est obligee comme professeur de musique.'

eng: "The Coxes were wondering last night whether she would get into any great family. How did you think the Coxes looked?"
fr: '-- Les Cox se demandaient hier soir si elle entrerait dans une grande famille. Comment avez-vous trouve les Cox ?'

eng: "Just as they always do--very vulgar."
fr: '-- J'ai trouve qu'ils avaient, comme d'habitude, l'air tres commun.'

eng: "They told me something," said Harriet rather hesitatingly; "but it is nothing of any consequence."
fr: '-- J'ai appris par eux une nouvelle, dit Henriette avec hesitation, du reste sans grande importance.'

eng: Emma was obliged to ask what they had told her, though fearful of its producing Mr. Elton.
fr: '-- Emma fut obligee de demander de quoi il s'agissait, tout en craignant fort une reminiscence de M. Elton.'

eng: "They told me--that Mr. Martin dined with them last Saturday."
fr: '-- M. Martin a dine avec eux samedi dernier.'

eng: "Oh!"
"He came to their father upon some business, and he asked him to stay to dinner."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Oh!"
"They talked a great deal about him, especially Anne Cox. I do not know what she meant, but she asked me if I thought I should go and stay there again next summer."
fr: '-- Anna Cox a beaucoup parle de lui ; elle m'a demande si je comptais faire un sejour chez eux l'ete prochain ; je me demande pourquoi elle m'a fait cette question.'

eng: "She meant to be impertinently curious, just as such an Anne Cox should be."
fr: '-- Elle a ete impertinente et curieuse et je n'en suis pas etonnee.'

eng: "She said he was very agreeable the day he dined there. He sat by her at dinner. Miss Nash thinks either of the Coxes would be very glad to marry him."
fr: '-- A diner, il etait parait-il, assis aupres d'elle ; Mlle Nash croit que l'une ou l'autre des Cox serait tres heureuse de l'epouser.'

eng: "Very likely.--I think they are, without exception, the most vulgar girls in Highbury."
fr: '-- C'est bien probable. Je crois que ce sont, sans comparaison, les filles les plus vulgaires d'Highbury !'

eng: Harriet had business at Ford's.--Emma thought it most prudent to go with her. Another accidental meeting with the Martins was possible, and in her present state, would be dangerous.
fr: '-- Henriette ayant a faire chez Ford, Emma crut plus prudent de l'accompagner ; elle craignait une nouvelle rencontre avec les Martin qui, dans les circonstances presentes, pouvait presenter des inconvenients.'

eng: Harriet, tempted by every thing and swayed by half a word, was always very long at a purchase; and while she was still hanging over muslins and changing her mind, Emma went to the door for amusement.--Much could not be hoped from the traffic of even the busiest part of Highbury;--Mr. Perry walking hastily by, Mr. William Cox letting himself in at the office-door, Mr. Cole's carriage-horses returning from exercise, or a stray letter-boy on an obstinate mule, were the liveliest objects she could presume to expect; and when her eyes fell only on the butcher with his tray, a tidy old woman travelling homewards from shop with her full basket, two curs quarrelling over a dirty bone, and a string of dawdling children round the baker's little bow-window eyeing the gingerbread, she knew she had no reason to complain, and was amused enough; quite enough still to stand at the door. A mind lively and at ease, can do with seeing nothing, and can see nothing that does not answer.
fr: '-- Dans les magasins, Henriette, tentee par tout ce qu'elle voyait, etait toujours tres longue a ses achats ; Emma la laissa en train de manier des mousselines et s'avanca vers la porte pour se distraire. Les premiers spectacles qui s'offrirent a ses yeux manquaient d'interet : ce fut d'abord le boucher dans sa carriole, une vieille femme proprette qui rentrait chez elle son panier plein de provisions sous le bras, deux chiens se disputant un os, un groupe d'enfants arrete devant la vitrine d'un boulanger ; mais soudain la scene s'anima et deux personnes apparurent : Mme Weston et son beau-fils.'

eng: She looked down the Randalls road. The scene enlarged; two persons appeared; Mrs. Weston and her son-in-law; they were walking into Highbury;--to Hartfield of course. They were stopping, however, in the first place at Mrs. Bates's; whose house was a little nearer Randalls than Ford's; and had all but knocked, when Emma caught their eye.--Immediately they crossed the road and came forward to her; and the agreeableness of yesterday's engagement seemed to give fresh pleasure to the present meeting.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Mrs. Weston informed her that she was going to call on the Bateses, in order to hear the new instrument. "For my companion tells me," said she, "that I absolutely promised Miss Bates last night, that I would come this morning. I was not aware of it myself. I did not know that I had fixed a day, but as he says I did, I am going now."
fr: '-- Nous allons faire une visite aux Bates, dit Mme Weston, afin d'entendre le nouvel instrument. Mon compagnon affirme que j'ai absolument promis a Mlle Bates de venir ce matin. Pour moi, je ne croyais pas avoir fixe de jour, mais je ne veux pas m'exposer a manquer de parole.'

eng: "And while Mrs. Weston pays her visit, I may be allowed, I hope," said Frank Churchill, "to join your party and wait for her at Hartfield--if you are going home."
fr: '-- Quant a moi, intervint Frank Churchill, j'espere obtenir l'autorisation de vous accompagner, Mademoiselle Woodhouse, nous attendrons Mme Weston a Hartfield, si vous rentrez.'

eng: Mrs. Weston was disappointed.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: My aunt always sends me off when she is shopping. She says I fidget her to death; and Miss Woodhouse looks as if she could almost say the same. What am I to do?
fr: Ma tante me renvoie toujours quand elle fait ses achats : elle pretend que je la tourmente et que je la gene. Mlle Woodhouse parait partager cette maniere de voir ! -- Je ne suis pas ici pour mon propre compte, j'attends Mlle Smith ;

eng: Miss Woodhouse looks as if she did not want me.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I am here on no business of my own," said Emma; "I am only waiting for my friend.
fr: Je ne suis pas ici pour mon propre compte, j'attends Mlle Smith ; elle aura sans doute bientot termine ses emplettes.

eng: She will probably have soon done, and then we shall go home. But you had better go with Mrs. Weston and hear the instrument.
fr: elle aura sans doute bientot termine ses emplettes. Mais vous feriez mieux, il me semble, d'accompagner Mme Weston et de participer a l'audition.

eng: Well--if you advise it.--But (with a smile) if Colonel Campbell should have employed a careless friend, and if it should prove to have an indifferent tone--what shall I say? I shall be no support to Mrs. Weston.
fr: Soit ! ~~~ Je suivrai votre conseil, mais, ajouta-t-il en souriant, supposons que le colonel Campbell ait charge un ami peu soigneux de la commande et que l'instrument soit mediocre. Je me trouverais dans une situation difficile. Je ne serais d'aucun secours a Mme Weston ;

eng: She might do very well by herself. A disagreeable truth would be palatable through her lips, but I am the wretchedest being in the world at a civil falsehood.
fr: elle s'en tirera tres bien toute seule. Une verite desagreable deviendrait acceptable dans sa bouche ; pour moi, je me sens incapable d'un mensonge poli.

eng: I do not believe any such thing," replied Emma.--"I am persuaded that you can be as insincere as your neighbours, when it is necessary; but there is no reason to suppose the instrument is indifferent. Quite otherwise indeed, if I understood Miss Fairfax's opinion last night.
fr: Je n'en crois rien, dit Emma, vous savez dissimuler aussi bien que votre voisin, le cas echeant. Du reste il n'y a aucune raison de prevoir cette eventualite : le piano doit etre excellent d'apres ce que m'a dit Mlle Fairfax hier soir.

eng: Do come with me," said Mrs. Weston, "if it be not very disagreeable to you.
fr: Venez donc avec moi, Frank, dit Mme Weston, nous n'avons pas besoin de rester longtemps ;

eng: It need not detain us long. We will go to Hartfield afterwards.
fr: nous irons a Hartfield ensuite.

eng: We will follow them to Hartfield.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I really wish you to call with me. It will be felt so great an attention!
fr: Je desire reellement que vous fassiez cette visite ; les Bates y seront extremement sensibles.

eng: and I always thought you meant it. He could say no more; and with the hope of Hartfield to reward him, returned with Mrs. Weston to Mrs. Bates's door.
fr: Frank Churchill n'avait plus rien a repondre ; ils se dirigerent de nouveau vers la porte de Mme Bates.

eng: Emma watched them in, and then joined Harriet at the interesting counter,--trying, with all the force of her own mind, to convince her that if she wanted plain muslin it was of no use to look at figured; and that a blue ribbon, be it ever so beautiful, would still never match her yellow pattern.
fr: Emma les regarda entrer et rejoignit ensuite Henriette qui se penchait perplexe sur le comptoir de M. Ford ; elle essaya de persuader a son amie qu'ayant besoin de mousseline unie, il etait parfaitement inutile d'examiner de la mousseline brodee et qu'un ruban bleu, malgre sa beaute, ne pourrait jamais s'appareiller a un echantillon jaune.

eng: At last it was all settled, even to the destination of the parcel. "Should I send it to Mrs. Goddard's, ma'am?" asked Mrs. Ford.--"Yes--no--yes, to Mrs. Goddard's. Only my pattern gown is at Hartfield. No, you shall send it to Hartfield, if you please. But then, Mrs. Goddard will want to see it.--And I could take the pattern gown home any day. But I shall want the ribbon directly--so it had better go to Hartfield--at least the ribbon. You could make it into two parcels, Mrs. Ford, could not you?"
fr: Cette intervention eut pour resultat de mettre un terme aux pourparlers. -- Devrai-je envoyer le paquet chez Mme Goddard ? demanda Mme Ford. -- Oui... non... chez Mme Goddard... ; seulement ma jupe modele est a Hartfield, envoyez-le a Hartfield, s'il vous plait. Mme Goddard, il est vrai, voudra le voir. Pourtant j'aurais besoin du ruban immediatement. Ne pourriez-vous pas faire deux paquets, Mme Ford ?

eng: It is not worth while, Harriet, to give Mrs. Ford the trouble of two parcels."
fr: A quoi bon, Henriette, donner a Mme Ford la peine de faire deux paquets ?

eng: "No more it is."
fr: -- Il n'y a pas la moindre difficulte, intervint Mme Ford obligeamment.

eng: "No trouble in the world, ma'am," said the obliging Mrs. Ford.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Oh! but indeed I would much rather have it only in one. Then, if you please, you shall send it all to Mrs. Goddard's--I do not know--No, I think, Miss Woodhouse, I may just as well have it sent to Hartfield, and take it home with me at night. What do you advise?"
fr: Je prefere, somme toute, n'avoir qu'un paquet. Donnez-moi votre avis, Mlle Woodhouse. ~~~ Ne vaut-il pas mieux le faire envoyer a Hartfield ?

eng: "That you do not give another half-second to the subject. To Hartfield, if you please, Mrs. Ford."
fr: -- N'hesitez pas une seconde de plus. A Hartfield, s'il vous plait, Mme Ford.

eng: "Aye, that will be much best," said Harriet, quite satisfied, "I should not at all like to have it sent to Mrs. Goddard's."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Voices approached the shop--or rather one voice and two ladies: Mrs. Weston and Miss Bates met them at the door. "My dear Miss Woodhouse," said the latter, "I am just run across to entreat the favour of you to come and sit down with us a little while, and give us your opinion of our new instrument; you and Miss Smith. How do you do, Miss Smith?--Very well I thank you.--And I begged Mrs. Weston to come with me, that I might be sure of succeeding.
fr: A ce moment des voix se rapprochaient ou plutot une voix et deux dames ; Mme Weston et Mlle Bates entraient dans le magasin. -- Ma chere Mlle Woodhouse, dit cette derniere, j'ai traverse la rue pour vous prier de nous faire la faveur de venir vous asseoir quelques instants a la maison afin de nous donner votre avis sur le nouvel instrument. Vous et Mlle Smith. Comment allez-vous Mlle Smith ? -- Tres bien, merci. J'ai supplie Mme Weston de m'accompagner afin d'etre sure de reussir.

eng: My mother is delightfully well; and Jane caught no cold last night.
fr: Ma mere va parfaitement et Jane n'a pas pris froid hier soir.

eng: How is Mr. Woodhouse?--I am so glad to hear such a good account.
fr: Comment se porte M. Woodhouse ?

eng: Mrs. Weston told me you were here.--Oh! then, said I, I must run across, I am sure Miss Woodhouse will allow me just to run across and entreat her to come in; my mother will be so very happy to see her--and now we are such a nice party, she cannot refuse.--
fr: J'ai appris par Mme Weston votre presence ici. ~~~ -- Oh ! alors, ai-je dit, je vais aller la trouver et lui demander d'entrer un instant ; ma mere sera si heureuse de la voir et il y a en ce moment chez nous une reunion si agreable qu'elle ne peut refuser.

eng: 'Aye, pray do,' said Mr. Frank Churchill, 'Miss Woodhouse's opinion of the instrument will be worth having.'
fr: Tout le monde approuva ma proposition. << C'est une excellente idee, dit M. Frank Churchill, l'opinion de Mlle Woodhouse sera importante a connaitre. >>

eng: But, said I, I shall be more sure of succeeding if one of you will go with me.--
fr: << Mais, dis-je, je serai plus sure de reussir si l'un de vous m'accompagne. >>

eng: 'Oh,' said he, 'wait half a minute, till I have finished my job;'
fr: << Oh ! dit-il, attendez une demi-minute, je vais avoir termine mon travail. >>

eng: --For, would you believe it, Miss Woodhouse, there he is, in the most obliging manner in the world, fastening in the rivet of my mother's spectacles.--The rivet came out, you know, this morning.--So very obliging!
fr: Car, le croiriez-vous Mlle Woodhouse, il est en ce moment occupe de la facon la plus obligeante du monde a fixer la branche des lunettes de ma mere : la vis etait tombee ce matin. On ne peut etre plus aimable !

eng: For my mother had no use of her spectacles--could not put them on.
fr: Ma mere ne savait comment faire sans ses lunettes.

eng: And, by the bye, every body ought to have two pair of spectacles; they should indeed. Jane said so.
fr: C'est une lecon : tout le monde devrait avoir deux paires de lunettes.

eng: I meant to take them over to John Saunders the first thing I did, but something or other hindered me all the morning; first one thing, then another, there is no saying what, you know.
fr: J'avais l'intention de les porter des la premiere heure chez John Sanders pour les faire reparer, mais je ne sais trop comment j'ai ete retardee toute la matinee.

eng: At one time Patty came to say she thought the kitchen chimney wanted sweeping.
fr: A un moment donne, Patty est venue dire que la cheminee de la cuisine avait besoin d'etre ramonee.

eng: Oh, said I, Patty do not come with your bad news to me. Here is the rivet of your mistress's spectacles out.
fr: << Oh ! ~~~ Patty, dis-je ne venez pas me raconter vos mauvaises nouvelles. C'est assez que les lunettes de votre maitresse soient deteriorees. >>

eng: Then the baked apples came home, Mrs. Wallis sent them by her boy; they are extremely civil and obliging to us, the Wallises, always--I have heard some people say that Mrs. Wallis can be uncivil and give a very rude answer, but we have never known any thing but the greatest attention from them.
fr: Ensuite les pommes au four sont arrivees ; Mme Wallis les a fait porter par son garcon ; les Wallis sont extremement obligeants pour nous ; j'ai entendu des gens dire que Mme Wallis etait capable, a l'occasion, de repondre grossierement ; mais, quant a nous, elle nous a toujours traites avec tous les egards possibles ;

eng: And it cannot be for the value of our custom now, for what is our consumption of bread, you know? Only three of us.--besides dear Jane at present--and she really eats nothing--makes such a shocking breakfast, you would be quite frightened if you saw it.
fr: ce ne peut pas etre par interet, car notre consommation de pain est insignifiante. Nous sommes, il est vrai, trois a table, mais, en ce moment, la pauvre Jane n'a aucun appetit ; ma mere serait effrayee si elle savait de quoi se compose le dejeuner de Jane ;

eng: I dare not let my mother know how little she eats--so I say one thing and then I say another, and it passes off.
fr: aussi pendant le repas, je m'efforce de parler d'une chose et puis d'une autre, et elle ne s'apercoit de rien.

eng: But about the middle of the day she gets hungry, and there is nothing she likes so well as these baked apples, and they are extremely wholesome, for I took the opportunity the other day of asking Mr. Perry; I happened to meet him in the street.
fr: Vers le milieu de la journee, elle commence a sentir la faim et elle prefere les pommes au four a tout autre mets. Precisement, ces jours derniers, j'ai eu l'occasion de parler avec M. Perry et il m'a confirme la valeur nutritive de cet aliment.

eng: Not that I had any doubt before--I have so often heard Mr. Woodhouse recommend a baked apple. I believe it is the only way that Mr. Woodhouse thinks the fruit thoroughly wholesome. We have apple-dumplings, however, very often. Patty makes an excellent apple-dumpling.
fr: J'ai du reste entendu M. Woodhouse recommander une pomme au four ; c'est la seule maniere d'accommoder ce fruit, qu'il preconise.

eng: Well, Mrs. Weston, you have prevailed, I hope, and these ladies will oblige us."
fr: Eh bien, avons-nous gagne notre cause ? Vous allez, j'espere, nous accompagner.

eng: Emma would be "very happy to wait on Mrs. Bates, &c.," and they did at last move out of the shop, with no farther delay from Miss Bates than, "How do you do, Mrs. Ford? I beg your pardon.
fr: -- Je serai tres heureux de presenter mes hommages a Mme Bates, repondit Emma. Elles quitterent finalement le magasin non sans que Mlle Bates eut ajoute : -- Comment allez-vous, Mme Ford ? Excusez-moi, je ne vous avais pas apercue.

eng: I did not see you before.'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "What was I talking of?" said she, beginning again when they were all in the street.
fr: Des qu'elles furent dans la rue, Mlle Bates reprit : -- Qu'est-ce que je disais ?

eng: Emma wondered on what, of all the medley, she would fix.
fr: Emma se demanda comment la bonne demoiselle parviendrait a faire un choix dans cette inextricable confusion.

eng: "I declare I cannot recollect what I was talking of.--Oh! my mother's spectacles.
fr: -- Ah ! oui, je parlais des lunettes de ma mere !

eng: So very obliging of Mr. Frank Churchill! 'Oh!' said he, 'I do think I can fasten the rivet; I like a job of this kind excessively.'
fr: M. Frank Churchill fit preuve d'une extreme obligeance ! << Je crois, dit-il, que je pourrais remettre cette vis ; j'aime beaucoup ce genre de travail. >>

eng: --Which you know shewed him to be so very....
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Indeed I must say that, much as I had heard of him before and much as I had expected, he very far exceeds any thing....
fr: Malgre tout le bien que j'avais entendu dire de lui, la realite a de beaucoup depasse mon attente.

eng: I do congratulate you, Mrs. Weston, most warmly. He seems every thing the fondest parent could....
fr: Je vous felicite bien sincerement, Mme Weston ; il semble vraiment etre le plus affectueux des parents...

eng: 'Oh!' said he, 'I can fasten the rivet. I like a job of that sort excessively.'
fr: << Je crois, dit-il, que je pourrais remettre cette vis ; j'aime beaucoup ce genre de travail. >>

eng: I never shall forget his manner.
fr: Je n'oublierai jamais sa maniere d'agir relativement aux lunettes.

eng: And when I brought out the baked apples from the closet, and hoped our friends would be so very obliging as to take some, 'Oh!' said he directly, 'there is nothing in the way of fruit half so good, and these are the finest-looking home-baked apples I ever saw in my life.'
fr: Quand j'ai apporte les pommes avec l'espoir d'en faire accepter une a nos amis : << Ces pommes, dit-il immediatement sont les plus belles pommes cuites au four que j'aie vues de ma vie >>.

eng: That, you know, was so very....
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: And I am sure, by his manner, it was no compliment.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Indeed they are very delightful apples, and Mrs. Wallis does them full justice--only we do not have them baked more than twice, and Mr. Woodhouse made us promise to have them done three times--but Miss Woodhouse will be so good as not to mention it.
fr: Ce sont en effet des pommes exquises et Mme Wallis en tire tout le parti possible ; elle ne les met au four que deux fois ; M. Woodhouse nous avaient engages a les faire passer trois fois au feu, aussi Mlle Woodhouse sera assez bonne pour ne pas en parler.

eng: The apples themselves are the very finest sort for baking, beyond a doubt; all from Donwell--some of Mr. Knightley's most liberal supply.
fr: Quant aux pommes, elles sont de la meilleure espece pour cuire : toutes proviennent de Donwell ; M. Knightley nous en envoie un sac tous les ans.

eng: He sends us a sack every year; and certainly there never was such a keeping apple anywhere as one of his trees--I believe there is two of them.
fr: Ma mere dit que le verger de Donwell a toujours ete renomme.

eng: My mother says the orchard was always famous in her younger days.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text - partially covered above)

eng: But I was really quite shocked the other day--for Mr. Knightley called one morning, and Jane was eating these apples, and we talked about them and said how much she enjoyed them, and he asked whether we were not got to the end of our stock.
fr: Mais l'autre jour j'ai ete vraiment confuse : M. Knightley est venu nous voir un matin et precisement Jane etait en train de manger des pommes ; nous lui dimes combien nous les trouvions excellentes et il nous demanda si nous etions arrivees au bout de notre provision :

eng: 'I am sure you must be,' said he, 'and I will send you another supply; for I have a great many more than I can ever use. William Larkins let me keep a larger quantity than usual this year. I will send you some more, before they get good for nothing.'
fr: << Je suis sur, ajouta-t-il, que vous ne devez plus en avoir et je vous en enverrai d'autres ; j'en ai beaucoup trop et elles vont pourrir. >>

eng: So I begged he would not--for really as to ours being gone, I could not absolutely say that we had a great many left--it was but half a dozen indeed; but they should be all kept for Jane; and I could not at all bear that he should be sending us more, so liberal as he had been already; and Jane said the same.
fr: Je l'ai prie de n'en rien faire ; il nous en restait a peine une demi-douzaine et je n'ai pu dire le contraire.

eng: And when he was gone, she almost quarrelled with me--No, I should not say quarrelled, for we never had a quarrel in our lives; but she was quite distressed that I had owned the apples were so nearly gone; she wished I had made him believe we had a great many left.
fr: Apres son depart, Jane me querella presque - je ne devrais pas employer ce mot, car nous n'avons jamais eu une discussion de notre vie - mais elle etait tout a fait desesperee que j'eusse avoue la verite ; j'aurais du, parait-il, laisser entendre qu'il y en avait un grand nombre.

eng: Oh, said I, my dear, I did say as much as I could.
fr: << Oh ! dis-je, ma chere, j'ai fait ce que j'ai pu >>.

eng: However, the very same evening William Larkins came over with a large basket of apples, the same sort of apples, a bushel at least, and I was very much obliged, and went down and spoke to William Larkins and said every thing, as you may suppose.
fr: Le meme soir, William Larkins arriva avec un enorme panier de pommes ; je suis descendue pour lui parler et j'ai dit tout ce qu'il etait possible de dire, comme vous pouvez bien le supposer.

eng: I am always glad to see him.
fr: Je suis toujours heureuse de le voir.

eng: But, however, I found afterwards from Patty, that William said it was all the apples of _that_ sort his master had; he had brought them all--and now his master had not one left to bake or boil.
fr: J'ai appris ensuite la verite par Patty : William lui confia qu'il n'y avait plus dans le fruitier des pommes de cette espece.

eng: William did not seem to mind it himself, he was so pleased to think his master had sold so many; for William, you know, thinks more of his master's profit than any thing; but Mrs. Hodges, he said, was quite displeased at their being all sent away.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She could not bear that her master should not be able to have another apple-tart this spring.
fr: Mme Hodge etait tres mecontente ; elle ne pouvait pas supporter l'idee que M. Knightley fut prive dorenavant de tartes aux pommes.

eng: "I wanted to keep it from Jane's knowledge; but, unluckily, I had mentioned it before I was aware."
fr: "Je voulais meme la cacher a Jane, mais, par malheur, j'y ai fait allusion involontairement."

eng: "Miss Bates had just done speaking as Patty opened the door; and her visitors walked upstairs without having any regular narration to attend to, pursued only by the sounds of her desultory good-will."
fr: "Mlle Bates finissait de parler quand Patty ouvrit la porte ; les visiteuses gravirent l'escalier, non sans etre accablees de recommandations."

eng: ""Pray take care, Mrs. Weston, there is a step at the turning. Pray take care, Miss Woodhouse, ours is rather a dark staircase--rather darker and narrower than one could wish. Miss Smith, pray take care. Miss Woodhouse, I am quite concerned, I am sure you hit your foot. Miss Smith, the step at the turning.""
fr: "-- Je vous en prie, Mme Weston, faites attention, il y a une marche au tournant. Mefiez-vous, Mlle Woodhouse, notre escalier est si etroit ! Mlle Smith, regardez bien ou vous mettez le pied. Mlle Woodhouse, je suis sure que vous vous etes cognee..."

eng: "CHAPTER X The appearance of the little sitting-room as they entered, was tranquillity itself;"
fr: "XXVIII Une absolue tranquillite regnait dans le petit salon ou les quatre dames penetrerent :"

eng: "Mrs. Bates, deprived of her usual employment, slumbering on one side of the fire,"
fr: "Mme Bates, privee de son occupation habituelle, sommeillait d'un cote de la cheminee ; "

eng: "Frank Churchill, at a table near her, most deedily occupied about her spectacles,"
fr: "Frank Churchill, assis a une table, etait profondement absorbe dans la reparation des lunettes"

eng: "and Jane Fairfax, standing with her back to them, intent on her pianoforte."
fr: "et Jane Fairfax, leur tournant le dos, se tenait aupres du piano."

eng: "This is a pleasure," said he, in rather a low voice, "coming at least ten minutes earlier than I had calculated. You find me trying to be useful; tell me if you think I shall succeed."
fr: "<< Voici un plaisir, dit-il d'une voix un peu basse, qui m'echoit dix minutes plus tot que je ne m'y attendais ! Vous me voyez en train d'essayer de me rendre utile.

eng: "What!" said Mrs. Weston, "have not you finished it yet? you would not earn a very good livelihood as a working silversmith at this rate."
fr: "-- Quoi ! dit Mme Weston, n'avez-vous pas encore termine ? Vous ne gagneriez pas facilement votre vie comme bijoutier !

eng: "I have not been working uninterruptedly," he replied, "I have been assisting Miss Fairfax in trying to make her instrument stand steadily, it was not quite firm; an unevenness in the floor, I believe. You see we have been wedging one leg with paper.
fr: "-- Je n'ai pas travaille sans interruption, reprit-il. J'ai aide Mlle Fairfax a assurer l'equilibre de son piano ; il n'etait pas bien d'accord, sans doute a cause d'une difference de niveau dans le parquet ; nous avons cale un des pieds avec du papier.

eng: This was very kind of you to be persuaded to come.
fr: C'est bien aimable de votre part, Mademoiselle Woodhouse, de vous etre laissee persuader ;

eng: I was almost afraid you would be hurrying home."
fr: je craignais que vous ne fussiez rentree immediatement.

eng: He contrived that she should be seated by him; and was sufficiently employed in looking out the best baked apple for her, and trying to make her help or advise him in his work, till Jane Fairfax was quite ready to sit down to the pianoforte again.
fr: Il s'arrangea a ce qu'Emma fut assise aupres de lui ; s'occupa de chercher pour elle les meilleures pommes, essaya de lui faire donner son avis sur le travail qu'il poursuivait. Au bout de cinq minutes, Jane Fairfax s'installa de nouveau au piano.

eng: That she was not immediately ready, Emma did suspect to arise from the state of her nerves; she had not yet possessed the instrument long enough to touch it without emotion; she must reason herself into the power of performance; and Emma could not but pity such feelings, whatever their origin, and could not but resolve never to expose them to her neighbour again.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: At last Jane began, and though the first bars were feebly given, the powers of the instrument were gradually done full justice to.
fr: A la fin Jane commenca : les premiers accorda furent attaques avec mollesse, mais peu a peu l'instrument fut mis en pleine valeur.

eng: Mrs. Weston had been delighted before, and was delighted again; Emma joined her in all her praise; and the pianoforte, with every proper discrimination, was pronounced to be altogether of the highest promise.
fr: Mme Weston avait ete enchantee auparavant et elle ne le fut pas moins cette fois ; Emma joignit ses eloges a ceux de son amie et le piano fut proclame absolument parfait.

eng: "Whoever Colonel Campbell might employ," said Frank Churchill, with a smile at Emma, "the person has not chosen ill.'
fr: -- Quel qu'ait ete le mandataire du colonel Campbell, dit Frank Churchill, avec un sourire a l'adresse d'Emma, cette personne n'a pas mal choisi.

eng: I dare say, Miss Fairfax, that he either gave his friend very minute directions, or wrote to Broadwood himself.
fr: Il a du donner a son ami des instructions tres precises ou ecrire lui-meme a Broadwood, Ne le pensez-vous pas, Mlle Fairfax ?

eng: Do not you think so?
fr: Ne le pensez-vous pas, Mlle Fairfax ?

eng: Jane did not look round.
fr: Jane ne se retourna pas ;

eng: She was not obliged to hear.
fr: elle n'etait pas forcee d'avoir entendu,

eng: Mrs. Weston had been speaking to her at the same moment.
fr: Mme Weston lui ayant parle au meme instant.

eng: "It is not fair," said Emma, in a whisper; "mine was a random guess.
fr: -- Ce n'est pas loyal, dit Emma a mi-voix, ma supposition etait toute gratuite.

eng: Do not distress her."
fr: Ne la tourmentez pas.

eng: He shook his head with a smile, and looked as if he had very little doubt and very little mercy.
fr: Il secoua la tete en souriant et ne parut nourrir ni doute ni pitie.

eng: Soon afterwards he began again, "How much your friends in Ireland must be enjoying your pleasure on this occasion, Miss Fairfax.
fr: Il reprit peu apres : -- Combien vos amis d'Irlande doivent en ce moment se rejouir du plaisir qu'ils vous ont procure, Mlle Fairfax.

eng: I dare say they often think of you, and wonder which will be the day, the precise day of the instrument's coming to hand.
fr: J'imagine qu'ils pensent souvent a vous et cherchent a deviner le jour precis de l'arrivee du piano.

eng: Do you imagine Colonel Campbell knows the business to be going forward just at this time?--Do you imagine it to be the consequence of an immediate commission from him, or that he may have sent only a general direction, an order indefinite as to time, to depend upon contingencies and conveniences?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He paused.
fr: He paused.

eng: She could not but hear; she could not avoid answering, "Till I have a letter from Colonel Campbell," said she, in a voice of forced calmness, "I can imagine nothing with any confidence.
fr: She could not but hear; she could not avoid answering, -- Jusqu'a ce que j'aie recu une lettre du colonel Campbell, repondit Jane, d'une voix contenue, je ne puis faire aucune conjecture raisonnable ;

eng: It must be all conjecture."
fr: c'est a peine si j'ose emettre des suppositions.

eng: "Conjecture--aye, sometimes one conjectures right, and sometimes one conjectures wrong.
fr: -- Pour ma part je voudrais bien etre a meme de prevoir dans combien de temps j'aurai reussi a fixer cette vis !

eng: I wish I could conjecture how soon I shall make this rivet quite firm.
fr: Que peut-on dire de sense, Mademoiselle Woodhouse, quand on travaille ?

eng: What nonsense one talks, Miss Woodhouse, when hard at work, if one talks at all;--your real workmen, I suppose, hold their tongues; but we gentlemen labourers if we get hold of a word--Miss Fairfax said something about conjecturing.
fr: Les veritables ouvriers, je suppose, restent silencieux, mais nous autres amateurs... Voila, c'est fait.

eng: There, it is done.
fr: Voila, c'est fait.

eng: I have the pleasure, madam, (to Mrs. Bates,) of restoring your spectacles, healed for the present."
fr: J'ai le plaisir, Madame, ajouta-t-il en s'adressant a Mme Bates, de vous rendre vos lunettes reparees pour un temps.

eng: He was very warmly thanked both by mother and daughter;
fr: Il fut remercie avec chaleur par la mere et la fille ;

eng: to escape a little from the latter, he went to the pianoforte, and begged Miss Fairfax, who was still sitting at it, to play something more.
fr: pour echapper aux actions de graces de cette derniere, il se refugia pres du piano ou Mlle Fairfax etait toujours assise et la pria de jouer encore.

eng: "If you are very kind," said he, "it will be one of the waltzes we danced last night;--let me live them over again.
fr: -- Si vous voulez etre tres bonne, dit-il, ce sera une des valses d'hier soir.

eng: You did not enjoy them as I did; you appeared tired the whole time.
fr: Vous n'avez pas paru prendre a la danse autant de plaisir que moi ; vous etiez sans doute fatiguee.

eng: I believe you were glad we danced no longer; but I would have given worlds--all the worlds one ever has to give--for another half-hour."
fr: Je vous soupconne de vous etre rejouie de la fin prematuree de la sauterie, mais moi j'aurais donne un monde pour la prolonger d'une demi-heure.

eng: She played.
fr: Quand elle eut termine,

eng: "What felicity it is to hear a tune again which _has_ made one happy!--If I mistake not that was danced at Weymouth."
fr: il reprit : -- Quelle joie, de reentendre un air auquel un bonheur est associe. Si je ne me trompe, nous avons danse a Weymouth cette meme valse ?

eng: She looked up at him for a moment, coloured deeply, and played something else.
fr: Elle leva les yeux vers lui, rougit et se remit a jouer.

eng: He took some music from a chair near the pianoforte, and turning to Emma, said, "Here is something quite new to me.
fr: Il prit sur la chaise qui se trouvait pres du piano plusieurs morceaux de musique et, se tournant vers Emma, il dit : -- Connaissez-vous cet auteur : Cramer ?

eng: Do you know it?--Cramer.--And here are a new set of Irish melodies.
fr: Voici une recente serie de melodies irlandaises :

eng: That, from such a quarter, one might expect.
fr: elles ont ete envoyees avec le piano. Rien d'etonnant venant d'un tel milieu.

eng: This was all sent with the instrument.
fr: C'est une aimable pensee du colonel Campbell, n'est-ce pas ?

eng: Very thoughtful of Colonel Campbell, was not it?
fr: Il savait que Mlle Fairfax ne pouvait pas se procurer de musique ici.

eng: He knew Miss Fairfax could have no music here.
fr: Je tiens pour particulierement touchante cette partie du present ; rien n'a ete fait vite, rien incompletement.

eng: I honour that part of the attention particularly; it shews it to have been so thoroughly from the heart.
fr: La veritable affection est seule capable de trouver des attentions aussi delicates.

eng: Nothing hastily done; nothing incomplete.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: True affection only could have prompted it."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Emma wished he would be less pointed, yet could not help being amused; and when on glancing her eye towards Jane Fairfax she caught the remains of a smile, when she saw that with all the deep blush of consciousness, there had been a smile of secret delight, she had less scruple in the amusement, and much less compunction with respect to her.--This amiable, upright, perfect Jane Fairfax was apparently cherishing very reprehensible feelings.
fr: Emma jeta un regard a la derobee vers Jane Fairfax et surprit la trace d'un sourire : la rougeur cachait mal les marques d'une joie interieure. ~~~ A la suite de cette constatation, les scrupules et la commiseration d'Emma s'evanouirent.

eng: He brought all the music to her, and they looked it over together.--Emma took the opportunity of whispering, "You speak too plain.
fr: Elle se pencha pour examiner la musique avec son voisin et profita de l'occasion pour murmurer : -- Vous parlez trop clairement :

eng: She must understand you."
fr: elle ne peut faire autrement que de vous comprendre.

eng: "I hope she does.
fr: -- Je l'espere bien.

eng: I would have her understand me.
fr: Je desire qu'elle me comprenne.

eng: I am not in the least ashamed of my meaning."
fr: Je n'ai nulle honte de ce que je pense.

eng: "But really, I am half ashamed, and wish I had never taken up the idea."
fr: -- Mais moi j'en ai et je voudrais ne vous avoir jamais fait part de mon soupcon.

eng: "I am very glad you did, and that you communicated it to me.
fr: -- Je suis bien content au contraire d'avoir ete eclaire.

eng: I have now a key to all her odd looks and ways.
fr: J'ai maintenant une cle pour expliquer la bizarrerie de ses airs et de ses manieres.

eng: Leave shame to her.
fr: Si elle nourrit des sentiments reprehensibles, il convient qu'elle en souffre.

eng: If she does wrong, she ought to feel it."
fr: -- Je ne la crois pas absolument innocente.

eng: "She is not entirely without it, I think."
fr: -- Je ne distingue pas bien les symptomes.

eng: "I do not see much sign of it.
fr: Elle joue en ce moment Robin Adair, le morceau favori de la personne en question.

eng: She is playing _Robin_ _Adair_ at this moment--_his_ favourite."
fr: Peu apres, Mlle Bates qui se tenait pres de la fenetre apercut M. Knightley qui passait a cheval.

eng: Shortly afterwards Miss Bates, passing near the window, descried Mr. Knightley on horse-back not far off.
fr: -- C'est bien M. Knightley !

eng: "Mr. Knightley I declare!--I must speak to him if possible, just to thank him.
fr: Je vais essayer de lui parler pour le remercier.

eng: I will not open the window here; it would give you all cold; but I can go into my mother's room you know.
fr: Je n'ouvrirai pas cette fenetre car vous auriez tous froid, mais je puis aller dans la chambre de ma mere.

eng: I dare say he will come in when he knows who is here.
fr: Je vais lui dire que nous avons des visiteurs.

eng: Quite delightful to have you all meet so!--Our little room so honoured!"
fr: C'est delicieux de vous avoir tous ensemble. ~~~ Quel honneur pour notre petit salon.

eng: She was in the adjoining chamber while she still spoke, and opening the casement there, immediately called Mr. Knightley's attention, and every syllable of their conversation was as distinctly heard by the others, as if it had passed within the same apartment.
fr: Elle se dirigea immediatement vers la piece voisine, et attira l'attention de M. Knightley. ~~~ La porte etant restee ouverte, chaque syllabe de leur conversation etait entendue distinctement par tous les assistants.

eng: "How d' ye do?--how d'ye do?--Very well, I thank you.
fr: -- Comment allez-vous ? commenca Mlle Bates.

eng: So obliged to you for the carriage last night.
fr: Je vous remercie mille fois pour la voiture.

eng: We were just in time; my mother just ready for us.
fr: Nous sommes rentrees juste a temps ; ma mere nous attendait.

eng: Pray come in; do come in.
fr: Je vous en prie, entrez ;

eng: You will find some friends here."
fr: vous trouverez quelques amis :

eng: So began Miss Bates; and Mr. Knightley seemed determined to be heard in his turn, for most resolutely and commandingly did he say, "How is your niece, Miss Bates?--I want to inquire after you all, but particularly your niece.
fr: M. Knightley dit d'une voix autoritaire : -- Comment va votre niece, mademoiselle Bates ? J'espere qu'elle n'a pas pris froid hier soir ?

eng: How is Miss Fairfax?--I hope she caught no cold last night.
fr: Mlle Bates fut forcee de donner une reponse directe avant de pouvoir se lancer dans une nouvelle dissertation.

eng: How is she to-day?
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Tell me how Miss Fairfax is."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "So obliged to you!--so very much obliged to you for the carriage," resumed Miss Bates.
fr: '-- Je vous suis si obligee pour la voiture, reprit Mlle Bates.

eng: He cut her short with, "I am going to Kingston. Can I do any thing for you?"
fr: Il l'interrompit en disant : -- Je vais a Kinston. Puis-je faire quelque chose pour vous ?

eng: "Oh! dear, Kingston--are you?--Mrs. Cole was saying the other day she wanted something from Kingston."
fr: -- Oh ! vraiment a Kinston ? Mme Cole disait l'autre jour qu'elle avait une commission pour Kinston.

eng: "Mrs. Cole has servants to send. Can I do any thing for _you_?"
fr: -- Mme Cole a des domestiques a sa disposition, mais je serai content de vous etre utile.

eng: "No, I thank you. But do come in. Who do you think is here?--Miss Woodhouse and Miss Smith; so kind as to call to hear the new pianoforte. Do put up your horse at the Crown, and come in."
fr: -- Je vous remercie, nous n'avons besoin de rien, mais entrez donc. Devinez qui est ici ? Mlle Woodhouse et Mlle Smith, venues pour juger le nouveau piano ; mettez votre cheval a la Couronne et venez nous rejoindre.

eng: "Well," said he, in a deliberating manner, "for five minutes, perhaps."
fr: -- Eh bien, dit-il, peut-etre... pour quelques instants.

eng: "And here is Mrs. Weston and Mr. Frank Churchill too!--Quite delightful; so many friends!"
fr: -- Et il y a aussi Mme Weston et M. Frank Churchill ! ~~~ C'est delicieux : tant d'amis !

eng: "No, not now, I thank you. I could not stay two minutes. I must get on to Kingston as fast as I can."
fr: -- Reflexion faite, ce sera pour une autre fois ; je ne pourrais rester que deux minutes. Je suis en retard.

eng: "Oh! ~~~ do come in. They will be so very happy to see you."
fr: -- Je vous en prie, ils seront si heureux de vous voir.

eng: "No, no; your room is full enough. ~~~ I will call another day, and hear the pianoforte."
fr: -- Non ; votre salon est deja plein de monde ; Je reviendrai un autre jour.

eng: "Well, I am so sorry!--Oh! Mr. Knightley, what a delightful party last night; how extremely pleasant.--Did you ever see such dancing?--Was not it delightful?--Miss Woodhouse and Mr. Frank Churchill; I never saw any thing equal to it."
fr: -- Comme il vous plaira ! Quelle charmante soiree nous avons passee hier soir ! Avez-vous admire la facon de danser de Mlle Woodhouse et de M. Frank Churchill ? Je n'ai jamais rien vu de pareil.

eng: "Oh! ~~~ very delightful indeed; I can say nothing less, for I suppose Miss Woodhouse and Mr. Frank Churchill are hearing every thing that passes.'
fr: -- Tout a fait delicieux en effet ; il me serait, du reste, difficile de ne pas en convenir, car je suppose que Mlle Woodhouse et M. Frank Churchill sont a portee de la voix !'

eng: I think Miss Fairfax dances very well; and Mrs. Weston is the very best country-dance player, without exception, in England.
fr: A mon avis, Mlle Fairfax danse avec une extreme elegance et je considere Mme Weston comme la plus parfaite executante de musique de danse qui soit en Angleterre !

eng: Now, if your friends have any gratitude, they will say something pretty loud about you and me in return; but I cannot stay to hear it.
fr: Maintenant, si vos amis ont la moindre gratitude, ils feront quelques remarques obligeantes sur notre compte ; je regrette de ne pouvoir rester pour les entendre.

eng: "Oh! Mr. Knightley, one moment more; something of consequence--so shocked!--Jane and I are both so shocked about the apples!"
fr: -- Oh ! M. Knightley, encore un moment ! J'ai quelque chose d'important a vous dire : Jane et moi nous sommes toutes deux si confuses a propos des pommes !

eng: "What is the matter now?"
fr: -- Pourquoi donc ?

eng: "To think of your sending us all your store apples. You said you had a great many, and now you have not one left.
fr: Est-il possible que vous nous ayez envoye toute votre reserve de pommes ! Vous en aviez encore beaucoup, disiez-vous, et en verite il ne vous en reste pas une.

eng: ~~~ We really are so shocked! Mrs. Hodges may well be angry. William Larkins mentioned it here. You should not have done it, indeed you should not.
fr: ~~~ Mme Hodges a bien raison d'etre irritee. William Larkins nous a tout raconte. Vous n'auriez pas du agir ainsi.

eng: he is off.
fr: le voila parti !

eng: He never can bear to be thanked.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: But I thought he would have staid now, and it would have been a pity not to have mentioned....
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Well, (returning to the room,) I have not been able to succeed.
fr: Eh bien, ajouta-t-elle en rentrant dans le salon, je n'ai pas reussi.

eng: Mr. Knightley cannot stop.
fr: M. Knightley est trop presse pour s'arreter.

eng: He is going to Kingston.
fr: Il va a Kinston.

eng: He asked me if he could do any thing....
fr: Il m'a demande s'il pouvait faire quelque chose pour...

eng: "Yes," said Jane, "we heard his kind offers, we heard every thing."
fr: -- Oui, dit Jane, nous avons entendu ses aimables offres, nous avons tout entendu.

eng: "Oh! yes, my dear, I dare say you might, because you know, the door was open, and the window was open, and Mr. Knightley spoke loud.
fr: -- Je n'en suis pas etonnee, ma chere, la porte est restee ouverte et M. Knightley parlait tout haut.

eng: You must have heard every thing to be sure.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: 'Can I do any thing for you at Kingston?' said he; so I just mentioned....
fr: << Puis-je faire quelque chose pour vous a Kinston ? >> m'a-t-il dit. J'en ai profite pour faire allusion a...

eng: Oh! Miss Woodhouse, must you be going?--You seem but just come--so very obliging of you.
fr: Oh ! Mlle Woodhouse, est-ce qu'il faut que vous partiez ? Il me semble que vous arrivez seulement.

eng: Emma found it really time to be at home; the visit had already lasted long; and on examining watches, so much of the morning was perceived to be gone, that Mrs. Weston and her companion taking leave also, could allow themselves only to walk with the two young ladies to Hartfield gates, before they set off for Randalls.
fr: Comme vous etes aimable ! En examinant les montres, on s'apercut qu'une grande partie de l'apres-midi s'etait ecoulee, Mme Weston et son beau-fils, apres avoir pris conge, a leur tour, accompagnerent les deux jeunes filles jusqu'a la grille d'Hartfield et se haterent de rentrer a Randalls.

eng: CHAPTER XI
fr: XXIX

eng: It may be possible to do without dancing entirely.
fr: Il est possible de vivre sans danser :

eng: Instances have been known of young people passing many, many months successively, without being at any ball of any description, and no material injury accrue either to body or mind;--but when a beginning is made--when the felicities of rapid motion have once been, though slightly, felt--it must be a very heavy set that does not ask for more.
fr: on a vu des jeunes gens ne pas aller au bal pendant plusieurs mois de suite et ne s'en ressentir ni au physique ni au moral ; mais une fois le premier pas fait, une fois les delices du mouvement rapide entrevues, il faut etre d'une essence bien grossiere pour ne pas desirer continuer.

eng: Frank Churchill had danced once at Highbury, and longed to dance again; and the last half-hour of an evening which Mr. Woodhouse was persuaded to spend with his daughter at Randalls, was passed by the two young people in schemes on the subject.
fr: Frank Churchill avait danse un soir a Highbury et brulait de recommencer. Il avait reussi a gagner son pere et sa belle-mere a ses idees et un plan de soiree dansante fut elabore, puis soumis a l'approbation de M. et de Mlle Woodhouse au cours d'une visite a Randalls.

eng: Frank's was the first idea; and his the greatest zeal in pursuing it; for the lady was the best judge of the difficulties, and the most solicitous for accommodation and appearance.
fr: Emma voyait les difficultes materielles du projet, mais en principe elle y etait tout acquise et ne menagea pas son concours a Frank Churchill :

eng: But still she had inclination enough for shewing people again how delightfully Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss Woodhouse danced--for doing that in which she need not blush to compare herself with Jane Fairfax--and even for simple dancing itself, without any of the wicked aids of vanity--to assist him first in pacing out the room they were in to see what it could be made to hold--and then in taking the dimensions of the other parlour, in the hope of discovering, in spite of all that Mr. Weston could say of their exactly equal size, that it was a little the largest.
fr: ils mesurerent d'abord la chambre ou ils se trouvaient et persisterent ensuite a vouloir prendre les dimensions du salon contigu, malgre les assurances de M. Weston sur l'equivalence des deux pieces.

eng: His first proposition and request, that the dance begun at Mr. Cole's should be finished there--that the same party should be collected, and the same musician engaged, met with the readiest acquiescence.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Mr. Weston entered into the idea with thorough enjoyment, and Mrs. Weston most willingly undertook to play as long as they could wish to dance; and the interesting employment had followed, of reckoning up exactly who there would be, and portioning out the indispensable division of space to every couple.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "You and Miss Smith, and Miss Fairfax, will be three, and the two Miss Coxes five," had been repeated many times over.
fr: Puis commenca l'enumeration des invites : -- Vous, Mlle Smith, Mlle Fairfax, les deux demoiselles Cox, cinq, recapitula plusieurs fois Frank Churchill.

eng: "And there will be the two Gilberts, young Cox, my father, and myself, besides Mr. Knightley.
fr: Du cote masculin, il y aura les deux Gilbert, le jeune Cox, mon pere et moi, outre M. Knightley.

eng: Yes, that will be quite enough for pleasure.
fr: Ce sera suffisant pour l'agrement

eng: You and Miss Smith, and Miss Fairfax, will be three, and the two Miss Coxes five; and for five couple there will be plenty of room."
fr: et il y aura largement de la place pour cinq couples.

eng: But soon it came to be on one side, "But will there be good room for five couple?--I really do not think there will."
fr: -- En y reflechissant, reprit M. Weston, il ne me semble guere possible de lancer des invitations pour cinq couples.

eng: On another, "And after all, five couple are not enough to make it worth while to stand up.
fr: Une sauterie aussi restreinte ne peut etre qu'improvisee.

eng: Five couple are nothing, when one thinks seriously about it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It will not do to _invite_ five couple.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It can be allowable only as the thought of the moment."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Somebody said that _Miss_ Gilbert was expected at her brother's, and must be invited with the rest.
fr: On decouvrit alors que Mlle Gilberte etait attendue chez son frere

eng: Somebody else believed _Mrs_. Gilbert would have danced the other evening, if she had been asked.
fr: et l'existence d'un autre jeune Cox ;

eng: A word was put in for a second young Cox; and at last, Mr. Weston naming one family of cousins who must be included, and another of very old acquaintance who could not be left out, it became a certainty that the five couple would be at least ten, and a very interesting speculation in what possible manner they could be disposed of.
fr: M. Weston nomma une famille de cousins qui devaient etre inclus dans l'invitation. Finalement on arriva a dix couples au moins et il fallut songer au moyen de les faire tenir dans l'espace disponible.

eng: The doors of the two rooms were just opposite each other.
fr: Les portes des deux chambres se faisaient precisement vis-a-vis :

eng: "Might not they use both rooms, and dance across the passage?"
fr: -- Ne pourrait-on danser dans les deux chambres a travers le passage ? suggera Frank Churchill.

eng: It seemed the best scheme; and yet it was not so good but that many of them wanted a better.
fr: On eut vite fait de s'apercevoir des inconvenients de cette solution.

eng: Emma said it would be awkward; Mrs. Weston was in distress about the supper; and Mr. Woodhouse opposed it earnestly, on the score of health.
fr: Mme Weston se desesperait de ne plus avoir de place pour le souper et la seule idee du couloir affectait tellement M. Woodhouse qu'on dut renoncer definitivement a ce plan.

eng: It made him so very unhappy, indeed, that it could not be persevered in.
fr: -- Oh non ! dit-il, ce serait de la plus extreme imprudence.

eng: Mrs. Weston, you would be quite laid up; do not let them talk of such a wild thing.
fr: Madame Weston, vous seriez certainement forcee de vous coucher ; ne les laissez pas parler d'une chose aussi absurde, je vous en prie.

eng: Pray do not let them talk of it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: That young man (speaking lower) is very thoughtless.
fr: Ce jeune homme, ajouta-t-il en baissant la voix, est etourdi ;

eng: He has been opening the doors very often this evening, and keeping them open very inconsiderately.
fr: il a laisse les portes ouvertes ce soir a plusieurs reprises tres inconsiderement ;

eng: He does not think of the draught.
fr: il ne pense pas aux courants d'air.

eng: I do not mean to set you against him, but indeed he is not quite the thing!
fr: Je ne voudrais pas vous indisposer contre lui, mais il n'est pas, je regrette de le dire, tout a fait ce qu'il devrait etre.

eng: Mrs. Weston was sorry for such a charge.
fr: Mme Weston fut desolee d'entendre ce requisitoire ;

eng: She knew the importance of it, and said every thing in her power to do it away.
fr: elle prevoyait les consequences qu'une pareille opinion pouvait avoir un jour ou l'autre et elle fit tout son possible pour effacer cette mauvaise impression.

eng: Every door was now closed, the passage plan given up, and the first scheme of dancing only in the room they were in resorted to again;
fr: Toutes les portes furent fermees et on renonca au couloir. Il fallut revenir a la conception primitive ;

eng: and with such good-will on Frank Churchill's part, that the space which a quarter of an hour before had been deemed barely sufficient for five couple, was now endeavoured to be made out quite enough for ten.
fr: Frank Churchill y mit tant de bonne volonte que l'espace juge a peine suffisant pour cinq couples, un quart d'heure auparavant, lui paraissait maintenant pouvoir en contenir dix.

eng: "We were too magnificent," said he.
fr: -- Nous avons ete trop genereux, dit-il dans nos appreciations des distances.

eng: "We allowed unnecessary room. Ten couple may stand here very well."
fr: Dix couples pourront parfaitement evoluer ici.

eng: Emma demurred.
fr: Emma hesita.

eng: "It would be a crowd--a sad crowd; and what could be worse than dancing without space to turn in?"
fr: -- Quel plaisir, dit-elle peut-il y avoir a danser sans l'espace necessaire ?

eng: "Very true," he gravely replied; "it was very bad."
fr: -- C'est juste, reprit-il gravement ; c'est un grand inconvenient.

eng: So you would all.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "It would be dreadful to be standing so close! Nothing can be farther from pleasure than to be dancing in a crowd--and a crowd in a little room!"
fr: 'Ce serait une cohue resserree dans une petite piece. -- Une cohue resserree dans une petite piece !'

eng: "Miss Woodhouse, you have the art of giving pictures in a few words. Exquisite, quite exquisite!--Still, however, having proceeded so far, one is unwilling to give the matter up."
fr: 'Mademoiselle Woodhouse, vous avez l'art de peindre un tableau en quelques mots. Neanmoins, au point ou nous en sommes, je ne me sens pas le courage de renoncer a ce projet ;'

eng: "It would be a disappointment to my father--and altogether--I do not know that--I am rather of opinion that ten couple might stand here very well."
fr: 'ce serait un desappointement pour mon pere et je ne vois pas d'obstacle insurmontable.'

eng: "Ils se separerent sans avoir rien decide."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Before the middle of the next day, he was at Hartfield; and he entered the room with such an agreeable smile as certified the continuance of the scheme."
fr: 'Dans l'apres-midi du lendemain, Frank Churchill arriva a Hartfield avec un sourire de satisfaction sur les levres : il venait en effet proposer une amelioration.'

eng: "It soon appeared that he came to announce an improvement. "Well, Miss Woodhouse," he almost immediately began, "your inclination for dancing has not been quite frightened away, I hope, by the terrors of my father's little rooms.'"
fr: '-- Eh bien ! Mademoiselle Woodhouse, commenca-t-il aussitot, j'espere que votre gout pour la danse n'a pas ete completement mis en fuite par l'horreur de l'exiguite des salons de mon pere.'

eng: "There is no denying it," he replied.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Emma perceived that the nature of his gallantry was a little self-willed, and that he would rather oppose than lose the pleasure of dancing with her; but she took the compliment, and forgave the rest. Had she intended ever to _marry_ him, it might have been worth while to pause and consider, and try to understand the value of his preference, and the character of his temper; but for all the purposes of their acquaintance, he was quite amiable enough."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Yes; if you and Mr. Woodhouse see no objection, and I trust you cannot, my father hopes his friends will be so kind as to visit him there.
fr: '-- Oui, si vous et M. Woodhouse n'y voyez pas d'objection.

eng: Better accommodations, he can promise them, and not a less grateful welcome than at Randalls. It is his own idea.
fr: Mon pere espere que ses amis voudront bien etre ses hotes dans ce local. Il peut leur garantir des conditions plus favorables et un accueil non moins cordial.

eng: Mrs. Weston sees no objection to it, provided you are satisfied.
fr: Mme Weston accepte cet arrangement a condition que vous soyez satisfaite.

eng: This is what we all feel. Oh!
fr: Vous aviez parfaitement raison !
