eng: you were perfectly right! Ten couple, in either of the Randalls rooms, would have been insufferable!--Dreadful!--
fr: Dix couples, dans l'un ou l'autre des salons de Randalls, c'eut ete insupportable, impossible !

eng: I felt how right you were the whole time, but was too anxious for securing _any_ _thing_ to like to yield.
fr: Je m'en rendais compte de mon cote, mais je desirais trop arriver a un resultat pour vouloir ceder.

eng: Is not it a good exchange?--You consent--I hope you consent?"
fr: Ne voyez-vous pas comme moi les avantages de cette nouvelle combinaison ?

eng: "It appears to me a plan that nobody can object to, if Mr. and Mrs. Weston do not. I think it admirable; and, as far as I can answer for myself, shall be most happy--It seems the only improvement that could be.
fr: -- Pour ma part, je serais tres heureuse...

eng: Papa, do you not think it an excellent improvement?"
fr: Papa, est-ce que vous n'approuvez pas aussi ?

eng: She was obliged to repeat and explain it, before it was fully comprehended; and then, being quite new, farther representations were necessary to make it acceptable.
fr: Apres avoir demande et recu des explications supplementaires, M. Woodhouse donna son avis :

eng: "No; he thought it very far from an improvement--a very bad plan--much worse than the other.
fr: -- En verite, un salon dans un hotel est toujours humide ; on n'aere jamais suffisamment, et la piece ne peut etre habitable.

eng: A room at an inn was always damp and dangerous; never properly aired, or fit to be inhabited. If they must dance, they had better dance at Randalls.
fr: Si vous devez danser, il vaudrait mieux que ce fut a Randalls.

eng: He had never been in the room at the Crown in his life--did not know the people who kept it by sight.--Oh! no--a very bad plan. They would catch worse colds at the Crown than anywhere."
fr: Je n'ai jamais mis le pied dans cet hotel. Tout le monde s'enrhumera.

eng: "I was going to observe, sir," said Frank Churchill, "that one of the great recommendations of this change would be the very little danger of any body's catching cold--so much less danger at the Crown than at Randalls!
fr: -- J'allais vous faire observer, Monsieur, dit Frank Churchill, qu'un des avantages de ce changement de local serait precisement d'ecarter tout danger de prendre froid ;

eng: Mr. Perry might have reason to regret the alteration, but nobody else could."
fr: M. Perry pourrait perdre a ce changement, mais personne d'autre n'aurait a le regretter.

eng: "Sir," said Mr. Woodhouse, rather warmly, "you are very much mistaken if you suppose Mr. Perry to be that sort of character. Mr. Perry is extremely concerned when any of us are ill.
fr: -- Monsieur, reprit M. Woodhouse avec chaleur, vous vous meprenez singulierement sur le caractere de M. Perry : M. Perry est extremement tourmente quand un de nous tombe malade.

eng: But I do not understand how the room at the Crown can be safer for you than your father's house."
fr: Mais je ne puis comprendre comment un salon d'hotel peut vous paraitre un meilleur abri que la maison de votre pere.

eng: "From the very circumstance of its being larger, sir. We shall have no occasion to open the windows at all--not once the whole evening; and it is that dreadful habit of opening the windows, letting in cold air upon heated bodies, which (as you well know, sir) does the mischief."
fr: En raison meme de sa grandeur, Monsieur ; nous n'aurons pas besoin d'ouvrir les fenetres, une seule fois et c'est precisement cette mauvaise habitude de laisser penetrer l'air de la nuit dans une chambre ou se trouvent des gens en transpiration qui est la cause de la plupart des refroidissements !

eng: "Open the windows!--but surely, Mr. Churchill, nobody would think of opening the windows at Randalls. Nobody could be so imprudent! I never heard of such a thing. Dancing with open windows!--I am sure, neither your father nor Mrs. Weston (poor Miss Taylor that was) would suffer it."'
fr: -- Ouvrir les fenetres ! Personne ne songerait a ouvrir les fenetres a Randalls. Je n'ai jamais entendu parler d'une chose pareille. Danser les fenetres ouvertes ! Ni votre pere ni Mme Weston - cette pauvre Mlle Taylor - ne tolereraient cette maniere d'agir.'

eng: "sir--but a thoughtless young person will sometimes step behind a window-curtain, and throw up a sash, without its being suspected."
fr: 'monsieur... mais quelque jeunesse inconsideree se glisse parfois derriere le rideau et releve un chassis sans y etre autorisee.'

eng: "I have often known it done myself."
fr: 'Je l'ai souvent vu faire moi-meme.'

eng: "Have you indeed, sir?--Bless me! ~~~ I never could have supposed it."
fr: '-- Est-ce possible, Monsieur, je ne l'aurais jamais cru ;'

eng: "But I live out of the world, and am often astonished at what I hear."
fr: 'mais je vis a l'ecart et je suis souvent etonne de ce que j'apprends.'

eng: "However, this does make a difference; and, perhaps, when we come to talk it over--"
fr: 'Neanmoins, cette circonstance merite consideration et peut-etre le moment venu...'

eng: "but these sort of things require a good deal of consideration."
fr: 'Ce genre de projet demande a etre murement pese ;'

eng: "One cannot resolve upon them in a hurry."
fr: 'on ne peut prendre une decision a la hate.'

eng: "If Mr. and Mrs. Weston will be so obliging as to call here one morning, we may talk it over, and see what can be done."
fr: 'Si M. et Mme Weston voulaient se donner la peine de venir me voir un de ces jours, nous pourrions examiner la question.'

eng: "But, unfortunately, sir, my time is so limited--"
fr: '-- Mais malheureusement, Monsieur, j'ai moi-meme si peu de temps...'

eng: "Oh!"
fr: '-- Il y aura,'

eng: "interrupted Emma, "there will be plenty of time for talking every thing over."
fr: 'interrompit Emma, tout le temps necessaire pour discuter le sujet ;'

eng: "There is no hurry at all."
fr: 'il n'y a aucune hate.'

eng: "If it can be contrived to be at the Crown, papa, it will be very convenient for the horses."
fr: 'Si l'on peut s'arranger a l'hotel de la Couronne, papa, ce sera bien commode pour les chevaux :'

eng: "They will be so near their own stable."
fr: 'ils seront tout pres de leur ecurie.'

eng: "So they will, my dear. That is a great thing."
fr: 'En effet, ma chere, c'est un point important ;'

eng: "Not that James ever complains; but it is right to spare our horses when we can."
fr: 'non pas que James se plaigne jamais, mais il importe de menager nos chevaux.'

eng: "If I could be sure of the rooms being thoroughly aired--"
fr: 'Si encore j'etais sur qu'on aurait soin de bien aerer le salon !'

eng: "but is Mrs. Stokes to be trusted?"
fr: 'Mais peut-on se fier a Mme Stokes ?'

eng: "I doubt it. ~~~ I do not know her, even by sight."
fr: 'J'en doute : je ne la connais meme pas de vue.'

eng: Do not you remember what Mr. Perry said, so many years ago, when I had the measles?
fr: M. Perry ne disait-il pas, quand j'ai eu la rougeole il y a tant d'annees : << Si Mlle Taylor prend la responsabilite de tenir Mlle Emma au chaud, il n'y a pas a se tourmenter ! >>

eng: 'If _Miss_ _Taylor_ undertakes to wrap Miss Emma up, you need not have any fears, sir.'
fr: << Si Mlle Taylor prend la responsabilite de tenir Mlle Emma au chaud, il n'y a pas a se tourmenter ! >>

eng: How often have I heard you speak of it as such a compliment to her!"
fr: Cette preuve de confiance vous avait frappe.

eng: "Aye, very true. Mr. Perry did say so. I shall never forget it.
fr: -- C'est bien vrai ! Je n'ai pas oublie.

eng: Poor little Emma! You were very bad with the measles; that is, you would have been very bad, but for Perry's great attention.
fr: Pauvre petite Emma, vous etiez bien malade ! Du moins, vous l'auriez ete sans les soins de Perry : il vint quatre fois par jour pendant une semaine.

eng: He came four times a day for a week.
fr: il vint quatre fois par jour pendant une semaine.

eng: He said, from the first, it was a very good sort--which was our great comfort; but the measles are a dreadful complaint.
fr: La rougeole est une terrible maladie.

eng: I hope whenever poor Isabella's little ones have the measles, she will send for Perry."
fr: J'espere qu'Isabelle, si ses petits enfants ont la rougeole, fera appeler Perry.

eng: "My father and Mrs. Weston are at the Crown at this moment," said Frank Churchill, "examining the capabilities of the house.
fr: Mon pere et Mme Weston sont en ce moment a l'hotel de la Couronne, en train d'etudier les lieux.

eng: I left them there and came on to Hartfield, impatient for your opinion, and hoping you might be persuaded to join them and give your advice on the spot.
fr: Ils desirent connaitre votre opinion, Mlle Woodhouse, et ils seraient heureux si vous consentiez a venir les rejoindre.

eng: I was desired to say so from both.
fr: Rien ne peut etre fait d'une facon definitive sans vous.

eng: It would be the greatest pleasure to them, if you could allow me to attend you there.
fr: Si vous le permettez, je vous accompagnerai jusqu'a l'hotel.

eng: They can do nothing satisfactorily without you."
fr: Rien ne peut etre fait d'une facon definitive sans vous.

eng: Emma was most happy to be called to such a council; and her father, engaging to think it all over while she was gone, the two young people set off together without delay for the Crown.
fr: Emma fut tres contente d'etre appelee a prendre part a ce conseil ; son pere promit de considerer le probleme pendant leur absence et les deux jeunes gens se mirent en route.

eng: There were Mr. and Mrs. Weston; delighted to see her and receive her approbation, very busy and very happy in their different way; she, in some little distress; and he, finding every thing perfect.
fr: M. et Mme Weston furent enchantes de l'approbation d'Emma ; ils etaient tres affaires ; Mme Weston n'etait pas absolument satisfaite ; mais lui trouvait tout parfait.

eng: "Emma," said she, "this paper is worse than I expected.
fr: -- Emma, dit Mme Weston, ce papier est en plus mauvais etat que je ne pensais :

eng: Look!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: in places you see it is dreadfully dirty; and the wainscot is more yellow and forlorn than any thing I could have imagined."
fr: par endroits il est extremement sale ; et la boiserie a une teinte jaune.

eng: "My dear, you are too particular," said her husband.
fr: -- Ma chere, vous etes trop meticuleuse, reprit son mari,

eng: "What does all that signify? You will see nothing of it by candlelight.
fr: c'est un detail sans importance. On n'y verra rien a la lumiere des bougies :

eng: It will be as clean as Randalls by candlelight.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: We never see any thing of it on our club-nights."
fr: nous ne nous apercevons jamais de rien les jours de nos reunions de whist !

eng: The ladies here probably exchanged looks which meant, "Men never know when things are dirty or not;" and the gentlemen perhaps thought each to himself, "Women will have their little nonsenses and needless cares."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: One perplexity, however, arose, which the gentlemen did not disdain.
fr: Une autre question se posa relativement a l'emplacement de la table du souper.

eng: It regarded a supper-room.
fr: L'unique chambre contigue a la salle de bal etait fort petite et devait servir de salon de jeu.

eng: At the time of the ballroom's being built, suppers had not been in question; and a small card-room adjoining, was the only addition.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: What was to be done?
fr: What was to be done?

eng: This card-room would be wanted as a card-room now; or, if cards were conveniently voted unnecessary by their four selves, still was it not too small for any comfortable supper?
fr: Cette piece etait fort petite et devait servir de salon de jeu. Une autre piece beaucoup plus vaste etait mise a leur disposition, mais elle etait situee a l'extremite d'un couloir.

eng: Another room of much better size might be secured for the purpose; but it was at the other end of the house, and a long awkward passage must be gone through to get at it.
fr: Une autre piece beaucoup plus vaste etait mise a leur disposition, mais elle etait situee a l'extremite d'un couloir.

eng: This made a difficulty.
fr: Mme Weston craignait les courants d'air pour les jeunes gens dans le passage ;

eng: Mrs. Weston was afraid of draughts for the young people in that passage; and neither Emma nor the gentlemen could tolerate the prospect of being miserably crowded at supper.
fr: dans un but de simplification, elle proposa de ne pas avoir un veritable souper, mais simplement un buffet avec des sandwiches, etc., dresse dans la petite chambre, mais cette idee fut aussitot ecartee comme pitoyable : un bal sans souper assis fut juge contraire a tous les droits de l'homme et de la femme ; Mme Weston dut promettre de ne plus y faire allusion.

eng: Mrs. Weston proposed having no regular supper; merely sandwiches, &c., set out in the little room; but that was scouted as a wretched suggestion.
fr: dans un but de simplification, elle proposa de ne pas avoir un veritable souper, mais simplement un buffet avec des sandwiches, etc., dresse dans la petite chambre, mais cette idee fut aussitot ecartee comme pitoyable :

eng: A private dance, without sitting down to supper, was pronounced an infamous fraud upon the rights of men and women; and Mrs. Weston must not speak of it again.
fr: un bal sans souper assis fut juge contraire a tous les droits de l'homme et de la femme ; Mme Weston dut promettre de ne plus y faire allusion.

eng: She then took another line of expediency, and looking into the doubtful room, observed, "I do not think it _is_ so very small. We shall not be many, you know."
fr: Elle changea alors d'expedient et dit : -- Il me semble qu'a la rigueur nous pourrions tous tenir ici ; nous ne serons pas si nombreux.

eng: And Mr. Weston at the same time, walking briskly with long steps through the passage, was calling out, "You talk a great deal of the length of this passage, my dear. It is a mere nothing after all; and not the least draught from the stairs."
fr: Mais Emma et les messieurs, etaient decides a etre installes confortablement pour souper. M. Weston se met a parcourir le couloir et cria : -- Vous avez parle de la longueur du couloir, ma chere, mais a bien considerer ce n'est rien du tout et on est a l'abri du vent de l'escalier.

eng: "I wish," said Mrs. Weston, "one could know which arrangement our guests in general would like best. To do what would be most generally pleasing must be our object--if one could but tell what that would be."
fr: -- Je voudrais bien savoir, dit Mme Weston, quel arrangement nos hotes prefereraient. Notre desir est de contenter tout le monde et si nous pouvions connaitre l'opinion generale, je serais plus tranquille.

eng: "Yes, very true," cried Frank, "very true.
fr: -- C'est juste, dit Frank,

eng: You want your neighbours' opinions. I do not wonder at you. If one could ascertain what the chief of them--the Coles, for instance. They are not far off. Shall I call upon them?
fr: on pourrait prendre l'avis de nos voisins, des Cole, par exemple, qui n'habitent pas loin. Irai-je les trouver ?

eng: Or Miss Bates? She is still nearer.--And I do not know whether Miss Bates is not as likely to understand the inclinations of the rest of the people as any body.
fr: Et aussi celui de Mlle Bates. Elle demeure encore plus pres. Il me semble que Mlle Bates serait assez capable de donner la note exacte, une sorte de moyenne ;

eng: I think we do want a larger council. Suppose I go and invite Miss Bates to join us?"
fr: si j'allais prier Mlle Bates de venir ?

eng: "Well--if you please," said Mrs. Weston rather hesitating, "if you think she will be of any use."
fr: -- Si vous croyez, reprit Mme Weston avec un peu d'hesitation, si vous croyez qu'elle peut nous etre utile.

eng: "You will get nothing to the purpose from Miss Bates," said Emma.
fr: -- Vous n'obtiendrez aucun eclaircissement de Mlle Bates, reprit Emma,

eng: "She will be all delight and gratitude, but she will tell you nothing.
fr: elle se confondra en remerciements et en expressions de reconnaissance, mais elle ne dira rien ;

eng: She will not even listen to your questions.'
fr: elle n'ecoutera meme pas vos questions.'

eng: "But she is so amusing, so extremely amusing! I am very fond of hearing Miss Bates talk."
fr: '-- Mais elle est si amusante, si extremement amusante ! J'aime beaucoup entendre parler Mlle Bates.'

eng: "And I need not bring the whole family, you know."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Here Mr. Weston joined them, and on hearing what was proposed, gave it his decided approbation.
fr: -- A ce moment, M. Weston arriva et ayant ete mis au courant de ce dont il s'agissait, donna son entiere approbation.

eng: "Aye, do, Frank.--Go and fetch Miss Bates, and let us end the matter at once."
fr: -- Certainement, Frank, allez chercher Mlle Bates ; elle approuvera notre plan, j'en suis sur ;

eng: "She will enjoy the scheme, I am sure; and I do not know a properer person for shewing us how to do away difficulties."
fr: je ne connais pas une personne plus apte a denouer les difficultes.

eng: "Fetch Miss Bates. We are growing a little too nice."
fr: Nous faisons trop d'embarras.

eng: "She is a standing lesson of how to be happy. But fetch them both."
fr: Elle nous enseignera la maniere d'etre content de tout. Mais, amenez-les toutes les deux.

eng: "Invite them both."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Both sir! Can the old lady?"
fr: -- Toutes les deux, Monsieur ! Est-ce que la vieille dame... ?

eng: "...The old lady!"
fr: -- La vieille dame !'

eng: And away he ran.
fr: Et il partit sur le champ.

eng: Long before he reappeared, attending the short, neat, brisk-moving aunt, and her elegant niece,--Mrs. Weston, like a sweet-tempered woman and a good wife, had examined the passage again, and found the evils of it much less than she had supposed before--indeed very trifling; and here ended the difficulties of decision.
fr: Bien avant le retour de Frank Churchill, Mme Weston avait examine de nouveau le couloir et en femme soumise s'etait rangee a l'avis de son mari ; en consequence il fut decide que la salle a manger serait utilisee.

eng: All the rest, in speculation at least, was perfectly smooth.
fr: Tout le reste du programme, du moins en theorie, paraissait extremement simple :

eng: All the minor arrangements of table and chair, lights and music, tea and supper, made themselves; or were left as mere trifles to be settled at any time between Mrs. Weston and Mrs. Stokes.
fr: on se mit d'accord sur l'eclairage, la musique, le the, le souper ; Mme Weston et Mme Stokes devaient resoudre les petites difficultes qui pourraient se presenter par la suite.

eng: Every body invited, was certainly to come; Frank had already written to Enscombe to propose staying a few days beyond his fortnight, which could not possibly be refused.
fr: On savait pouvoir compter sur tous les invites ; Frank avait deja ecrit a Enscombe pour demander de rester quelques jours de plus et il escomptait une reponse favorable.

eng: And a delightful dance it was to be.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Most cordially, when Miss Bates arrived, did she agree that it must.
fr: Mlle Bates, en arrivant, ne put qu'apporter ses felicitations :

eng: As a counsellor she was not wanted; but as an approver, (a much safer character,) she was truly welcome.
fr: elles furent du reste beaucoup mieux accueillies que ne l'eussent probablement ete ses conseils.

eng: Her approbation, at once general and minute, warm and incessant, could not but please; and for another half-hour they were all walking to and fro, between the different rooms, some suggesting, some attending, and all in happy enjoyment of the future.
fr: Pendant une demi-heure encore, ils allerent et vinrent a travers les pieces et diverses ameliorations de detail furent suggerees.

eng: The party did not break up without Emma's being positively secured for the two first dances by the hero of the evening, nor without her overhearing Mr. Weston whisper to his wife, "He has asked her, my dear. That's right.
fr: Au moment de l'adieu, Frank Churchill renouvela son invitation a Emma pour les premieres danses ; peu apres celle-ci entendit M. Weston murmurer a l'oreille de sa femme : << Naturellement, ma chere, il l'a invitee ! >>

eng: I knew he would!"
fr: XXX

eng: CHAPTER XII
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: One thing only was wanting to make the prospect of the ball completely satisfactory to Emma--its being fixed for a day within the granted term of Frank Churchill's stay in Surry; for, in spite of Mr. Weston's confidence, she could not think it so very impossible that the Churchills might not allow their nephew to remain a day beyond his fortnight.
fr: Au bout de quelques jours arriva une lettre d'Enscombe accordant l'autorisation demandee ; les termes de la reponse indiquaient que les Churchill n'etaient pas satisfaits de cette prolongation de sejour, mais ils ne s'y opposerent pas.

eng: But this was not judged feasible.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The preparations must take their time, nothing could be properly ready till the third week were entered on, and for a few days they must be planning, proceeding and hoping in uncertainty--at the risk--in her opinion, the great risk, of its being all in vain.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Enscombe however was gracious, gracious in fact, if not in word.
fr: Tout paraissait donc marcher a souhait.

eng: His wish of staying longer evidently did not please; but it was not opposed.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: All was safe and prosperous; and as the removal of one solicitude generally makes way for another, Emma, being now certain of her ball, began to adopt as the next vexation Mr. Knightley's provoking indifference about it.
fr: La bonne humeur etait generale.

eng: Either because he did not dance himself, or because the plan had been formed without his being consulted, he seemed resolved that it should not interest him, determined against its exciting any present curiosity, or affording him any future amusement.
fr: Jane Fairfax elle-meme se montrait enthousiaste, elle en devenait animee, franche et dit spontanement : << Oh ! mademoiselle Woodhouse j'espere qu'il n'arrivera rien pour empecher cette reunion ; je m'en fais, je l'avoue, un veritable plaisir. >>

eng: To her voluntary communications Emma could get no more approving reply, than, "Very well.
fr: Seul M. Knightley continuait a ne laisser paraitre aucun interet. En reponse aux communications d'Emma, il se contentait de repondre : -- Tres bien.

eng: If the Westons think it worth while to be at all this trouble for a few hours of noisy entertainment, I have nothing to say against it, but that they shall not chuse pleasures for me.--Oh! yes, I must be there; I could not refuse; and I will keep as much awake as I can; but I would rather be at home, looking over William Larkins's week's account; much rather, I confess.
fr: S'il plait aux Weston de se donner tant de peine pour quelques heures d'un amusement bruyant, c'est leur affaire ; mais il ne depend pas d'eux que j'y prenne plaisir. Naturellement, je ne peux pas refuser ; je ferai de mon mieux pour rester eveille ; toutefois, j'aurais prefere de beaucoup rester a la maison pour examiner les comptes de William Larkins.

eng: Pleasure in seeing dancing!--not I, indeed--I never look at it--I do not know who does.
fr: Je ne danse pas et je ne trouve aucun charme au role de spectateur ;

eng: Fine dancing, I believe, like virtue, must be its own reward.
fr: du reste, la plupart de ceux qui ne prennent pas une part active au bal partagent mon indifference : bien danser procure sans doute une satisfaction interieure comme la vertu !

eng: Those who are standing by are usually thinking of something very different.
fr: Helas ! toute raison de divergence avec M. Knightley devait bientot disparaitre :

eng: This Emma felt was aimed at her; and it made her quite angry.
fr: apres deux jours d'une fausse securite, Frank Churchill recut une lettre de son oncle le priant de revenir sans delai :

eng: It was not in compliment to Jane Fairfax however that he was so indifferent, or so indignant; he was not guided by _her_ feelings in reprobating the ball, for _she_ enjoyed the thought of it to an extraordinary degree.
fr: << Mme Churchill etait tres malade ; deja fort souffrante en repondant a son neveu, elle n'avait pas voulu, dans son desir de lui eviter un desappointement, faire allusion a son etat de sante. >>

eng: It made her animated--open hearted--she voluntarily said;-- "Oh! Miss Woodhouse, I hope nothing may happen to prevent the ball. What a disappointment it would be!
fr: Emma fut aussitot mise au courant par un billet de Mme Weston : << Frank ira a Highbury apres dejeuner prendre conge de ses amis. Vous le verrez d'ici peu a Hartfield. >>

eng: I do look forward to it, I own, with _very_ great pleasure."
fr: Cette triste communication mit fin au dejeuner d'Emma ; ses regrets etaient proportionnes au plaisir qu'elle s'etait promis de cette fete.

eng: It was not to oblige Jane Fairfax therefore that he would have preferred the society of William Larkins.
fr: Les sentiments de M. Woodhouse etaient tres differents : il se preoccupait particulierement de la maladie de Mme Churchill et aurait voulu savoir le traitement qu'elle suivait.

eng: No!--she was more and more convinced that Mrs. Weston was quite mistaken in that surmise.
fr: Frank Churchill se fit un peu attendre ; il arriva enfin : la tristesse et l'abattement etaient peints sur son visage ; apres les salutations d'usage, il s'assit et garda le silence pendant quelques instants ; mais il dit :

eng: There was a great deal of friendly and of compassionate attachment on his side--but no love.
fr: -- Je ne m'attendais pas a vous dire adieu aujourd'hui !

eng: Alas! there was soon no leisure for quarrelling with Mr. Knightley.
fr: -- Mais vous reviendrez, dit Emma, ce ne sera pas votre seule visite a Randalls ?

eng: Two days of joyful security were immediately followed by the over-throw of every thing.
fr: -- Je ferai certainement tout mon possible ; ce sera ma preoccupation continuelle et si mon oncle et ma tante vont au printemps a la ville...

eng: A letter arrived from Mr. Churchill to urge his nephew's instant return.
fr: Mais j'ai bien peur que ce soit une habitude perdue : l'annee derniere ils n'ont pas bouge.

eng: Mrs. Churchill was unwell--far too unwell to do without him; she had been in a very suffering state (so said her husband) when writing to her nephew two days before, though from her usual unwillingness to give pain, and constant habit of never thinking of herself, she had not mentioned it; but now she was too ill to trifle, and must entreat him to set off for Enscombe without delay.
fr: -- Il nous faut donc renoncer a notre pauvre bal ?

eng: The substance of this letter was forwarded to Emma, in a note from Mrs. Weston, instantly.
fr: -- Ah ! Pourquoi avons-nous tant attendu ? Que n'avons-nous saisi le plaisir lorsqu'il etait a portee. Vous l'aviez predit !

eng: As to his going, it was inevitable. He must be gone within a few hours, though without feeling any real alarm for his aunt, to lessen his repugnance.
fr: Helas ! Vous avez toujours raison.

eng: He knew her illnesses; they never occurred but for her own convenience.
fr: -- Je regrette bien d'avoir eu raison ; j'aurais de beaucoup prefere etre heureuse que perspicace.

eng: Mrs. Weston added, "that he could only allow himself time to hurry to Highbury, after breakfast, and take leave of the few friends there whom he could suppose to feel any interest in him; and that he might be expected at Hartfield very soon."
fr: -- De toute facon le bal aura lieu ; mon pere compte bien que ce n'est que partie remise. N'oubliez pas votre promesse. Emma sourit gracieusement.

eng: This wretched note was the finale of Emma's breakfast.
fr: Chaque journee augmentait mon regret de partir. Heureux ceux qui restent a Highbury !

eng: When once it had been read, there was no doing any thing, but lament and exclaim.
fr: -- Puisque vous nous jugez si favorablement a present, dit Emma, je me permettrai de vous demander si vous n'etiez pas a un moment donne, un peu prevenu contre nous ? Vous vous seriez decide a venir depuis longtemps si vous aviez eu une bonne opinion de Highbury.

eng: The loss of the ball--the loss of the young man--and all that the young man might be feeling!--It was too wretched!--Such a delightful evening as it would have been!--Every body so happy! and she and her partner the happiest!--"I said it would be so," was the only consolation.
fr: Il se mit a rire en protestant contre cette allegation.

eng: Her father's feelings were quite distinct.
fr: -- Et il faut que vous partiez ce matin ?

eng: He thought principally of Mrs. Churchill's illness, and wanted to know how she was treated; and as for the ball, it was shocking to have dear Emma disappointed; but they would all be safer at home.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Emma was ready for her visitor some time before he appeared; but if this reflected at all upon his impatience, his sorrowful look and total want of spirits when he did come might redeem him.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He felt the going away almost too much to speak of it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: His dejection was most evident.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He sat really lost in thought for the first few minutes; and when rousing himself, it was only to say, "Of all horrid things, leave-taking is the worst."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "But you will come again," said Emma. "This will not be your only visit to Randalls."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Ah!--(shaking his head)--the uncertainty of when I may be able to return!--I shall try for it with a zeal!--It will be the object of all my thoughts and cares!--and if my uncle and aunt go to town this spring--but I am afraid--they did not stir last spring--I am afraid it is a custom gone for ever."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Our poor ball must be quite given up."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Ah! that ball!--why did we wait for any thing?--why not seize the pleasure at once?--How often is happiness destroyed by preparation, foolish preparation!--You told us it would be so.--Oh! Miss Woodhouse, why are you always so right?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Indeed, I am very sorry to be right in this instance.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I would much rather have been merry than wise."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "If I can come again, we are still to have our ball.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: My father depends on it. Do not forget your engagement."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Emma looked graciously.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Such a fortnight as it has been!" he continued; "every day more precious and more delightful than the day before!--every day making me less fit to bear any other place. Happy those, who can remain at Highbury!"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "As you do us such ample justice now," said Emma, laughing, "I will venture to ask, whether you did not come a little doubtfully at first? Do not we rather surpass your expectations?
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I am sure we do.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I am sure you did not much expect to like us. You would not have been so long in coming, if you had had a pleasant idea of Highbury."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He laughed rather consciously; and though denying the sentiment, Emma was convinced that it had been so.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "And you must be off this very morning?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I am almost afraid that every moment will bring him.
fr: Je crains de le voir arriver d'un instant a l'autre.

eng: Not five minutes to spare even for your friends Miss Fairfax and Miss Bates? How unlucky!
fr: Quoi ! Vous n'aurez meme pas cinq minutes a consacrer a vos amies, Mlle Fairfax et Mlle Bates ? C'est bien facheux !

eng: Miss Bates's powerful, argumentative mind might have strengthened yours.
fr: L'immuable logique de Mlle Bates aurait pu avoir une bonne influence sur votre esprit a cette heure de desarroi !

eng: Yes--I _have_ called there; passing the door, I thought it better. It was a right thing to do.
fr: J'ai deja pris conge de ces dames ; en passant devant la porte je suis entre comme il convenait. Je voulais rester trois minutes, mais j'ai ete force de prolonger ma visite et d'attendre le retour de Mlle Bates qui etait sortie ;

eng: I went in for three minutes, and was detained by Miss Bates's being absent. ~~~ She was out; and I felt it impossible not to wait till she came in.
fr: c'est une femme dont il est difficile de ne pas se moquer, mais je n'aurais pas voulu l'offenser. J'ai profite de l'occasion...

eng: She is a woman that one may, that one _must_ laugh at; but that one would not wish to slight.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It was better to pay my visit, then"-- He hesitated, got up, walked to a window. ~~~
fr: Il hesita, se leva et alla a la fenetre.

eng: "In short," said he, "perhaps, Miss Woodhouse--I think you can hardly be quite without suspicion"--
fr: -- En un mot, dit-il, mademoiselle Woodhouse, il n'est pas possible que vous n'ayez pas quelques soupcons...

eng: He looked at her, as if wanting to read her thoughts.
fr: Il la regarda comme pour lire dans la pensee de la jeune fille.

eng: She hardly knew what to say. It seemed like the forerunner of something absolutely serious, which she did not wish.
fr: Emma se sentait mal a l'aise ; ces paroles semblaient le prelude d'une declaration et elle ne desirait pas l'ecouter.

eng: Forcing herself to speak, therefore, in the hope of putting it by, she calmly said, "You are quite in the right; it was most natural to pay your visit, then"--
fr: Se forcant a parler dans l'espoir d'amener une diversion elle reprit : -- Vous avez eu bien raison ; il etait tout naturel de profiter de votre passage a travers Highbury pour faire cette visite.

eng: He was silent. She believed he was looking at her; probably reflecting on what she had said, and trying to understand the manner.
fr: Il se tut, semblant chercher a deviner le sens de cette reponse.

eng: She heard him sigh. ~~~ It was natural for him to feel that he had _cause_ to sigh.
fr: Puis elle l'entendit soupirer : evidemment il se rendait compte qu'elle ne voulait pas l'encourager.

eng: He could not believe her to be encouraging him.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: A few awkward moments passed, and he sat down again; and in a more determined manner said, "It was something to feel that all the rest of my time might be given to Hartfield. My regard for Hartfield is most warm"--
fr: La gene du jeune homme persista quelques moments encore, puis il dit d'un ton plus decide : -- De cette facon, j'ai pu consacrer le reste de mon temps a Hartfield. Il s'arreta de nouveau, l'air embarrasse.

eng: He stopt again, rose again, and seemed quite embarrassed.--He was more in love with her than Emma had supposed; and who can say how it might have ended, if his father had not made his appearance?
fr: Emma se demandait comment cette scene se terminerait lorsque M. Weston apparut suivi de M. Woodhouse.

eng: Mr. Woodhouse soon followed; and the necessity of exertion made him composed. A very few minutes more, however, completed the present trial.
fr: Apres quelques minutes de conversation, M. Weston se leva et annonca qu'il etait temps de partir.

eng: Mr. Weston, always alert when business was to be done, and as incapable of procrastinating any evil that was inevitable, as of foreseeing any that was doubtful, said, "It was time to go;" and the young man, though he might and did sigh, could not but agree, to take leave.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I shall hear about you all," said he; "that is my chief consolation. I shall hear of every thing that is going on among you. I have engaged Mrs. Weston to correspond with me. ~~~ She has been so kind as to promise it. ~~~ Oh! the blessing of a female correspondent, when one is really interested in the absent!--she will tell me every thing. In her letters I shall be at dear Highbury again."
fr: -- J'aurai de vos nouvelles a tous, dit Frank Churchill. Je saurai tout ce qui se passe ici ; j'ai demande a Mme Weston de m'ecrire et elle a bien voulu me le promettre ; en lisant ses lettres, je me croirai encore a Highbury !

eng: A very friendly shake of the hand, a very earnest "Good-bye," closed the speech, and the door had soon shut out Frank Churchill.
fr: Une tres cordiale poignee de main accompagnee de souhaits reciproques mit fin a l'entretien, et la porte se referma sur les deux hommes.

eng: Short had been the notice--short their meeting; he was gone; and Emma felt so sorry to part, and foresaw so great a loss to their little society from his absence as to begin to be afraid of being too sorry, and feeling it too much. It was a sad change. ~~~
fr: Emma ne tarda pas a s'apercevoir des consequences de ce depart ; les rencontres avec Frank Churchill avaient ete presque journalieres ; sans aucun doute sa presence a Randalls avait apporte une grande animation : chaque jour elle attendait sa visite et elle etait sure de le trouver aussi attentif, aussi plein d'entrain !

eng: They had been meeting almost every day since his arrival. Certainly his being at Randalls had given great spirit to the last two weeks--indescribable spirit; the idea, the expectation of seeing him which every morning had brought, the assurance of his attentions, his liveliness, his manners!
fr: Cette derniere quinzaine avait ete agreablement employee et le retour a la vie courante d'Harfield ne pouvait manquer de paraitre triste.

eng: It had been a very happy fortnight, and forlorn must be the sinking from it into the common course of Hartfield days.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: To complete every other recommendation, he had _almost_ told her that he loved her. What strength, or what constancy of affection he might be subject to, was another point; but at present she could not doubt his having a decidedly warm admiration, a conscious preference of herself; and this persuasion, joined to all the rest, made her think that she _must_ be a little in love with him, in spite of every previous determination against it.
fr: De plus, au cours de leur derniere entrevue Frank Churchill lui avait laisse entendre qu'il l'aimait et de ce fait le prestige du jeune homme se trouvait rehausse. Emma cherchait a se rendre compte de l'etat de son propre coeur.

eng: "I certainly must," said she. "This sensation of listlessness, weariness, stupidity, this disinclination to sit down and employ myself, this feeling of every thing's being dull and insipid about the house!-- I must be in love; I should be the oddest creature in the world if I were not--for a few weeks at least. ~~~ Well!'
fr: -- Je dois certainement etre amoureuse, se dit-elle ; cette sensation de fatigue, d'ennui, ce degout de m'asseoir et de m'appliquer a une tache quelconque, ce sont la tous les symptomes de l'amour.'

eng: It was some days before she saw Jane Fairfax, to judge of her honest regret in this woeful change; but when they did meet, her composure was odious.
fr: Emma s'attendait a ce que Jane Fairfax prit une part active aux regrets causes par ce contre-temps, mais a quelques jours de la elle put constater la parfaite indifference de la jeune fille ;

eng: She had been particularly unwell, however, suffering from headache to a degree, which made her aunt declare, that had the ball taken place, she did not think Jane could have attended it; and it was charity to impute some of her unbecoming indifference to the languor of ill-health.
fr: celle-ci avait ete assez souffrante de maux de tete et Mlle Bates declara que de toute facon sa niece n'aurait pu assister au bal.

eng: CHAPTER XIII Emma continued to entertain no doubt of her being in love.
fr: L'inconcevable sang-froid dont Jane fit preuve dans cette circonstance fut pour Emma un nouveau grief ajoute a beaucoup d'autres. XXXI

eng: Her ideas only varied as to the how much.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: At first, she thought it was a good deal; and afterwards, but little.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She had great pleasure in hearing Frank Churchill talked of; and, for his sake, greater pleasure than ever in seeing Mr. and Mrs. Weston; she was very often thinking of him, and quite impatient for a letter, that she might know how he was, how were his spirits, how was his aunt, and what was the chance of his coming to Randalls again this spring.
fr: Emma reconnut bientot que les ravages causes par Frank Churchill etaient peu considerables. Elle avait grand plaisir a entendre parler de lui ; elle esperait qu'une visite au printemps serait possible

eng: But, on the other hand, she could not admit herself to be unhappy, nor, after the first morning, to be less disposed for employment than usual; she was still busy and cheerful; and, pleasing as he was, she could yet imagine him to have faults; and farther, though thinking of him so much, and, as she sat drawing or working, forming a thousand amusing schemes for the progress and close of their attachment, fancying interesting dialogues, and inventing elegant letters; the conclusion of every imaginary declaration on his side was that she _refused_ _him_.
fr: mais elle n'etait nullement malheureuse ; le premier moment passe elle s'etait mise a vaquer gaiement, comme d'habitude, a ses occupations. Tout en rendant justice aux qualites du jeune homme elle voyait clairement ses defauts ; et de plus, si le souvenir de Frank Churchill occupait souvent sa pensee, aux heures de loisir, les plans, les dialogues, les lettres, les declarations qu'elle imaginait aboutissaient invariablement a un refus de sa part.

eng: Their affection was always to subside into friendship.
fr: Ils se separaient avec de tendres paroles, mais la separation etait fatale :

eng: Every thing tender and charming was to mark their parting; but still they were to part.
fr: elle se rendait compte que, malgre sa resolution de ne pas quitter son pere, de ne jamais se marier, un attachement serieux lui aurait rendu la lutte plus penible.

eng: When she became sensible of this, it struck her that she could not be very much in love; for in spite of her previous and fixed determination never to quit her father, never to marry, a strong attachment certainly must produce more of a struggle than she could foresee in her own feelings.
fr: << Il n'appert pas que je fasse grand usage du mot sacrifice, se dit-elle, dans mes aimables refus, ni dans mes spirituelles reponses,

eng: "I do not find myself making any use of the word _sacrifice_," said she.--"In not one of all my clever replies, my delicate negatives, is there any allusion to making a sacrifice.
fr: Frank Churchil evidemment n'est pas necessaire a mon bonheur et je m'en rejouis.

eng: I do suspect that he is not really necessary to my happiness.
fr: D'autre part, il est, je crois, tres amoureux et s'il revient, je me tiendrai sur mes gardes et j'eviterai toute apparence d'encouragement.

eng: So much the better.
fr: Ce serait inexcusable d'agir autrement etant decidee a ne pas l'epouser.

eng: I certainly will not persuade myself to feel more than I do.
fr: Du reste, je ne pense pas qu'il ait pu a aucun moment, se meprendre sur mon attitude ;

eng: I am quite enough in love.
fr: dans ce cas, ses regards et son langage eussent ete tres differents a l'heure de la separation :

eng: I should be sorry to be more."
fr: neanmoins, je m'observerai encore plus. Je ne m'imagine pas qu'il soit capable de constance : ses sentiments sont chauds, mais je les crois sujets a variation.

eng: Upon the whole, she was equally contented with her view of his feelings.
fr: Dieu merci ! ~~~ mon bonheur n'est pas serieusement en jeu.

eng: "_He_ is undoubtedly very much in love--every thing denotes it--very much in love indeed!--and when he comes again, if his affection continue, I must be on my guard not to encourage it.--It would be most inexcusable to do otherwise, as my own mind is quite made up.
fr: Tout le monde, dit-on, doit etre amoureux une fois dans sa vie et me voici quitte a bon compte ! >>

eng: Not that I imagine he can think I have been encouraging him hitherto.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: No, if he had believed me at all to share his feelings, he would not have been so wretched.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Could he have thought himself encouraged, his looks and language at parting would have been different.--Still, however, I must be on my guard.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: This is in the supposition of his attachment continuing what it now is; but I do not know that I expect it will; I do not look upon him to be quite the sort of man--I do not altogether build upon his steadiness or constancy.--His feelings are warm, but I can imagine them rather changeable.--Every consideration of the subject, in short, makes me thankful that my happiness is not more deeply involved.--I shall do very well again after a little while--and then, it will be a good thing over; for they say every body is in love once in their lives, and I shall have been let off easily."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: When his letter to Mrs. Weston arrived, Emma had the perusal of it; and she read it with a degree of pleasure and admiration which made her at first shake her head over her own sensations, and think she had undervalued their strength.
fr: Quand Mme Weston apporta a Hartfield la premiere lettre de son beau-fils, Emma la parcourut aussitot avec plaisir et interet :

eng: It was a long, well-written letter, giving the particulars of his journey and of his feelings, expressing all the affection, gratitude, and respect which was natural and honourable, and describing every thing exterior and local that could be supposed attractive, with spirit and precision.
fr: c'etait une longue missive et une description imagee de son voyage. Le jeune homme s'adressait a Mme Weston avec une veritable affection et la transition de Highbury a Enscombe, le contraste entre les deux endroits au point de vue des principaux avantages de la vie etaient indiques autant que les convenances le permettaient.

eng: No suspicious flourishes now of apology or concern; it was the language of real feeling towards Mrs. Weston; and the transition from Highbury to Enscombe, the contrast between the places in some of the first blessings of social life was just enough touched on to shew how keenly it was felt, and how much more might have been said but for the restraints of propriety.--The charm of her own name was not wanting.
fr: Le nom de Mlle Woodhouse apparaissait a plusieurs reprises, mele a une allusion aimable, a un compliment, a un rappel d'un propos tenu par la jeune fille.

eng: _Miss_ _Woodhouse_ appeared more than once, and never without a something of pleasing connexion, either a compliment to her taste, or a remembrance of what she had said; and in the very last time of its meeting her eye, unadorned as it was by any such broad wreath of gallantry, she yet could discern the effect of her influence and acknowledge the greatest compliment perhaps of all conveyed.
fr: En post-scriptum il avait ajoute : << Je n'ai pas eu mardi un instant de libre comme vous le savez pour saluer la petite amie de Mlle Woodhouse ; veuillez transmettre a miss Smith mes excuses et mes adieux. >>

eng: Compressed into the very lowest vacant corner were these words--"I had not a spare moment on Tuesday, as you know, for Miss Woodhouse's beautiful little friend.
fr: Emma gouta la delicatesse de cette attention detournee dont Harriet n'etait que le pretexte.

eng: Pray make my excuses and adieus to her."
fr: Mme Churchill allait mieux, mais il ne pouvait, meme en imagination, fixer une date pour son retour a Randalls.

eng: This, Emma could not doubt, was all for herself.
fr: Emma replia la lettre et la rendit a Mme Weston.

eng: Harriet was remembered only from being _her_ friend.
fr: Apres comme avant cette lecture, elle sentait pouvoir fort bien se passer de Frank Churchill et elle souhaita que ce dernier apprit a se passer de Mlle Woodhouse.

eng: His information and prospects as to Enscombe were neither worse nor better than had been anticipated; Mrs. Churchill was recovering, and he dared not yet, even in his own imagination, fix a time for coming to Randalls again.
fr: L'arrivee de Frank Churchill avait ete pendant une quinzaine de jours le sujet principal des conversations a Highbury, mais des la disparition de ce dernier les faits et gestes de M. Elton reprirent leur ancien interet.

eng: Gratifying, however, and stimulative as was the letter in the material part, its sentiments, she yet found, when it was folded up and returned to Mrs. Weston, that it had not added any lasting warmth, that she could still do without the writer, and that he must learn to do without her.
fr: ~~~ Le jour du mariage fut bientot fixe.

eng: Her intentions were unchanged.
fr: Bientot M. Elton serait de retour avec sa femme.

eng: Her resolution of refusal only grew more interesting by the addition of a scheme for his subsequent consolation and happiness.
fr: Emma fut peniblement affectee en apprenant cette nouvelle.

eng: His recollection of Harriet, and the words which clothed it, the "beautiful little friend," suggested to her the idea of Harriet's succeeding her in his affections.
fr: Sans doute le moral d'Henriette s'etait fortifie et la perspective du bal de M. Weston avait grandement contribue a apaiser ses regrets ; mais Emma craignait qu'elle n'eut pas encore atteint le degre d'indifference necessaire pour affronter les evenements actuels.

eng: Was it impossible?--No.--Harriet undoubtedly was greatly his inferior in understanding; but he had been very much struck with the loveliness of her face and the warm simplicity of her manner; and all the probabilities of circumstance and connexion were in her favour.--For Harriet, it would be advantageous and delightful indeed.
fr: En effet, la pauvre Henriette fut bientot dans une disposition d'esprit necessitant toute la patience d'Emma : celle-ci considerait comme son devoir le plus strict de donner a son amie toutes les preuves d'affection possibles ;

eng: "I must not dwell upon it," said she.--"I must not think of it.
fr: pourtant c'etait un travail ingrat que de precher sans produire jamais aucun effet : Henriette ecoutait toujours avec soumission : << C'est tres juste, c'est exactement ainsi ; ce n'est pas la peine de penser a eux >>,

eng: I know the danger of indulging such speculations.
fr: mais le resultat etait nul et, au bout d'une demi-heure, Henriette etait aussi anxieuse et inquiete qu'auparavant.

eng: But stranger things have happened; and when we cease to care for each other as we do now, it will be the means of confirming us in that sort of true disinterested friendship which I can already look forward to with pleasure."
fr: A bout de ressources Emma chercha a faire vibrer une autre corde chez Henriette et elle lui dit : -- En vous laissant aller a etre si malheureuse a cause du mariage de M. Elton vous ne pouvez me faire sentir plus durement l'erreur dans laquelle je suis tombee.

eng: It was well to have a comfort in store on Harriet's behalf, though it might be wise to let the fancy touch it seldom; for evil in that quarter was at hand.
fr: C'est moi qui suis responsable de tout ; je ne l'ai pas oublie, je vous assure ; trompee moi-meme je vous ai trompee a mon tour ; ce sera pour moi un sujet de triste meditation.

eng: As Frank Churchill's arrival had succeeded Mr. Elton's engagement in the conversation of Highbury, as the latest interest had entirely borne down the first, so now upon Frank Churchill's disappearance, Mr. Elton's concerns were assuming the most irresistible form.--His wedding-day was named.
fr: Henriette fut trop touchee de ce discours pour pouvoir faire mieux que de protester par quelques monosyllabes. Emma continua : -- Je ne vous ai jamais dit, Henriette : Faites des efforts a cause de moi, pensez moins, parlez moins de M. Elton par egard pour moi.

eng: He would soon be among them again; Mr. Elton and his bride.
fr: Vous aviez d'autres motifs d'agir ainsi et plus graves : j'ai fait appel a votre raison vous representant la necessite de prendre l'habitude de rester maitre de soi, l'importance de ne pas provoquer les soupcons des autres, l'urgence de sauvegarder votre sante.

eng: There was hardly time to talk over the first letter from Enscombe before "Mr. Elton and his bride" was in every body's mouth, and Frank Churchill was forgotten.
fr: Mon seul but etait de vous eviter des souffrances inutiles.

eng: Emma grew sick at the sound.
fr: Peut-etre, pourtant, ai-je quelquefois pense qu'Henriette ne pouvait pas oublier les egards que l'affection doit inspirer.

eng: She had had three weeks of happy exemption from Mr. Elton; and Harriet's mind, she had been willing to hope, had been lately gaining strength.
fr: Cet appel aux sentiments d'Henriette fut en partie couronne de succes. L'idee de manquer de reconnaissance et de consideration pour Mlle Woodhouse, la rendit tout a fait malheureuse : -- Vous ayez ete pour moi la meilleure des amies !

eng: With Mr. Weston's ball in view at least, there had been a great deal of insensibility to other things; but it was now too evident that she had not attained such a state of composure as could stand against the actual approach--new carriage, bell-ringing, and all.
fr: Personne ne vous vaut ! Je n'aime personne autant que vous ! Je sais combien j'ai ete ingrate, Mlle Woodhouse !

eng: Poor Harriet was in a flutter of spirits which required all the reasonings and soothings and attentions of every kind that Emma could give.
fr: Ces protestations appuyees de la plus tendre mimique toucherent le coeur d'Emma. << La spontaneite d'un coeur aimant a un charme incomparable, se dit-elle ensuite a elle-meme.

eng: Emma felt that she could not do too much for her, that Harriet had a right to all her ingenuity and all her patience; but it was heavy work to be for ever convincing without producing any effect, for ever agreed to, without being able to make their opinions the same.
fr: C'est la nature affectueuse de mon pere et d'Isabelle qui les font aimer de tous. Je n'ai pas ces qualites, mais je sais les apprecier et les respecter. Henriette m'est de beaucoup superieure a ce point de vue.

eng: Harriet listened submissively, and said "it was very true--it was just as Miss Woodhouse described--it was not worth while to think about them--and she would not think about them any longer" but no change of subject could avail, and the next half-hour saw her as anxious and restless about the Eltons as before.
fr: Chere Henriette, je ne voudrais pas vous changer pour la plus intelligente des creatures humaines ! >> XXXII

eng: At last Emma attacked her on another ground.
fr: Ce fut dans l'eglise d'Highbury que Mme Elton s'offrit pour la premiere fois aux regards :

eng: "Your allowing yourself to be so occupied and so unhappy about Mr. Elton's marrying, Harriet, is the strongest reproach you can make _me_.
fr: cette apparition suffit a interrompre les devotions, mais non pas a satisfaire la curiosite.

eng: You could not give me a greater reproof for the mistake I fell into.
fr: Emma tenait a presenter sans delai ses felicitations ; elle se decida a amener Henriette avec elle afin d'adoucir pour son amie, dans la mesure du possible, l'emoi de la premiere entrevue.

eng: It was all my doing, I know.
fr: Neanmoins, Henriette se comporta fort bien et ne laissa pas percer son emotion : elle etait seulement plus pale et plus silencieuse que de coutume.

eng: I have not forgotten it, I assure you.--Deceived myself, I did very miserably deceive you--and it will be a painful reflection to me for ever.
fr: Naturellement, la visite fut courte, la gene etait inevitable de part et d'autre.

eng: Do not imagine me in danger of forgetting it."
fr: Dans ces conditions, Emma se promit de ne pas porter un jugement hatif sur la jeune femme ; la premiere impression n'etait pas favorable : chez une etrangere, une jeune mariee, il y avait exces d'aisance ;

eng: Harriet felt this too much to utter more than a few words of eager exclamation.
fr: la tournure etait agreable, le visage egalement, mais Emma ne discerna, ni dans les traits, ni dans le maintien, aucune distinction naturelle.

eng: Emma continued, "I have not said, exert yourself Harriet for my sake; think less, talk less of Mr. Elton for my sake; because for your own sake rather, I would wish it to be done, for the sake of what is more important than my comfort, a habit of self-command in you, a consideration of what is your duty, an attention to propriety, an endeavour to avoid the suspicions of others, to save your health and credit, and restore your tranquillity.
fr: Quant a M. Elton, elle etait disposee a se montrer indulgente : les visites de noce sont, de toute facon, une epreuve redoutable ; il faut une extreme bonne grace a un homme pour bien s'acquitter de sa fonction.

eng: These are the motives which I have been pressing on you.
fr: Le role de la femme est plus facile : elle a toujours le privilege de la timidite.

eng: They are very important--and sorry I am that you cannot feel them sufficiently to act upon them.
fr: Dans ce cas particulier, il convenait de tenir compte a M. Elton de la situation particulierement delicate ou il se trouvait : n'etait-il pas entoure de la femme qu'il venait d'epouser, de la jeune fille qu'il avait demandee en mariage et de celle qu'on lui avait destinee ?

eng: My being saved from pain is a very secondary consideration.
fr: Emma lui reconnaissait bien volontiers le droit d'etre mal a l'aise et de mettre quelque affectation a ne le point paraitre.

eng: I want you to save yourself from greater pain.
fr: -- Eh bien, Mlle Woodhouse, dit Henriette en quittant la maison, eh bien, que pensez-vous de Mme Elton ? N'est-elle pas charmante ?

eng: Perhaps I may sometimes have felt that Harriet would not forget what was due--or rather what would be kind by me."
fr: Emma hesita un moment et repondit : -- Oh oui, certainement, une tres aimable jeune femme. -- Je la trouve tres jolie.

eng: This appeal to her affections did more than all the rest.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The idea of wanting gratitude and consideration for Miss Woodhouse, whom she really loved extremely, made her wretched for a while, and when the violence of grief was comforted away, still remained powerful enough to prompt to what was right and support her in it very tolerably.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "You, who have been the best friend I ever had in my life--Want gratitude to you!--Nobody is equal to you!--I care for nobody as I do for you!--Oh!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Miss Woodhouse, how ungrateful I have been!"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Such expressions, assisted as they were by every thing that look and manner could do, made Emma feel that she had never loved Harriet so well, nor valued her affection so highly before.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "There is no charm equal to tenderness of heart," said she afterwards to herself.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "There is nothing to be compared to it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Warmth and tenderness of heart, with an affectionate, open manner, will beat all the clearness of head in the world, for attraction, I am sure it will.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It is tenderness of heart which makes my dear father so generally beloved--which gives Isabella all her popularity.--I have it not--but I know how to prize and respect it.--Harriet is my superior in all the charm and all the felicity it gives.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Dear Harriet!--I would not change you for the clearest-headed, longest-sighted, best-judging female breathing.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Oh!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: the coldness of a Jane Fairfax!--Harriet is worth a hundred such--And for a wife--a sensible man's wife--it is invaluable.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I mention no names; but happy the man who changes Emma for Harriet!"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: CHAPTER XIV Mrs. Elton was first seen at church: but though devotion might be interrupted, curiosity could not be satisfied by a bride in a pew, and it must be left for the visits in form which were then to be paid, to settle whether she were very pretty indeed, or only rather pretty, or not pretty at all.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Emma had feelings, less of curiosity than of pride or propriety, to make her resolve on not being the last to pay her respects; and she made a point of Harriet's going with her, that the worst of the business might be gone through as soon as possible.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She could not enter the house again, could not be in the same room to which she had with such vain artifice retreated three months ago, to lace up her boot, without _recollecting_.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: A thousand vexatious thoughts would recur.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Compliments, charades, and horrible blunders; and it was not to be supposed that poor Harriet should not be recollecting too; but she behaved very well, and was only rather pale and silent.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The visit was of course short; and there was so much embarrassment and occupation of mind to shorten it, that Emma would not allow herself entirely to form an opinion of the lady, and on no account to give one, beyond the nothing-meaning terms of being "elegantly dressed, and very pleasing."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She did not really like her.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She would not be in a hurry to find fault, but she suspected that there was no elegance;--ease, but not elegance.-- She was almost sure that for a young woman, a stranger, a bride, there was too much ease.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Her person was rather good; her face not unpretty; but neither feature, nor air, nor voice, nor manner, were elegant.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Emma thought at least it would turn out so.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: As for Mr. Elton, his manners did not appear--but no, she would not permit a hasty or a witty word from herself about his manners.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It was an awkward ceremony at any time to be receiving wedding visits, and a man had need be all grace to acquit himself well through it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The woman was better off; she might have the assistance of fine clothes, and the privilege of bashfulness, but the man had only his own good sense to depend on; and when she considered how peculiarly unlucky poor Mr. Elton was in being in the same room at once with the woman he had just married, the woman he had wanted to marry, and the woman whom he had been expected to marry, she must allow him to have the right to look as little wise, and to be as much affectedly, and as little really easy as could be.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Well, Miss Woodhouse," said Harriet, when they had quitted the house, and after waiting in vain for her friend to begin; "Well, Miss Woodhouse, (with a gentle sigh,) what do you think of her?--Is not she very charming?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: There was a little hesitation in Emma's answer.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Oh!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: yes--very--a very pleasing young woman."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I think her beautiful, quite beautiful."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: 'And now, Miss Woodhouse, I do not think I shall mind seeing them again.'
fr: 'et maintenant, Mlle Woodhouse, je ne crois pas qu'il me sera penible de les revoir :'

eng: 'He is just as superior as ever;--but being married, you know, it is quite a different thing.'
fr: 'j'admirerais toujours M. Elton ; mais je le considererai sous un autre jour.'

eng: 'No, indeed, Miss Woodhouse, you need not be afraid; I can sit and admire him now without any great misery.'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: 'To know that he has not thrown himself away, is such a comfort!--'
fr: 'La pensee qu'il a fait un bon mariage me console.'

eng: 'She does seem a charming young woman, just what he deserves.'
fr: 'Heureuse creature !'

eng: 'Happy creature!'
fr: 'Eh bien, je leur souhaite de tout mon coeur d'etre heureux ;'

eng: "How delightful!"
fr: 'Comme c'est delicieux !'

eng: When the visit was returned, Emma made up her mind. She could then see more and judge better.
fr: Peu de jours apres, M. et Mme Elton vinrent a Hartfield et Emma fut a meme de se former une opinion ; elle etait seule avec son pere ;

eng: From Harriet's happening not to be at Hartfield, and her father's being present to engage Mr. Elton, she had a quarter of an hour of the lady's conversation to herself, and could composedly attend to her; and the quarter of an hour quite convinced her that Mrs. Elton was a vain woman, extremely well satisfied with herself, and thinking much of her own importance; that she meant to shine and be very superior, but with manners which had been formed in a bad school, pert and familiar; that all her notions were drawn from one set of people, and one style of living; that if not foolish she was ignorant, and that her society would certainly do Mr. Elton no good.
fr: M. Elton entretint M. Woodhouse et elle put se consacrer a la jeune mariee : un quart d'heure de conversation suffit a la convaincre que Mme Elton etait une femme vaine, contente d'elle-meme, pleine de pretentions ; ses manieres avaient ete formees a mauvaise ecole ; elle etait impertinente et familiere ; elle ne paraissait pas sotte mais Emma la soupconna de ne pas etre particulierement instruite.

eng: Harriet would have been a better match.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: If not wise or refined herself, she would have connected him with those who were; but Miss Hawkins, it might be fairly supposed from her easy conceit, had been the best of her own set.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The rich brother-in-law near Bristol was the pride of the alliance, and his place and his carriages were the pride of him.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The very first subject after being seated was Maple Grove, "My brother Mr. Suckling's seat;"--a comparison of Hartfield to Maple Grove.
fr: Mme Elton commenta aussitot par faire part a Emma de la bonne impression que lui produisait Hartfield. -- Cette maison me rappelle tout a fait Maple Grove, dit-elle, la propriete de mon beau-frere, M. Suckling.

eng: The grounds of Hartfield were small, but neat and pretty; and the house was modern and well-built. Mrs. Elton seemed most favourably impressed by the size of the room, the entrance, and all that she could see or imagine. "Very like Maple Grove indeed!--She was quite struck by the likeness!--That room was the very shape and size of the morning-room at Maple Grove; her sister's favourite room."--Mr. Elton was appealed to.--"Was not it astonishingly like?--She could really almost fancy herself at Maple Grove." "And the staircase--You know, as I came in, I observed how very like the staircase was; placed exactly in the same part of the house. I really could not help exclaiming! I assure you, Miss Woodhouse, it is very delightful to me, to be reminded of a place I am so extremely partial to as Maple Grove. I have spent so many happy months there! (with a little sigh of sentiment). A charming place, undoubtedly. Every body who sees it is struck by its beauty; but to me, it has been quite a home. Whenever you are transplanted, like me, Miss Woodhouse, you will understand how very delightful it is to meet with any thing at all like what one has left behind. I always say this is quite one of the evils of matrimony."
fr: Cette piece est precisement de la grandeur et de la forme de celle ou ma soeur se tient le plus volontiers. Elle en appela a M. Elton. -- La ressemblance n'est-elle pas frappante ? Et l'escalier ? Quand je suis entree, je n'ai pu m'empecher de pousser une exclamation. J'ai, je dois l'avouer, une grande predilection pour Maple Grove, que je considere comme mon veritable << home >>. Si jamais, Mademoiselle Woodhouse, vous etes transplantee comme je le suis, vous comprendrez combien il est delicieux de rencontrer sur son chemin un decor familier.

eng: Emma made as slight a reply as she could; but it was fully sufficient for Mrs. Elton, who only wanted to be talking herself. "So extremely like Maple Grove!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: ~~~ And it is not merely the house--the grounds, I assure you, as far as I could observe, are strikingly like.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Oh! yes, I am quite aware of that. It is the garden of England, you know."
fr: "-- Oh ! je sais parfaitement a quoi m'en tenir : ce comte est le jardin de l'Angleterre."

eng: "Surry is the garden of England."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Yes; but we must not rest our claims on that distinction. Many counties, I believe, are called the garden of England, as well as Surry."
fr: "-- Oui ; mais il ne faut pas appuyer notre opinion sur ce dicton car, si je ne me trompe, plusieurs autres provinces se parent de cette couronne."

eng: "No, I fancy not," replied Mrs. Elton, with a most satisfied smile. "I never heard any county but Surry called so."
fr: "-- Je ne l'ai jamais entendu dire, assura Mme Elton avec un sourire satisfait."

eng: Emma was silenced.
fr: "Emma n'insista pas."

eng: "My brother and sister have promised us a visit in the spring, or summer at farthest," continued Mrs. Elton; "and that will be our time for exploring. While they are with us, we shall explore a great deal, I dare say."
fr: "-- Mon beau-frere et ma soeur nous ont promis de venir nous voir au commencement de l'ete, continua Mme Elton. Pendant leur sejour nous comptons explorer le pays."

eng: "They will have their barouche-landau, of course, which holds four perfectly; and therefore, without saying any thing of _our_ carriage, we should be able to explore the different beauties extremely well."
fr: "Ils ameneront probablement leur landau dans lequel quatre personnes tiennent a l'aise ; de cette facon nous serons a meme de visiter les differents sites fort commodement."

eng: "They would hardly come in their chaise, I think, at that season of the year. Indeed, when the time draws on, I shall decidedly recommend their bringing the barouche-landau; it will be so very much preferable."
fr: "A cette epoque de l'annee ils n'auront certainement pas l'idee de voyager dans leur berline, mais pour eviter toute surprise je vais leur ecrire a ce propos."

eng: "When people come into a beautiful country of this sort, you know, Miss Woodhouse, one naturally wishes them to see as much as possible; and Mr. Suckling is extremely fond of exploring. We explored to King's-Weston twice last summer, in that way, most delightfully, just after their first having the barouche-landau."
fr: "M. Suckling aime beaucoup les excursions : l'ete dernier nous avons ete jusqu'a King Weston dans les meilleures conditions, precisement apres l'acquisition du landau."

eng: "You have many parties of that kind here, I suppose, Miss Woodhouse, every summer?"
fr: "Je suppose, mademoiselle Woodhouse, que vous faites souvent de grandes promenades."

eng: "No; not immediately here. We are rather out of distance of the very striking beauties which attract the sort of parties you speak of; and we are a very quiet set of people, I believe; more disposed to stay at home than engage in schemes of pleasure."
fr: "-- Non ; nous sommes un peu eloignes des points de vue reputes et d'autre part nous sommes tous ici, je crois, extremement casaniers et peu disposes a organiser des parties de plaisir."

eng: "Ah! there is nothing like staying at home for real comfort."
fr: "-- Personne n'est plus attache a son << home >> que moi ; mon amour de la maison etait passe en proverbe a Maple Grove."

eng: "Nobody can be more devoted to home than I am. I was quite a proverb for it at Maple Grove."
fr: (Partially aligned with previous sentence)

eng: "Many a time has Selina said, when she has been going to Bristol, 'I really cannot get this girl to move from the house. I absolutely must go in by myself, though I hate being stuck up in the barouche-landau without a companion; but Augusta, I believe, with her own good-will, would never stir beyond the park paling.'"
fr: "Combien de fois Celina n'a-t-elle pas dit en se mettant en route pour Bristol : << Je renonce a demander a Augusta de m'accompagner, je deteste pourtant bien etre assise seule dans le landau, mais je sais par experience qu'il n'est pas possible de lui faire franchir la grille du parc.'"

eng: "Many a time has she said so; and yet I am no advocate for entire seclusion."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I perfectly understand your situation, however, Miss Woodhouse--(looking towards Mr. Woodhouse), Your father's state of health must be a great drawback.
fr: Neanmoins je comprends parfaitement votre situation, Mademoiselle Woodhouse ; l'etat de sante de votre pere doit etre pour vous un empechement serieux.

eng: Why does not he try Bath?--Indeed he should.
fr: Pourquoi n'essaye-t-il pas le traitement de Bath ?

eng: Let me recommend Bath to you. I assure you I have no doubt of its doing Mr. Woodhouse good.
fr: Laissez-moi vous recommander Bath, je suis sure que les eaux reussiraient parfaitement a M. Woodhouse.

eng: "My father tried it more than once, formerly; but without receiving any benefit; and Mr. Perry, whose name, I dare say, is not unknown to you, does not conceive it would be at all more likely to be useful now."
fr: -- Mon pere a suivi ce traitement a maintes reprises autrefois mais sans profit ; et M. Perry dont le nom ne vous est sans doute pas inconnu, ne juge pas opportun de le lui conseiller actuellement.

eng: "Ah! that's a great pity; for I assure you, Miss Woodhouse, where the waters do agree, it is quite wonderful the relief they give. In my Bath life, I have seen such instances of it!
fr: -- Je vous assure, Mlle Woodhouse, qu'on obtient des resultats incroyables : pendant mon sejour a Bath j'ai ete a meme de constater des cures merveilleuses.

eng: And it is so cheerful a place, that it could not fail of being of use to Mr. Woodhouse's spirits, which, I understand, are sometimes much depressed.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: And as to its recommendations to _you_, I fancy I need not take much pains to dwell on them. The advantages of Bath to the young are pretty generally understood. It would be a charming introduction for you, who have lived so secluded a life; and I could immediately secure you some of the best society in the place. A line from me would bring you a little host of acquaintance; and my particular friend, Mrs. Partridge, the lady I have always resided with when in Bath, would be most happy to shew you any attentions, and would be the very person for you to go into public with.
fr: D'autre part, les avantages de Bath pour les jeunes filles sont connus ; ce serait un excellent milieu pour vos debuts dans le monde : un mot de moi vous ferait accueillir cordialement par la meilleure societe de l'endroit ; mon amie intime, Mme Partridge, la dame chez qui j'ai toujours habite pendant mes sejours a Bath, serait trop heureuse de s'occuper de vous et de vous servir de chaperon.

eng: It was as much as Emma could bear, without being impolite. The idea of her being indebted to Mrs. Elton for what was called an _introduction_--of her going into public under the auspices of a friend of Mrs. Elton's--probably some vulgar, dashing widow, who, with the help of a boarder, just made a shift to live!--The dignity of Miss Woodhouse, of Hartfield, was sunk indeed!
fr: Mme Elton se tut a cet endroit de son discours : ce fut heureux car elle avait atteint la limite de ce qu'Emma pouvait entendre sans etre impolie : celle-ci fremit a l'idee d'etre l'obligee de Mme Elton, d'aller dans le monde sous les auspices d'une amie de cette derniere, probablement quelque veuve vulgaire et intrigante ! La dignite de Mlle Woodhouse etait veritablement ecrasee !

eng: She restrained herself, however, from any of the reproofs she could have given, and only thanked Mrs. Elton coolly; "but their going to Bath was quite out of the question; and she was not perfectly convinced that the place might suit her better than her father."
fr: Neanmoins elle s'efforca de dissimuler son irritation et se contenta de remercier froidement Mme Elton. -- Il ne peut etre question pour nous d'aller a Bath, repondit-elle. Je ne suis pas sure du reste si l'endroit me conviendrait plus qu'a mon pere.

eng: And then, to prevent farther outrage and indignation, changed the subject directly.
fr: Pour eviter le retour de nouveaux outrages, Emma se hata de changer de conversation.

eng: "I do not ask whether you are musical, Mrs. Elton. Upon these occasions, a lady's character generally precedes her; and Highbury has long known that you are a superior performer."
fr: -- Je ne vous demande pas si vous etes musicienne, Mme Elton. Dans ces occasions on est generalement au courant de toutes les qualites d'une personne avant de la connaitre ; Highbury sait depuis longtemps que vous avez un talent superieur.

eng: "Oh! ~~~ no, indeed; I must protest against any such idea. A superior performer!--very far from it, I assure you. Consider from how partial a quarter your information came. I am doatingly fond of music--passionately fond;--and my friends say I am not entirely devoid of taste; but as to any thing else, upon my honour my performance is _mediocre_ to the last degree.
fr: -- Oh ! ~~~ non ! du tout ; je proteste contre cette allegation, reflechissez a quelle source vous avez puise vos informations ! J'aime beaucoup la musique, passionnement meme et je ne suis pas, au dire de mes amis, depourvue de gout ; mais quant au reste, sur mon honneur, mon jeu est tout a fait mediocre.

eng: You, Miss Woodhouse, I well know, play delightfully.
fr: Mais vous, Mademoiselle Woodhouse, vous jouez, parait-il delicieusement ; ce sera une vraie joie pour moi de vous entendre.

eng: ~~~ I assure you it has been the greatest satisfaction, comfort, and delight to me, to hear what a musical society I am got into. I absolutely cannot do without music. It is a necessary of life to me; and having always been used to a very musical society, both at Maple Grove and in Bath, it would have been a most serious sacrifice.
fr: Je ne puis pas, a la lettre, me passer de musique. Au debut de notre engagement, M. Elton, en me decrivant ma future residence, m'exprimait sa crainte que je ne trouvasse la vie trop retiree, il s'inquietait aussi de l'inferiorite de la maison ; je lui repondis : << Je renonce volontiers au monde, au theatre, au bal et je ne crains pas du tout la solitude.
